verse.text: [note]1[/note]Inasmuch as [note]2[/note]many have undertaken to [note]3[/note]draw up a narrative concerning the [note]4[/note]matters which have been fully accomplished among us,
verse.note: Or, Since, as is well known,...
This indicates that there were more than four who wrote an account of the Savior's earthly life.
Or, set in order.

Events of John the Baptist's birth, ministry, and martyrdom, and of Jesus' birth, life, ministry, teaching, death, resurrection, and ascension for the accomplishing of God's redemption that sinners may be saved by grace.

verse.text: Even as [note]1[/note]those who from the beginning became [xref]a[/xref]eyewitnesses and [note]2[/note]ministers of the [note]3[/note]word have [note]4[/note]delivered [i]them[/i] to us,
verse.note: The first group of New Testament believers, composed of those who were with the Savior during His ministry on earth.

Lit., servants; i.e., official servants, apparitors, who attend or serve an officer or authority to carry out his orders. The Greek word is used in [link]4:20[/link]; [link]Matt. 5:25[/link]; [link]Mark 14:54[/link]; [link]Acts 26:16[/link]; and [link]1 Cor. 4:1[/link].
The word of the gospel, ministered and preached to people ([link]Acts 6:4[/link]; [link]8:4[/link]).
This indicates that the writer of this Gospel was not among those disciples who were with the Savior during His earthly life.

verse.text: It seemed good to [note]1[/note]me also, having carefully investigated all things from the first, to write [i]them[/i] out for you in an [xref]a[/xref]orderly fashion, most [xref]b[/xref]excellent [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Theophilus,
verse.note: The early church recognized Luke as the author of both this Gospel and the Acts. Luke's authorship is evident from the style of composition of the two books. Luke was a Gentile ([link]Col. 4:14[/link]; cf. [link]Col. 4:11[/link]), probably an Asiatic Greek, and a physician ([link]Col. 4:14[/link]). Beginning in Troas, he joined Paul in his ministry and accompanied him in his last three ministry journeys ([link]Acts 16:10-17[/link]; [link]20:5-21:18[/link]; [link]27:1-28:15[/link]). He was a faithful companion of Paul until Paul's martyrdom ([link]Philem. 24[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:11[/link]). Hence, his Gospel should represent Paul's views, as Mark's represents Peter's (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in Mark 1[/link]).[br][br]The Gospels of Luke, Matthew, and Mark are synoptic in regard to the Savior's humanity (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Mark 1[/link]). Luke's Gospel reveals God among men in His saving grace given to fallen mankind. Its purpose is to present the Savior as a genuine, normal, and perfect man. It gives a complete genealogy of the man Jesus, from His parents back to Adam, the first generation of mankind, and shows that He is a genuine descendant of man — a son of man (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link], pars. 2 and 3, in [link]Matt. 1[/link]). Its record of the life of this man impresses us with the completeness and perfection of His humanity. Hence, this Gospel stresses the Lord as the Man-Savior. Based on the moral principles that apply to all men, it presents gospel messages, as in [link]4:16-21[/link]; [link]7:41-43[/link]; [link]12:14-21[/link]; and [link]13:2-5[/link]; gospel parables, as in [link]10:30-37[/link]; [link]14:16-24[/link]; [link]15:3-32[/link]; and [link]18:9-14[/link]; and gospel cases, as in [link]7:36-50[/link]; [link]13:10-17[/link]; [link]16:19-31[/link]; [link]19:1-10[/link]; and [link]23:39-43[/link]. None of these are recorded in the other Gospels. In contrast to Matthew, Luke does not stress the dispensational aspect or the Jewish background. It is the Gospel written to mankind in general, and it announces the good news to all people ([link]2:10[/link]). Its characteristic is absolutely not Jewish but Gentile ([link]4:25-28[/link]). It is a Gospel to all sinners, both Jewish and Gentile. As such, the sequence of its record is according to morality, not according to historical events. See notes [link]16[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Matt. 8[/link] and [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 14[/link].
The Greek word means [i]loved by God,[/i] or [i]friend of God.[/i] Probably a Gentile believer who occupied some official position under the Roman Empire.

verse.text: So that you may fully know the certainty of the things concerning which you were instructed.

In the days of [xref]a[/xref]Herod, king of Judea, there was a certain priest named Zachariah, of the [note]1[/note]course of Abijah; and his wife was of the daughters of [xref]b[/xref]Aaron, and her name was Elizabeth.
verse.note: This was the eighth of the twenty-four courses of priestly service ordained by David ([link]1 Chron. 24:10[/link]).

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]they were both [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]righteous before God, [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]walking in all the commandments and [note]4[/note]ordinances of the Lord, [xref]c[/xref]blameless.
verse.note: They were among God's chosen people and had been preserved in the custody of the law in the Old Testament and brought forth by it to be useful to God for the initiation of the gospel in the New Testament.

This does not contradict [link]Rom. 3:20[/link]. Here it means to be right, i.e., blameless, in the sight of God according to the Old Testament commandments and ordinances ([link]2:25[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:6[/link]). It does not mean that these righteous ones were not sinful, without sin and sins. They were blameless, but not without blemish. They still needed the unblemished sin and trespass offerings in type ([link]Lev. 4:28[/link]; [link]5:15[/link]) for their expiation that they might have contact with God.
I.e., living according to.

The Old Testament law is generally called "the law"; its contents are divided into three categories: commandments, statutes, and ordinances. Commandments, as God's basic commands, are the general principles of the law. There are ten commandments ([link]Exo. 20:2-17[/link]). Statutes, or laws, regulations, set forth, explain in detail, and supplement the commandments, as recorded in [link]Exo. 20:22-26[/link]. Ordinances, like statutes, set forth, explain in detail, and supplement the commandments, and, in addition, include verdicts, as recorded in [link]Exo. 21:1-23:19[/link]. Ordinances minus the verdicts become statutes. The Greek word for [i]ordinances[/i] here is the same as that in [link]Rom. 2:26[/link] and in [link]Heb. 9:1[/link], [link]10[/link].

verse.text: And they had [note]1[/note]no child, because Elizabeth was barren, and they were both advanced in their days.
verse.note: This was sovereign of the Lord. It afforded God an opportunity to initiate His gospel not by man's natural strength but by His divine act.

verse.text: And while he served as priest in the [xref]a[/xref]order of his course before God,
According to the custom of the priestly service, the lot fell to him to enter into the [xref]a[/xref]temple of the Lord and [note]1[/note]burn incense.
verse.note: On the incense altar within the Holy Place ([link]v. 11[/link]; [link]Exo. 30:6-8[/link]; [link]1 Sam. 2:28[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 23:13[/link]; [link]2 Chron. 29:11[/link]).

verse.text: And all the multitude of the people were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]praying outside at the hour of the burning of incense.
verse.note: The prayer of God's people affords Him a way to carry out His plan.

verse.text: And an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing at the right side of the [xref]a[/xref]altar of incense.
And Zachariah was troubled when he saw [i]him,[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]fear fell upon him.

But the angel said to him, Do [xref]a[/xref]not be afraid, Zachariah, because your petition has been heard, and your wife Elizabeth will [note]1[/note]bear you a son, and you shall call his name [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]John.
verse.note: This indicates that Zachariah had prayed that his wife would bear him a son. This indicates also that our prayer carries out God's operation, implying that our natural strength must be brought to an end that God's operation may begin by His divine act. This was revealed in the case of Abraham and Sarah ([link]Gen. 17:15-19[/link]) and in the case of Hannah ([link]1 Sam. 1:5-20[/link]).

Of Hebrew origin, [i]Jehohanan[/i] contracted to [i]Johanan[/i] ([link]2 Kings 25:23[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 3:24[/link]; [link]2 Chron. 28:12[/link]). The Hebrew word means [i]Jehovah is favorable, Jehovah shows grace,[/i] or [i]Jehovah is the gracious Giver.[/i]

verse.text: And you will have joy and exultation, and many will rejoice at his birth.

For he will be [xref]a[/xref]great in the sight of the Lord, and he shall by [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]no means drink wine and liquor. And he will be filled with the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Holy Spirit, even from his mother's [xref]d[/xref]womb,
verse.note: This indicates that John would be a Nazarite ([link]Num. 6:1-4[/link]). He would not drink wine but would be filled with the Holy Spirit; the Holy Spirit replaced the wine ([link]Eph. 5:18[/link]).

In the New Testament this is the first divine title ascribed to the Spirit of God. Such a title is not used in the Old Testament. (In [link]Psa. 51:11[/link] and [link]Isa. 63:10-11[/link], [i]Holy Spirit[/i] [KJV] should be translated [i]Spirit of holiness[/i].) It was at this time, for the initiation of the gospel of God, to prepare the way for the Savior's coming and to prepare a human body for Him, that this divine title of God's Spirit was used. The preparing of the way for the Savior's coming required that His forerunner be filled with the Holy Spirit even from his mother's womb, so that he could separate the people unto God from all things other than God, making them holy unto Him for His purpose. The preparing of a human body for the Savior required that the Holy Spirit impart the divine nature into humanity, making man holy for the carrying out of God's plan of redemption.

verse.text: And many of the sons of Israel he will turn to the Lord their God.

And [i]it is[/i] he [i]who[/i] will go [xref]a[/xref]before Him in the spirit and power of [note]1[/note]Elijah to turn the [xref]b[/xref]hearts of the fathers to the children, and the [xref]c[/xref]disobedient [note]2[/note]to the [note]3[/note]prudence of the righteous, to [xref]d[/xref]prepare for the Lord a people made ready.
verse.note: This was the fulfillment of [link]Mal. 4:5[/link] ([link]Matt. 11:14[/link] and note 2; [link]Mark 9:11-13[/link]).
Lit., in [the sphere of] the prudence of the righteous.
Or, counsel. Wisdom is the inward insight, whereas prudence is the outward practical application of wisdom. Hence, [i]prudence[/i] can be rendered [i]counsel.[/i]

verse.text: And Zachariah said to the angel, By what shall I know this? For I am an [xref]a[/xref]old man and my wife is advanced in [note]1[/note]years.
verse.note: Lit., her days.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]angel answered and said to him, I am [xref]b[/xref]Gabriel, who stands before God, and I was sent to speak to you and to announce the good news of these things to you.
And behold, you shall be [xref]a[/xref]silent and not able to speak until the day that these things happen, because you did [note]1[/note]not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their time.
verse.note: Believing opens the praising and testifying mouth ([link]2 Cor. 4:13[/link]); unbelief keeps our tongue silent.

verse.text: And the people were waiting for Zachariah, and they marveled at his delaying in the [xref]a[/xref]temple.
And when he came out, he was not able to speak to them, and they realized that he had seen a [xref]a[/xref]vision in the temple. And he made signs to them and remained dumb.
And when the days of his service were fulfilled, he went to his house.
And after these days Elizabeth his wife conceived and stayed in seclusion for five months, saying,
In this way has the Lord dealt with me in the days in which He looked upon [i]me[/i] to take away my [xref]a[/xref]reproach among men.
And in the sixth month the angel [xref]a[/xref]Gabriel was sent from God to a city of [note]1[/note]Galilee named [xref]b[/xref]Nazareth,
verse.note: Galilee was a region without fame, and Nazareth was a despised city ([link]John 7:52[/link]; [link]1:46[/link]).

verse.text: To a [xref]a[/xref]virgin engaged to a man named [xref]b[/xref]Joseph, of the house of [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]David; and the virgin's name was Mary.
verse.note: The virgin Mary lived in a despised city in a region without fame, but she was a descendant of the royal family of King David ([link]vv. 31-32[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:16[/link], notes 1 and 2).

verse.text: And he came to her and said, Rejoice, you who have been graced! The Lord is [xref]a[/xref]with you. [note]1[/note]
verse.note: Some MSS add, You are blessed among women.

verse.text: And she was greatly troubled at this saying and began reasoning what kind of greeting this might be.
And the angel said to her, Do [xref]a[/xref]not be afraid, Mary, for you have found [xref]b[/xref]grace with God.
And behold, you will [xref]a[/xref]conceive in [i]your[/i] womb and bear a son, and you shall call His name [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Jesus.
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link].

verse.text: He will be [xref]a[/xref]great and will be called [xref]b[/xref]Son of the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Most High; and the Lord God will give to Him the [xref]d[/xref]throne of [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]David His father,
verse.note: A divine title, denoting the Supreme (God — [link]Gen. 14:18[/link]); hence, in Greek there is no article. Jesus is great because He is the Son of the Most High, the Supreme God.

Jesus, conceived of the Holy Spirit and born of a human virgin, is the Son of the Most High God, and at the same time He is the son of a highly ranked man, David the king ([link]Matt. 1:1[/link]; [link]22:45[/link]). His status is both divine and human.

verse.text: And He will [note]1[/note]reign over the house of Jacob [xref]a[/xref]forever, and of His [note]2[/note]kingdom there will be [xref]b[/xref]no end.
verse.note: Jesus will have the house of Jacob — the nation of Israel — as the center of His reign ([link]Acts 1:6[/link]; [link]15:16[/link]), through which He will rule over the entire world as His kingdom ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]), first in the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]) and then in the new heaven and new earth for eternity ([link]Rev. 22:3[/link], [link]5[/link]).
The preceding verse unveils the family of Jesus; this verse unveils His kingdom.

verse.text: But Mary said to the angel, How will this be, since I have not known a man?

And the angel answered and said to her, The [note]1[/note]Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the [xref]a[/xref]Most High will [note]2[/note]overshadow you; therefore also the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]holy thing which is born will be called the [xref]c[/xref]Son of God.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]2[/sup][/link].

Like the overshadowing of the cloud on the Mount of Transfiguration ([link]Matt. 17:5[/link]) and over the tabernacle ([link]Exo. 40:34[/link], [link]38[/link]). According to this verse, it seems that the Holy Spirit would be only upon Mary as the power for her to conceive the holy child. However, [link]Matt. 1:18[/link] and [link]20[/link] tell us that Mary "was found to be with child of the Holy Spirit," and that "that which has been begotten in her is of the Holy Spirit." This indicates that the divine essence out of the Holy Spirit had been begotten in Mary's womb before she delivered the child Jesus. Such a conception of the Holy Spirit in the human virgin, accomplished with the divine and human essences, constituted a mingling of the divine nature with the human nature, which produced a God-man, One who is both the complete God and the perfect man, possessing the divine nature and the human nature distinctly, without a third nature being produced. This is the most wonderful and most excellent person of Jesus, who is Jehovah the Savior.[br][br]The conception of John the Baptist was strikingly different in essence from that of Jesus the Savior. The conception of the Baptist was God's miracle, accomplished with the overage human essence, merely by the divine power without the involvement of the divine essence. This resulted in the bringing forth of a mere man who was filled with the Spirit of God ([link]v. 15[/link]) but who lacked the nature of God. The conception of the Savior was God's incarnation ([link]John 1:14[/link]), constituted not only by the divine power but also of the divine essence added to the human essence, thus producing the God-man of two natures — divinity and humanity. Through this, God joined Himself to humanity that He might be manifested in the flesh ([link]1 Tim. 3:16[/link]) and might be a Man-Savior ([link]2:11[/link]).
As the conception was of the Holy Spirit, so what was born of that conception was a holy thing, intrinsically holy. This was Jesus our Savior.

verse.text: And behold, Elizabeth your relative, she also has conceived a son in her old age, and this is the sixth month for her who is called barren,
Because no word will be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]impossible [note]2[/note]with God.
verse.note: Or, powerless.
Lit., from.

verse.text: And Mary said, Behold, the slave of the Lord. May it happen to me according to your word. And the [xref]a[/xref]angel departed from her.
And Mary rose up in those days and went to the [xref]a[/xref]hill country with haste, to a city of Judah,
And entered into the house of Zachariah and greeted Elizabeth.
And when Elizabeth heard Mary's greeting, the [note]1[/note]baby leaped in her womb, and Elizabeth was filled with the [xref]a[/xref]Holy Spirit.
verse.note: The forerunner exulted ([link]v. 44[/link]) on meeting the Savior even while both of them were still in their mothers' wombs.

verse.text: And she lifted up her voice with a loud cry and said, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]fruit of your womb!
verse.note: Elizabeth's blessing, given through the Holy Spirit ([link]v. 41[/link]), revealed the humanity of the Savior as the fruit and the deity of the Savior as the Lord ([link]v. 43[/link]) and confirmed Mary's faith in the Lord's word ([link]v. 45[/link]). Such a blessing indicates that Elizabeth too was a godly woman, fit for God's use in carrying out His purpose.

Here and in [link]Acts 2:30[/link], [i]fruit[/i] is used to signify Christ only in the sense of offspring. In [link]Rev. 22:2[/link] the same Greek word is used to signify the fruit of the tree of life. Christ is the Shoot of Jehovah ([link]Isa. 4:2[/link]) and of David ([link]Jer. 23:5[/link]) and the fruit of Mary and of David ([link]Acts 2:30[/link]) that we may eat of Him as the tree of life ([link]Rev. 2:7[/link]).

verse.text: And how has this [i]happened[/i] to me, that the mother of my [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Lord should come to me?
verse.note: Elizabeth, being filled with the Holy Spirit ([link]v. 41[/link]), recognized the fruit of Mary's womb as her Lord, acknowledging the deity of the child to be born of Mary ([link]Psa. 110:1[/link]; [link]Matt. 22:43-45[/link]).

verse.text: For behold, when the sound of your greeting came to my ears, the baby leaped with exultation in my womb.
[note]1[/note]And blessed is she who has [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]believed, because there will be a [note]3[/note]completion of the things spoken to her from the Lord.
verse.note: Or, And blessed is she who believed that there will be a completion of the things spoken to her from the Lord.
In contrast to unbelieving Zachariah ([link]v. 20[/link]).
This is a prophecy given by the Holy Spirit ([link]v. 41[/link]) to confirm the Lord's word in [link]vv. 30-37[/link], a word spoken to Mary by the angel Gabriel.

verse.text: And Mary said, [note]1[/note]My [xref]a[/xref]soul [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]magnifies the Lord,
verse.note: Mary's poetic praise was composed of many quotations from the Old Testament, indicating that she was a godly woman qualified to be a channel for the Savior's incarnation, and that Jesus would grow up in a family that was filled with the knowledge and love of God's holy Word.

Mary's praise magnified the Lord based on her experience of God as her Savior through His everlasting mercy ([link]vv. 47-50[/link]) and on her observation of others' experience of God's merciful and faithful doings ([link]vv. 51-55[/link]). In content and standard, her praise was like some of the Old Testament psalms. However, she did not say anything concerning Christ, unlike Elizabeth in her blessing ([link]vv. 41-43[/link]) and Zachariah in his prophecy ([link]vv. 67-71[/link], [link]76-79[/link]) spoken through the Holy Spirit.

verse.text: And my [xref]a[/xref]spirit [note]1[/note]has [xref]b[/xref]exulted in God my [xref]c[/xref]Savior;
verse.note: First, Mary's spirit exulted in God; then her soul magnified the Lord. Her praise to God issued from her spirit and was expressed through her soul. Her spirit was filled with joy in God her Savior, and her soul manifested that joy for the magnifying of the Lord. She lived and acted in her spirit, which directed her soul. Her spirit's exulting in God was due to her enjoyment of God as her Savior, and her soul's magnifying of the Lord was due to her exalting of the Lord, who is Jehovah, the great To Be.

verse.text: Because He has [xref]a[/xref]looked upon the low estate of His slave. For behold, from now on all generations will count me [xref]b[/xref]blessed,
Because the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Mighty One has done [xref]b[/xref]great things for me, and [xref]c[/xref]holy is His name.
verse.note: Or, Powerful.

verse.text: And His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]mercy is unto [xref]b[/xref]generations and generations, unto those who [xref]c[/xref]fear Him.
verse.note: Both Mary and Zachariah stressed God's mercy ([link]vv. 54[/link], [link]58[/link], [link]72[/link], [link]78[/link]; see notes [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 4[/link] and [link]5[sup]2[/sup] in Titus 3[/link]), thus acknowledging their low estate ([link]v. 48[/link]) and humbly ([link]v. 52[/link]) recognizing that they were not worthy to be favored by God.

verse.text: He has exercised might with His [xref]a[/xref]arm; He has scattered [i]those who are[/i] [xref]b[/xref]proud in the understanding of their heart.
He has brought down [xref]a[/xref]potentates from thrones and has [xref]b[/xref]exalted the [xref]c[/xref]humble;
The [xref]a[/xref]hungry He has filled with good things, and the rich He has sent away empty.
He has upheld Israel His [xref]a[/xref]servant to [xref]b[/xref]remember mercy,
Even [note]1[/note]as He spoke to our fathers, to [xref]a[/xref]Abraham and to his seed forever.
verse.note: Referring to God's faithfulness in keeping His word. Both Mary and Zachariah stressed not only God's mercy (see note [link]50[sup]1[/sup][/link]) but also His faithfulness ([link]vv. 70[/link], [link]72[/link], and note [link]72[sup]2[/sup][/link]). God's mercy took care of their condition, and His faithfulness took care of His position so that He could favor them with His gracious doings.

verse.text: And Mary remained with her about three months, and returned to her home.
Now the time was fulfilled for Elizabeth to give birth, and she bore a son.
And her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had magnified His mercy with her, and they rejoiced with her.
And on the eighth day they came to [xref]a[/xref]circumcise the little child, and they tried to call him after the name of his father, Zachariah.
Yet his mother answered and said, No, but he shall be called [xref]a[/xref]John.
And they said to her, There is no one among your relatives who is called by this name.
And they gestured to his father as to what he would want him to be called.
And asking for a tablet, he wrote, saying, John is his name. And they all marveled.
And his [note]1[/note]mouth was opened instantly, and his [xref]a[/xref]tongue [i]loosed,[/i] and he began to speak, blessing God.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]fear came on all those dwelling around them, and in all the [xref]b[/xref]hill country of Judea all these [note]1[/note]things were spread about.
verse.note: Lit., words.

verse.text: And all who heard [i]these things[/i] put [i]them[/i] in their [xref]a[/xref]heart, saying, What then will this little child be? For indeed the hand of the Lord was [xref]b[/xref]with him.
And Zachariah his father was filled with the [xref]a[/xref]Holy Spirit and prophesied, saying,
[xref]a[/xref]Blessed be the Lord, the God of [xref]b[/xref]Israel, because He has [xref]c[/xref]visited and accomplished [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]redemption for His people,
verse.note: Zachariah's prophecy concerned God's redemptive move for His people unto their salvation, accomplished by the raising of Christ, in His humanity, as a horn of salvation in the house of David, and, in His divinity, as the rising sun from on high, through God's rich mercy according to His holy covenant ([link]vv. 68-73[/link], [link]76-79[/link]). Concerning the divine-human person and the saving work of the Man-Savior, his prophecy brings in more light than Elizabeth's blessing, yet it still bears an Old Testament color in the Old Testament style and flavor, like Mary's praise and Elizabeth's blessing.

verse.text: And raised a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]horn of salvation for us in the house of [xref]b[/xref]David His servant,
verse.note: Jesus the Savior, who came out of the house of David ([link]Jer. 23:5-6[/link]).

verse.text: Even [note]1[/note]as He spoke through the mouth of His holy [xref]a[/xref]prophets [note]2[/note]from of old —
verse.note: See note [link]55[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Or, from the foundation of the world.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Salvation from our enemies and from the [xref]b[/xref]hand of all who hate us,
To accomplish [note]1[/note]mercy with our fathers and to [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]remember His holy [xref]b[/xref]covenant,
verse.note: See note [link]50[sup]1[/sup][/link]. So in [link]v. 78[/link].
Referring to God's faithfulness in keeping His word, which was made His covenant by His oath ([link]v. 73[/link]).

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]oath which He swore to Abraham our father,
verse.note: God's covenant is enacted upon His promise ([link]Heb. 8:6[/link]). A promise is a common, ordinary word that has not been confirmed by an oath. In the Old Testament, after God made a promise, He sealed it with an oath. He swore by His Godhead to confirm His promise. Thus His promise was made His covenant.

verse.text: To grant us that we, having been delivered out of the hand of [i]our[/i] enemies, might [note]1[/note]serve Him without fear,
verse.note: Lit., serve Him as priests.

verse.text: In [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]holiness and [xref]b[/xref]righteousness before Him all our days.
verse.note: The emphasis of [i]holiness[/i] here is godliness and devoutness before God; the Greek word is different from that for [i]holy[/i] in [link]Rom. 1:2[/link]. Holiness is mainly toward God, and righteousness is mainly toward men. This book stresses the humanity of Jesus; hence, holiness and righteousness are singled out here as the main characteristics of man's behavior before God, by which man serves Him.

verse.text: And you also, little child, shall be called a [xref]a[/xref]prophet of the [xref]b[/xref]Most High, for you will go [xref]c[/xref]before the [note]1[/note]Lord to [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]prepare His ways,
verse.note: Jesus the Savior ([link]v. 17[/link]; [link]Mal. 3:1[/link]).
See note [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: To give knowledge of [xref]a[/xref]salvation to His people by the [xref]b[/xref]forgiveness of their sins,
Because of the merciful [xref]a[/xref]compassions of our God, in which the rising [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sun will [xref]c[/xref]visit us from on high,
verse.note: Jesus the Savior was the dawning sun to the dark age. His coming ended the night of the Old Testament and began the day of the New Testament. As the fruit in Elizabeth's blessing ([link]v. 42[/link] and note 2), He is life to us ([link]John 14:6[/link]); as the sun in Zachariah's prophecy, He is light to us ([link]John 9:5[/link]; [link]Matt. 4:16[/link]). As such a One, He is the Accomplisher and the center of God's redemption that His people may obtain salvation.

verse.text: To shine upon those sitting in [xref]a[/xref]darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the way of [xref]b[/xref]peace.
And the little child [xref]a[/xref]grew and became strong in [note]1[/note]spirit, and he was in the [xref]b[/xref]wilderness until the day of his presentation to Israel.
verse.note: The forerunner's mother and father were filled with the Holy Spirit ([link]vv. 41[/link], [link]67[/link]). It was easy for their child to grow and become strong in his spirit and thereby to live in the wilderness. For him to grow and become strong in spirit means that he was with and for God, and for him to live in the wilderness means that he was apart from man's culture and religion that God might have a free and clear way to use him as the forerunner of the Savior.

verse.text: And in those days a decree went out from [xref]a[/xref]Caesar Augustus for a [xref]b[/xref]census to be taken of all the inhabited earth.
This was the [note]1[/note]first census that took place when Quirinius [xref]a[/xref]governed Syria.
verse.note: This is sovereign of God, as mentioned in [link]Prov. 21:1[/link]. By this census Mary and Joseph were brought from Nazareth to Bethlehem that the Savior might be born there for the fulfillment of the prophecy concerning the place of His birth ([link]Micah 5:2[/link]; [link]John 7:41-42[/link]).

verse.text: And all went to be registered, each to his own city.

And [xref]a[/xref]Joseph also went up from Galilee out of the city of [xref]b[/xref]Nazareth into Judea, to David's city, which is called [xref]c[/xref]Bethlehem, because he was of the [note]1[/note]house and family of David,
verse.note: The royal house and family in line to inherit the throne of David ([link]3:23-31[/link]; [link]1:32[/link]; cf. [link]Matt. 1:6-16[/link]).

verse.text: To be registered with Mary, who was engaged to him and was [xref]a[/xref]pregnant.
And while they were there, the days were fulfilled for her to bear,

And she [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bore her [xref]b[/xref]firstborn son; and she wrapped Him in swaddling clothes and laid Him in a [note]2[/note]manger because there was no place for them in the [xref]c[/xref]inn.
verse.note: Luke presents a Man-Savior. After the narration of the conception of the Man-Savior, Luke gives us in this chapter an excellent record of (1) His genuine human birth, which was according to the law of God's creation of man, that He might be a Man-Savior for the salvation of man; (2) His physical circumcision, carried out according to the law of God's ordination ([link]vv. 21-24[/link]), that He might be the legal seed of Abraham ([link]Gen. 17:9-14[/link]), the One in whom God's promise to Abraham — "In you all the families of the earth will be blessed" ([link]Gen. 12:3[/link]) — as the gospel announced to him ([link]Gal. 3:8[/link]), could be fulfilled for all the Gentiles ([link]Gal. 3:14[/link]); (3) His physical growth, which was according to the law of human life ([link]v. 40[/link]), that He might be a perfect man to express God for the fulfillment of God's redemptive plan; and (4) His proper boyhood, during which He grew in His interest concerning the things of God, which interest was related to His deity as the Son of God the Father ([link]vv. 40-52[/link]), that He might have the full measure of wisdom, stature, and favor with God and men.[br][br]The record here concerning the Savior's birth and youth is very different from that in [link]Matt. 2[/link]. What Matthew recorded of events that occurred at the Savior's birth and during His youth constitutes striking evidence of Christ's legitimate kingship. Luke also recorded the Savior's birth and youth, but what he recorded were events of a different category, events that offer strong proof of Jesus' genuine humanity. The two records cover only two of the different aspects of the Savior's wonderful status. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 2[/link].
The Man-Savior's life began in a manger in the lowest estate because the inn was occupied by fallen mankind with his busy activities.

verse.text: And there were [note]1[/note]shepherds in the same region, spending their nights in the fields and keeping watch over their flock by night.
verse.note: Their work in shepherding the flock (which provided not only food for man but also offerings to God) and their diligence in keeping the night watches qualified them to be the first to receive the good news of the wonderful birth of the Savior, which was announced by the angel.

verse.text: And an [xref]a[/xref]angel of the Lord [xref]b[/xref]stood by them, and the [xref]c[/xref]glory of the Lord shone around them; and they [xref]d[/xref]feared greatly.
And the angel said to them, Do [xref]a[/xref]not be afraid; for behold, I [xref]b[/xref]announce to you good news of [xref]c[/xref]great joy, which will be for [xref]d[/xref]all the people,
Because today a [xref]a[/xref]Savior has been [xref]b[/xref]born to you in [xref]c[/xref]David's city, who is [xref]d[/xref]Christ the [xref]e[/xref]Lord.
And this will be the [note]1[/note]sign to you: you will find a [note]2[/note]baby wrapped in swaddling clothes and lying in a manger.
verse.note: A baby in a manger, signifying smallness in lowliness, was a sign of the Man-Savior's life.
This little baby is called the "Mighty God" in the prophecy concerning the Man-Savior ([link]Isa. 9:6[/link]).

verse.text: And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly [xref]a[/xref]army, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]praising God and saying,
verse.note: The exultation of the angels, who were excited by the birth of the Savior for man's salvation (cf. [link]15:7[/link]), resulted in their praising God.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Glory in the [xref]b[/xref]highest [i]places[/i] to God, and on [xref]c[/xref]earth [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]peace among [note]2[/note]men of [i]His[/i] [xref]e[/xref]good pleasure.
verse.note: The coming of the Savior rendered glory to God in the heavens and brought peace to men on earth.
Men chosen by God according to His good pleasure ([link]Eph. 1:5[/link]).

verse.text: And when the angels departed from them into heaven, the shepherds spoke to one another, Let us go then to Bethlehem and see this [note]1[/note]thing that has happened, which the Lord has made known to us.
verse.note: Lit., word.

verse.text: And they came in haste and found both Mary and Joseph, and the baby lying in the manger.
And when they had seen [i]this,[/i] they made known the word which was spoken to them concerning this little child.
And all those who heard marveled at the things spoken to them by the shepherds.
But Mary kept all these things and pondered [i]them[/i] in her [xref]a[/xref]heart.
And the shepherds returned, [xref]a[/xref]glorifying and praising God for all the things which they had heard and seen, even as it was spoken to them.
And when eight days were fulfilled to [xref]a[/xref]circumcise Him, His name was called [xref]b[/xref]Jesus, the name given by the angel before He was conceived in the womb.
And when the days for their [xref]a[/xref]purification according to the law of Moses were fulfilled, they [xref]b[/xref]brought Him up to Jerusalem to present [i]Him[/i] to the Lord
(Even as it is written in the [xref]a[/xref]law of the Lord, [xref]b[/xref]"Every male who opens the womb shall be called holy to the Lord"),
And to give a sacrifice according to what is said in the [note]1[/note]law of the Lord: [note]2[/note]A pair of turtledoves or two young doves.
verse.note: So that the Man-Savior could be a proper Israelite as a proper man before God and men, whatever was required in the law was fully fulfilled in [link]vv. 21-24[/link] ([link]v. 39[/link]).
This kind of sacrifice indicates the offerers' poverty ([link]Lev. 12:8[/link]). Poverty was another characteristic of the Man-Savior's life.

verse.text: And behold, there was a man in Jerusalem whose name was Simeon. And this man was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]righteous and [xref]b[/xref]devout, [xref]c[/xref]waiting for the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]consolation of Israel, and the [xref]e[/xref]Holy Spirit was upon him.
verse.note: Righteous mainly toward men and devout toward God.
The Man-Savior is the consolation of God's chosen people.

verse.text: And it had been divinely communicated to him by the Holy Spirit that he would [xref]a[/xref]not see death before he had seen the Lord's [xref]b[/xref]Christ.
And he came in the Spirit into the temple; and when the parents brought in the little child Jesus for them to do according to the custom of the [xref]a[/xref]law concerning Him,
He received Him into his arms and [xref]a[/xref]blessed God and said,
Now You release Your slave, Master, according to Your word, in [xref]a[/xref]peace;
For my eyes have seen Your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]salvation,
verse.note: The Man-Savior is God's salvation given to His people.

verse.text: Which You have prepared before the face of all the peoples,
A [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]light for revelation to the Gentiles and the [xref]b[/xref]glory of Your people Israel.
verse.note: The Man-Savior is a light to the Gentiles and the glory of Israel.

verse.text: And His father and mother marveled at the things being spoken about Him.

And Simeon blessed them and said to Mary His mother, Behold, this One is [note]1[/note]appointed for the [xref]a[/xref]falling and rising up of many in Israel and for a [note]2[/note]sign [xref]b[/xref]spoken against —
verse.note: The Man-Savior was appointed by God to be a test to the children of Israel, so that many of them would be stumbled by Him and many raised up by Him ([link]Rom. 9:33[/link]).

The Man-Savior is also a sign, a token, spoken against, contradicted, and opposed by the people who take sides with His enemy, so that the reasonings of many hearts may be revealed. In Simeon's word the Man-Savior was revealed as the consolation of Israel, the salvation of God, a light to the Gentiles, the glory of Israel, a test to Israel, and a sign opposed.

verse.text: And a [note]1[/note]sword will pierce through your own soul also — so that the reasonings of many hearts may be [note]2[/note]revealed.
verse.note: While the Man-Savior as a sign is spoken against, the suffering also pierces the inner being of the one who brings Him forth. This is to experience His suffering in our experience of Him.
What is within man's heart is easily revealed by his attitude toward Christ.

verse.text: And there was one Anna, a [xref]a[/xref]prophetess, a daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of [xref]b[/xref]Asher. She was well advanced in years, having lived with [i]her[/i] husband seven years from her virginity,

[note]1[/note]And she was a [xref]a[/xref]widow up to the age of eighty-four, who did not depart from the temple, [note]2[/note]serving [i]God[/i] with [xref]b[/xref]fastings and petitions [xref]c[/xref]night and day.
verse.note: Or, And she was a widow for eighty-four years.
Lit., serving as a priest.

verse.text: And at that very hour she came up and returned thanks to God, and spoke concerning Him to all those [xref]a[/xref]waiting for the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]redemption [note]2[/note]of Jerusalem.
verse.note: The Man-Savior as the redemption of God's people.
Some MSS read, in.

verse.text: And when they had finished all things according to the [xref]a[/xref]law of the Lord, they returned into Galilee, to their own city, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Nazareth.
verse.note: The Man-Savior was born in Bethlehem, the city of David, and remained there only briefly; but He was raised in Nazareth, a despised city, which was in Galilee, a despised region. This was arranged by the sovereignty of God in order to make Him a despised person. Being despised was another characteristic of the Savior's human life.

verse.text: And the little child [note]1[/note]grew and became strong, being filled with [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]wisdom, and the [note]3[/note]grace of God was upon Him.
verse.note: Grew in stature ([link]v. 52[/link]) and became strong in spirit (cf. [link]1:80[/link]).
The wisdom of the Savior's deity ([link]Col. 2:2-3[/link]) was revealed in proportion to the measure of His bodily growth. So in [link]v. 52[/link].
As a man, even Jesus needed the grace of God for His human life. He was filled with the wisdom of His deity and needed the grace of God in His humanity.

verse.text: And His parents went year by year to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem at the Feast of the [xref]b[/xref]Passover.
And when He became [note]1[/note]twelve years old, they went up according to the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]custom of the feast.
verse.note: At the age of twelve, a boy was called by the Jews "son of the law" and first incurred legal obligation (Alford). The number twelve signifies eternal perfection in God's administration. Hence, [i]twelve years old[/i] indicates that what the Lord did here was altogether related to God's administration.
Ordained by God that one might be legally a male in Israel ([link]Deut. 16:16[/link]).

verse.text: And when they had completed the days, while they were returning, the boy Jesus remained behind in Jerusalem, and His parents did not know [i]it.[/i]
But supposing that He was in the company, they went a day's journey and sought Him among their relatives and acquaintances.
And when they did not find Him, they returned to Jerusalem searching for Him.
And after three days they found Him in the [xref]a[/xref]temple, sitting in the midst of the [xref]b[/xref]teachers, both hearing them and questioning them.
And all those who heard Him were [xref]a[/xref]amazed at His understanding and His answers.

And when they saw Him, they were astounded; and His mother said to Him, Child, why have You treated us like this? Behold, Your father and I, being [note]1[/note]greatly distressed, have been seeking You.
verse.note: Lit., painfully distressed.

verse.text: And He said to them, Why is it that you were seeking Me? Did you not know that I [note]1[/note]must be [note]2[/note]in the things of [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]My Father?
verse.note: Indicating that the boy Jesus was caring for the interest of God.
Or, in My Father's house.
Indicating the deity of the boy Jesus ([link]John 5:18[/link]). In His humanity He was the son of His parents; in His deity He was the Son of God the Father.

verse.text: And they did [xref]a[/xref]not understand the word which He spoke to them.
And He went down with them and came to Nazareth, and was [note]1[/note]subject to them. And His mother carefully kept all these things in her [xref]a[/xref]heart.
verse.note: In His humanity He was subject to His human parents.

verse.text: And Jesus advanced in wisdom and [note]1[/note]stature and in the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace [i]manifested in Him[/i] before God and men.
verse.note: The Greek word denotes not only stature, as in [link]19:3[/link], but also age (see note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link]).

In grace before God because He was growing in the expression of God according to God's desire; in grace before men because He was growing in the divine attributes manifested in the human virtues, which were gracious to men. He was growing as a God-man before God and men.

verse.text: Now in the fifteenth year of the government of Tiberius [xref]a[/xref]Caesar, while [xref]b[/xref]Pontius Pilate was [xref]c[/xref]governor of Judea, and [xref]d[/xref]Herod was tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip was tetrarch of the region of Ituraea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias was tetrarch of Abilene,
During the high priesthood of Annas and [xref]a[/xref]Caiaphas, the word of God came to [xref]b[/xref]John the son of Zachariah in the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]wilderness.
verse.note: See notes [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link] and [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: And he came into all the region surrounding the Jordan, proclaiming a [note]1[/note]baptism of [xref]a[/xref]repentance [note]2[/note]for [xref]b[/xref]forgiveness of sins,
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]3[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].
See note [link]4[sup]4[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: As it is written in the book of the words of [xref]a[/xref]Isaiah the prophet, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]"A voice of one crying in the wilderness, [xref]c[/xref]Prepare the way of the Lord; make straight His paths.
verse.note: For the rest of the verse, see notes in [link]Mark 1:3[/link].

verse.text: Every [note]1[/note]ravine shall be filled up, and every [xref]a[/xref]mountain and hill shall be leveled; and the [xref]b[/xref]crooked [i]places[/i] shall become a straight [i]way,[/i] and the rough ways smooth.
verse.note: [i]Ravine, mountain, crooked places,[/i] and [i]rough ways[/i] are figures of speech describing the condition of men's hearts toward God and toward one another, and the relationships among men ([link]1:16-17[/link]), which needed to be dealt with to prepare the way for the Savior's coming.

verse.text: And all [note]1[/note]flesh shall see the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]salvation of God."
verse.note: I.e., fallen men.
The Savior is the salvation of God. When He comes, the salvation of God comes. To see and receive Him is to see and receive the salvation of God.

verse.text: He said therefore to the crowds going out to be baptized by him, [note]1[/note]Offspring of [xref]a[/xref]vipers, who prompted you to flee from the coming [xref]b[/xref]wrath?
verse.note: The offspring of vipers are the children of the devil ([link]1 John 3:10[/link]). The devil is the ancient serpent ([link]Rev. 12:9[/link]); hence, his children become serpents with the same life and nature that he has.

verse.text: Produce then fruits [xref]a[/xref]worthy of your repentance, and do not begin to say within yourselves, We have [xref]b[/xref]Abraham as [i]our[/i] father; for I tell you that God is able out of these stones to [note]1[/note]raise up children to Abraham.
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].

verse.text: And already also the axe is laid at the root of the trees. Every tree therefore that does not produce [xref]a[/xref]good fruit is cut down and cast into the [note]1[/note]fire.
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And the crowds asked him, saying, [xref]a[/xref]What then shall we do?
And he answered and said to them, He who has two [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]tunics, let him share with the one who has none; and he who has food, let him do likewise.
verse.note: A shirt-like undergarment. So throughout the book.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]tax collectors also came to be baptized, and they said to him, Teacher, what shall we do?
And he said to them, [xref]a[/xref]Exact nothing more than what you have been ordered to.

And some serving in the military also questioned him, saying, And we, what shall we do? And he said to them, Extort nothing from anyone by force, nor [note]1[/note]take [i]anything[/i] by false accusation, and be content with your wages.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 19[/link].

verse.text: Now while the people were in [note]1[/note]expectation and all were reasoning in their hearts concerning John, whether he might possibly be the Christ,
verse.note: Expecting to know whether John might be the Christ, the Messiah ([link]John 1:19-27[/link]).

verse.text: John answered and said to all, I [note]1[/note]baptize you in [xref]a[/xref]water, but He who is stronger than I is coming, the thong of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie. He Himself will baptize you in the [xref]b[/xref]Holy Spirit and fire,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 16-17[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 3:11-12[/link] and [link]Mark 1:7-8[/link].

verse.text: Whose winnowing fan is in His hand to thoroughly cleanse His [xref]a[/xref]threshing floor and to gather the wheat into His [xref]b[/xref]barn, but the chaff He will burn up with unquenchable [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]fire.
verse.note: The fire in the lake of fire ([link]Rev. 20:15[/link]).

verse.text: So, exhorting [i]them[/i] with many other things also, he [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]announced the gospel to the people.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: But Herod the tetrarch, because he was reproved by him concerning [xref]a[/xref]Herodias, his brother's wife, and concerning all the evil things which Herod did,
Added this also above all: he shut John up in [xref]a[/xref]prison.
Now when all the people were baptized and as Jesus was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]baptized and was praying, heaven was opened,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 21-22[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 3:16-17[/link] and [link]Mark 1:9-11[/link].

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Holy Spirit descended in bodily form as a dove upon Him. And a voice came out of heaven: You are My Son, the [xref]b[/xref]Beloved; in You I have found My delight.
verse.note: The Holy Spirit's conceiving of Jesus in [link]1:35[/link] was essential, related to the divine being, the divine person, of Jesus. The essence of the Holy Spirit's divine element in the conception of Jesus was unchangeable and irremovable. However, the Holy Spirit's descending upon Jesus here was economical, related to the ministry, the work, of Jesus. The power of the Holy Spirit for the ministry of Jesus ([link]4:14[/link], [link]18[/link]; [link]Matt. 12:28[/link]) could be removed from Him, depending on the need for it. It was in such an economical way that God forsook and left Jesus while He was carrying the sinners' sin in dying for them on the cross ([link]Matt. 27:46[/link]). The Holy Spirit in power descended upon Him here, but He had the Holy Spirit in essence from His birth; and while the Holy Spirit in power was descending upon Him, He was existing with the Holy Spirit in essence.

verse.text: And He, Jesus, when He [xref]a[/xref]began [i]to minister,[/i] was about [note]1[/note]thirty years old, being, [note]2[/note]so it was thought, the [note]3[/note]son of [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]Joseph, the [i]son[/i] of Heli,
verse.note: The full age for God's service ([link]Num. 4:3[/link], [link]35[/link], [link]39-40[/link], [link]43-44[/link], [link]47-48[/link]).
Lit., according to law.

See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link]. The record of John's Gospel, the Gospel of the God-Savior, begins from God and comes to man ([link]John 1:1[/link], [link]14[/link]), emphasizing Christ's divinity to attest to His divine-human status. The genealogy of Luke's Gospel, the Gospel of the Man-Savior, begins from man and traces back to God ([link]vv. 23[/link], [link]38[/link]), stressing Christ's humanity to affirm His human-divine status. He was born a man to bring God to man that He might accomplish redemption to bring man to God. In Him God and man are joined together.
See notes [link book="Matt." chapter="1"]16[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link].

verse.text: The [i]son[/i] of Matthat, the [i]son[/i] of Levi, the [i]son[/i] of Melchi, the [i]son[/i] of Jannai, the [i]son[/i] of Joseph,
The [i]son[/i] of Mattathias, the [i]son[/i] of Amos, the [i]son[/i] of Nahum, the [i]son[/i] of Esli, the [i]son[/i] of Naggai,
The [i]son[/i] of Maath, the [i]son[/i] of Mattathias, the [i]son[/i] of Semein, the [i]son[/i] of Josech, the [i]son[/i] of Joda,
The [i]son[/i] of Joanan, the [i]son[/i] of Rhesa, the [i]son[/i] of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Zerubbabel, the [i]son[/i] of Salathiel, the [i]son[/i] of Neri,
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link].

verse.text: The [i]son[/i] of Melchi, the [i]son[/i] of Addi, the [i]son[/i] of Cosam, the [i]son[/i] of Elmadam, the [i]son[/i] of Er,
The [i]son[/i] of Joshua, the [i]son[/i] of Eliezer, the [i]son[/i] of Jorim, the [i]son[/i] of Matthat, the [i]son[/i] of Levi,
The [i]son[/i] of Simeon, the [i]son[/i] of Judah, the [i]son[/i] of Joseph, the [i]son[/i] of Jonam, the [i]son[/i] of Eliakim,
The [i]son[/i] of Melea, the [i]son[/i] of Menna, the [i]son[/i] of Mattatha, the [i]son[/i] of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Nathan, the [i]son[/i] of [xref]b[/xref]David,
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]3[/sup][/link], pars. 2 and 3, in [link]Matt. 1[/link].

verse.text: The [i]son[/i] of [xref]a[/xref]Jesse, the [i]son[/i] of Obed, the [i]son[/i] of Boaz, the [i]son[/i] of Salmon, the [i]son[/i] of Nahshon,
The [i]son[/i] of Aminadab, the [i]son[/i] of Aram, the [i]son[/i] of Hezron, the [i]son[/i] of Pharez, the [i]son[/i] of Judah,
The [i]son[/i] of Jacob, the [i]son[/i] of Isaac, the [i]son[/i] of Abraham, the [i]son[/i] of [xref]a[/xref]Terah, the [i]son[/i] of Nahor,
The [i]son[/i] of Serug, the [i]son[/i] of Reu, the [i]son[/i] of Peleg, the [i]son[/i] of Eber, the [i]son[/i] of Sala,
The [i]son[/i] of Cainan, the [i]son[/i] of Arphaxad, the [i]son[/i] of Shem, the [i]son[/i] of [xref]a[/xref]Noah, the [i]son[/i] of Lamech,
The [i]son[/i] of Methuselah, the [i]son[/i] of Enoch, the [i]son[/i] of Jared, the [i]son[/i] of Maleleel, the [i]son[/i] of Cainan,
The [i]son[/i] of Enosh, the [i]son[/i] of Seth, the [i]son[/i] of [note]1[/note]Adam, the [note]2[/note][i]son[/i] of [note]3[/note]God.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 4, in Matt. 1[/link].

This does not mean that Adam was born of God and possessed the life of God, just as [i]son of Joseph[/i] does not mean that Jesus was born of Joseph; rather, He was thought to be the son of Joseph ([link]v. 23[/link]). Adam was created by God ([link]Gen. 5:1-2[/link]), and God was his origin. Based on this he was considered the son of God, even as the heathen poets considered all mankind to be the offspring of God ([link]Acts 17:28[/link]). Mankind was only created by God, not regenerated of Him. This is absolutely and intrinsically different from the believers in Christ being the sons of God. They have been born, regenerated, of God and possess God's life and nature ([link]John 1:12-13[/link]; [link]3:16[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:4[/link]).

From Jesus ([link]v. 23[/link]) back to God there are seventy-seven generations, in which are seen the history of God's creation, man's fall, God's promise, and man's salvation: of God, man was created ([link]v. 38[/link]; [link]Gen. 1:26-27[/link]; [link]2:7[/link]); in Adam, man became fallen ([link]v. 38[/link]; [link]Gen. 3[/link]); through Abraham, man received God's promise ([link]v. 34[/link]; [link]Gen. 12:1-3[/link]); and in Jesus, man is saved ([link]v. 23[/link]; [link]2:10-11[/link]).

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Jesus, full of the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Holy Spirit, returned from the [xref]b[/xref]Jordan and was led [note]3[/note]by the [xref]c[/xref]Spirit in the [xref]d[/xref]wilderness, while being tempted for forty days by the devil.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-13[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 4:1-11[/link].
See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].
Or, in.

verse.text: And He did not eat anything in those days, and when they were concluded, He became hungry.
And the devil said to Him, If You are the Son of God, speak to this stone that it become bread.
And Jesus answered him, It is written, [xref]a[/xref]"Man shall not live on bread alone[note]1[/note]."
verse.note: Some MSS add, but on every word of God.

verse.text: And he led Him up and showed Him all the kingdoms of the inhabited earth in a moment of time.
And the devil said to Him, To You I will give all this [xref]a[/xref]authority and their glory, because to me it [note]1[/note]has been delivered, and to whomever I want I give it.
verse.note: This must have occurred in the preadamic age. The devil's word here indicates that when God anointed the archangel to be the head of the preadamic age ([link]Ezek. 28:13-14[/link]), the authority and glory of the kingdom of the earth must have been given to him. The Lord's word in [link]John 12:31[/link] confirms this. After he rebelled against God and became God's enemy, Satan, he was judged by God ([link]Isa. 14:12-15[/link]), but the full execution of God's judgment upon him will not be completed until the end of the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:7-10[/link]). Hence, until that time he has authority over the kingdoms of the earth. He tempted the Lord Jesus by offering this authority and its glory to Him. His evil offer was rejected by God's Christ, but it will be accepted by the Antichrist, the man of lawlessness ([link]2 Thes. 2:3-4[/link]), at the end of this age ([link]Rev. 13:4[/link]) for the executing of Satan's evil strategy against God. Only by Christ, who lives in us, can we reject the evil tempter.

verse.text: If You therefore worship before me, it shall all be Yours.
And Jesus answered and said to him,[note]1[/note] It is written, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall worship the Lord your God, and Him only shall you [note]2[/note]serve."
verse.note: Some MSS add, Go away, behind Me, Satan.
Lit., serve as a priest.

verse.text: And he led Him into Jerusalem and set [i]Him[/i] on the [note]1[/note]wing of the temple and said to Him, If You are the Son of God, cast Yourself down from here;
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].

verse.text: For it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"To His angels He shall give charge concerning You to protect You,
And on [i]their[/i] hands they shall bear You up, lest You strike Your foot against a stone."
And Jesus answered and said to him, It is said, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall not [note]1[/note]test the Lord your God."
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].

verse.text: And when the devil had concluded every temptation, he went away from Him [note]1[/note]until an opportune time.
verse.note: Indicating that the devil would seek for another time and would come back to tempt Him again and again at any time he saw fit ([link]Matt. 16:22-23[/link]; [link]John 8:40[/link]; [link]Luke 22:53[/link]; [link]John 6:70-71[/link]).

verse.text: And Jesus returned in the power of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit into [xref]b[/xref]Galilee. And [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]reports about Him went out through all the surrounding region.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].
Or, the fame concerning Him went out.

verse.text: And He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]taught in their [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]synagogues and was [note]3[/note]glorified by all.
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 1[/link]. So in [link]v. 31[/link].
See notes [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link] and [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link].
I.e., praised, extolled.

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]came to [xref]b[/xref]Nazareth, where He had been brought up, and according to His [xref]c[/xref]custom He entered on the [xref]d[/xref]Sabbath day into the [xref]e[/xref]synagogue and stood up to [xref]f[/xref]read.
And the scroll of the prophet [xref]a[/xref]Isaiah was handed to Him. And He unrolled the scroll and found the place where it was written,

[xref]a[/xref]"The [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Spirit of the Lord is upon Me, because He has [xref]c[/xref]anointed Me to [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]announce the gospel to the [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]poor; He has sent Me to proclaim [xref]f[/xref]release to the [note]4[/note]captives, and [note]5[/note]recovery of sight to the [note]6[/note][xref]g[/xref]blind, to send away in release those who are [note]7[/note][xref]h[/xref]oppressed,
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].
See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup][/link]. To announce the gospel was the first commission of the Savior as God's anointed One, Messiah.
Poor in heavenly, spiritual, and divine things ([link]12:21[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:17[/link]; cf. [link]Matt. 5:3[/link]).
Prisoners of war, exiles and prisoners under Satan's bondage ([link]Isa. 42:7[/link]).
Recovery of sight is related to being released from the power of Satan ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]).
Those who are blind physically and spiritually ([link]Zeph. 1:17[/link]; [link]John 9:39-41[/link]; [link]1 John 2:11[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:17[/link]).
From a verb meaning [i]to break in pieces[/i] ([link]Matt. 12:20[/link]). Here it denotes being oppressed under Satan in sickness or in sin ([link]13:11-13[/link]; [link]John 8:34[/link]).

verse.text: To proclaim the [note]1[/note]acceptable year of the Lord, [i]the year of jubilee."[/i]
verse.note: The New Testament age, typified by the year of jubilee ([link]Lev. 25:8-17[/link]). The New Testament age would be the time when God would accept the returned captives of sin ([link]Isa. 49:8[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 6:2[/link]) and when those oppressed under the bondage of sin would enjoy the release of God's salvation and keep the New Testament jubilee.

verse.text: And when He rolled up the scroll and gave [i]it[/i] back to the attendant, He sat down. And the eyes of all in the synagogue were fixed on Him.
And He began to say to them, Today this Scripture has been [xref]a[/xref]fulfilled in your hearing.

And all bore witness to Him and [xref]a[/xref]marveled at the [note]1[/note]words of [xref]b[/xref]grace proceeding out of His mouth, and they said, Is not this [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Joseph's son?
verse.note: Referring to the words in [link]v. 21[/link], and including the words of the gospel in [link]vv. 18-19[/link].
They knew the Savior according to His flesh ([link]2 Cor. 5:16[/link]), not according to the Spirit ([link]Rom. 1:4[/link]).

verse.text: And He said to them, Surely you will say this proverb to Me, Physician, heal [xref]a[/xref]yourself! What we heard happening in [xref]b[/xref]Capernaum, do here also in Your [i]own[/i] country.
And He said, Truly I say to you that no prophet is acceptable in his [i]own[/i] country.
But in truth I say to you, There were many widows in Israel in the days of [xref]a[/xref]Elijah, when the sky was shut up for three years and six months, when a great famine came over all the land;
And to none of them was Elijah sent, except to [i]the city of[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sarepta of [xref]b[/xref]Sidon, to a [note]2[/note]woman [i]who was[/i] a widow.
verse.note: The Old Testament name is Zarephath ([link]1 Kings 17:9[/link]).

This was a case of feeding, signifying the Lord's feeding of the hungry ([link]John 6:33[/link], [link]35[/link]). The case of Naaman in the next verse is a case of cleansing, signifying the Lord's cleansing of sinners ([link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]). The Savior's mentioning of these two cases implied that His gospel would turn to the Gentiles ([link]Acts 13:45-48[/link]; see notes [link book="Matt." chapter="15"]21[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 15[/link]) — not because His standard of morality was unable to embrace the Jews but because of the Jews' hardhearted rejection of Him.

verse.text: And there were many [xref]a[/xref]lepers in Israel during the time of Elisha the prophet, and none of them were cleansed, except [xref]b[/xref]Naaman the Syrian.
And all in the synagogue were filled with [xref]a[/xref]anger when they heard these things,
And they rose up and [xref]a[/xref]cast Him out of the city and led Him to the brow of the hill on which their city was built so that they might throw Him down the cliff.
But He, [note]1[/note]passing through their midst, [xref]a[/xref]went away.
verse.note: Showing His steadiness under the threatening of His opposers.

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]came down to [xref]b[/xref]Capernaum, a city of Galilee. And He [xref]c[/xref]taught them on the [xref]d[/xref]Sabbath.
And they were [xref]a[/xref]astounded at His teaching, because His word was with [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]authority.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: And in the synagogue there was a man who had a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit of an unclean demon, and he cried out with a loud voice,
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Ah! [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]What do we have to do with You, Jesus, [xref]b[/xref]Nazarene? Have You come to destroy us? I [xref]c[/xref]know who You are — the [xref]d[/xref]Holy One of God.
verse.note: An interjection expressing anger or dismay. The Greek word may be translated [i]Let us alone.[/i]
Lit., What to us and to You. A Hebrew idiom.

verse.text: And Jesus rebuked him, saying, Be [xref]a[/xref]quiet and come out from him. And throwing him down in the midst, the demon came out from him without harming him at all.

And amazement came upon all, and they spoke to one another, saying, What is this word? For with [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]authority and [xref]b[/xref]power He orders the unclean spirits, and they come out.
verse.note: See note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reports went out concerning Him into every place of the surrounding region.
verse.note: Or, a sound.

verse.text: And He rose up [i]and went[/i] from the synagogue and [xref]a[/xref]entered into the house of Simon. And [note]1[/note]Simon's mother-in-law was [note]2[/note]suffering with a high [note]3[/note]fever, and they asked Him concerning her.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 38-41[/link]; [link]5:12-14[/link]; and [link]7:1-10[/link], the order in the narration of the incidents is according to morality; this differs from the order in [link]Matt. 8:2-16[/link] and [link]Mark 1:29-2:1[/link]. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Matt. 8[/link].
Lit., constrained.
See notes [link book="Mark" chapter="1"]30[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: And standing over her, He [xref]a[/xref]rebuked the fever, and it left her. And she instantly rose up and served them.
And when the sun was setting, all those who had any that were sick with various diseases brought them to Him; and He [xref]a[/xref]laid His hands on each one of them and healed them.

And demons also came out from many, [xref]a[/xref]crying out and saying, You are the [xref]b[/xref]Son of God! And He rebuked [i]them[/i] and would [xref]c[/xref]not allow them to speak, because they knew that He was the [xref]d[/xref]Christ.

And when [xref]a[/xref]day came, He departed and went into a [xref]b[/xref]deserted place. And the crowds [xref]c[/xref]sought Him, and they came up to Him and tried to hold on to Him so that He would not go away from them.
But He said to them, I must [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]announce the gospel of the [note]2[/note]kingdom of God to the other cities also, because for [note]3[/note]this I was sent.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]to announce good news, to declare (bring) glad tidings, to preach (the gospel).[/i] Hence, to announce the gospel of the kingdom of God is to preach the kingdom of God as the gospel, the good news.

The kingdom of God is the Savior (see note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link]) as the seed of life sown into His believers, God's chosen people ([link]Mark 4:3[/link], [link]26[/link]), and developing into a realm over which God can rule as His kingdom in His divine life. The entrance into the kingdom is regeneration ([link]John 3:5[/link]), and the development of the kingdom is the believers' growth in the divine life ([link]2 Pet. 1:3-11[/link]). The kingdom is the church life today, in which the faithful believers live ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]), and it will develop into the coming kingdom as a reward to be inherited ([link]Gal. 5:21[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:5[/link]) by the overcoming saints in the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]). Eventually, it will consummate in the New Jerusalem as the eternal kingdom of God, an eternal realm of the eternal blessing of God's eternal life, which all God's redeemed will enjoy in the new heaven and new earth for eternity — [link]Rev. 21:1-4[/link]; [link]22:1-5[/link], [link]14[/link] (see notes [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link], and [link chapter="4"]3[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]3[sup]2[/sup][/link], [link]26[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]26[sup]3[/sup] in Mark 4[/link]). Such a kingdom, the kingdom of God, is what the Savior announced here as the gospel, the good news, to those who were alienated from the life of God ([link]Eph. 4:18[/link]).
See note [link]38[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: And He [note]1[/note]preached in the [xref]a[/xref]synagogues of [note]2[/note]Judea.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

Some MSS read, Galilee; corresponding with [link]Mark 1:39[/link] and [link]Matt. 4:23[/link]. Galilee was a part of the country of the Jews, which was commonly called Judea (see notes [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link] and [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 23[/link]).

verse.text: And as the crowd pressed upon Him to hear the word of God, He was [xref]a[/xref]standing by the [note]1[/note]lake of [xref]b[/xref]Gennesaret.
verse.note: A common name for the Sea of Galilee ([link]Matt. 4:18[/link]; [link]Mark 1:16[/link]).

verse.text: And He [note]1[/note]saw two boats lying by the lake, and the fishermen had gotten out of them and were washing the nets.
verse.note: The events in [link]vv. 2-10a[/link] are not in the record in [link]Matt. 4:18-22[/link] or [link]Mark 1:16-20[/link].

verse.text: And He got into one of the [xref]a[/xref]boats, which was [note]1[/note]Simon's, and asked him to put out a little from the land. And He sat down and from the boat taught the crowds.
verse.note: Previously, Simon had been brought to the Lord by his brother Andrew ([link]John 1:40-42[/link]).

verse.text: And when He ceased speaking, He said to Simon, Put out into the deep and let down your [xref]a[/xref]nets for a catch.
And Simon answered and said, [note]1[/note]Master, through the whole night we toiled and caught [xref]a[/xref]nothing; but based on Your word I will let down the nets.
verse.note: One who exercises any kind of oversight.

verse.text: And when they did this, they enclosed a great number of [xref]a[/xref]fish, and their nets began to tear apart.
And they signaled to their companions in the other boat to come and assist them. And they came and filled both the boats, so that they began to sink.
And when Simon Peter saw [i]this,[/i] he fell down at Jesus' knees, saying, Depart from me, for I am a [xref]a[/xref]sinful man, Lord.
For amazement had taken possession of him and all who were with him, because of the catch of the fish which they took;

And likewise also James and John, the sons of Zebedee, who were [note]1[/note]partners with Simon. And Jesus said to Simon, Do not be afraid. From now on you will be [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]catching men alive.
verse.note: The word here denotes a close association, a common interest.

This was the Lord's calling of Peter by means of a miracle in fishing. (See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in John 21[/link].) The Greek word for [i]catch alive[/i] is a compound of [i]living[/i] and [i]to catch;[/i] hence, [i]to catch alive, to take captive alive[/i] (in war), instead of killing. The common fishers catch fish unto death. But Peter was called by the Lord to be a fisher of men ([link]Matt. 4:19[/link]) that he might catch men unto life ([link]Acts 2:38[/link]; [link]11:18[/link]).

verse.text: And when they had brought the boats to the land, they [xref]a[/xref]left all and [xref]b[/xref]followed Him.

And while He was in one of the cities, behold, there was a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]man full of leprosy. And when he saw Jesus, he [xref]b[/xref]fell on [i]his[/i] face and begged Him, saying, Lord, if You are willing, You can cleanse me.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 12-15[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 8:2-4[/link] and [link]Mark 1:40-45[/link].

verse.text: And stretching out His hand, He touched him, saying, I am willing; be cleansed! And immediately the leprosy left him.

And He charged him to tell [xref]a[/xref]no one: But go away, show yourself to the [xref]b[/xref]priest, and offer [i]the gift[/i] for your cleansing, even as [xref]c[/xref]Moses directed, for a [xref]d[/xref]testimony to them.
But the word concerning Him spread abroad all the more, and [xref]a[/xref]great crowds came together to hear [i]Him[/i] and to be [xref]b[/xref]healed from their infirmities.
But He Himself [i]often[/i] withdrew in the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]prayed.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: And on one of the days He was teaching, and there were Pharisees and [xref]a[/xref]teachers of the law sitting [i]there,[/i] who had come out of every [xref]b[/xref]village of Galilee and [xref]c[/xref]Judea and Jerusalem. And the [xref]d[/xref]power of the Lord [note]1[/note]was with Him to heal.
verse.note: Other MSS read, was there to heal them.

verse.text: And behold, some men [xref]a[/xref]brought on a bed a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]man who was paralyzed, and they sought [i]a way[/i] to carry him in and lay him before Him.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 18-26[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 9:2-8[/link] and [link]Mark 2:3-12[/link].

verse.text: And since they could not find by what [i]way[/i] they might carry him in because of the crowd, they went up onto the housetop and let him down with the cot through the tiles into the midst, in front of Jesus.
And seeing their [xref]a[/xref]faith, He said, Man, your sins are [xref]b[/xref]forgiven you.
And the scribes and the Pharisees began to reason, saying, Who is this who speaks [xref]a[/xref]blasphemies? Who can [xref]b[/xref]forgive sins except God alone?
But Jesus, [xref]a[/xref]knowing fully their reasonings, answered and said to them, Why are you reasoning in your hearts?
Which is easier: to say, Your sins are forgiven you, or to say, Rise and walk?
But that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on the earth to [xref]a[/xref]forgive sins — He said to the one paralyzed, To you I say, Rise and take up your cot and go to your house.
And he rose up at once before them and took up that upon which he was lying and went away to his house, [xref]a[/xref]glorifying God.
And astonishment took hold of all, and they glorified God and were filled with fear, saying, We have seen extraordinary things today.
And after these things He went out and beheld a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]tax collector named Levi [xref]b[/xref]sitting at the tax office, and He said to him, Follow Me.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 27-32[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 9:9-13[/link] and [link]Mark 2:13-17[/link].

verse.text: And leaving all, he rose up and [xref]a[/xref]followed Him.
And Levi gave a great reception for Him in his [note]1[/note]house; and there was a great crowd of [xref]a[/xref]tax collectors and others who were reclining [i]at table[/i] with them.
verse.note: A saved one should open his house for the Lord's enjoyment.

verse.text: And the Pharisees and their [xref]a[/xref]scribes murmured at His disciples, saying, Why do you [xref]b[/xref]eat and drink with the tax collectors and sinners?
And Jesus answered and said to them, Those who are healthy have no need of a physician, but those who are ill;
I have not come to call the [xref]a[/xref]righteous, but [xref]b[/xref]sinners to [xref]c[/xref]repentance.
And they [xref]a[/xref]said to Him, The [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]disciples of John [xref]c[/xref]fast often and make petitions, likewise also those of the Pharisees, but Yours eat and drink.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 33-39[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 9:14-17[/link].

verse.text: And Jesus said to them, You cannot make the sons of the bridechamber fast while the [xref]a[/xref]bridegroom is with them, can you?
But the [xref]a[/xref]days will come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them; then they will fast in those days.

And He also spoke a parable to them: No one tears a patch from a new garment and puts [i]it[/i] on an old garment; otherwise, [note]1[/note]he will tear the new [i]garment,[/i] and also the patch from the new will not match the old.
verse.note: Or, the new will tear, and the patch from the new...

verse.text: And no one puts new wine into old wineskins; otherwise, the new wine will burst the wineskins, and it will be poured out and the wineskins will be ruined;
But new wine must be put into fresh wineskins.
And no one who has drunk the old desires the new, for he says, The old is better.

[note]1[/note]And [note]2[/note]one [xref]a[/xref]Sabbath He was going through the grainfields, and His disciples were picking and eating the [xref]b[/xref]ears of grain, rubbing [i]them[/i] in their hands.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-5[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 12:1-8[/link] and [link]Mark 2:23-28[/link].
Many MSS read, the second first Sabbath; i.e., the second Sabbath after the first.

verse.text: And some of the [xref]a[/xref]Pharisees said, Why are you doing what is [xref]b[/xref]not lawful to do on the Sabbath?
And Jesus answered them and said, Have you not even read this that [xref]a[/xref]David did when he became hungry, he and those who were with him;

How he entered into the house of God, and taking the [xref]a[/xref]bread of the Presence, he ate [i]it[/i] and gave [i]some[/i] to those with him, which is not lawful [i]for anyone[/i] to eat except the priests alone?
And He said to them, The [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath.
And [note]1[/note]on another Sabbath He entered into the [xref]a[/xref]synagogue and [note]2[/note]taught. And there was a [xref]b[/xref]man there, and his right hand was withered.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 6-11[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 12:9-14[/link] and [link]Mark 3:1-6[/link].
See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: And the scribes and the Pharisees were [xref]a[/xref]watching Him closely [i]to see[/i] if He would heal on the Sabbath, so that they might find [i]reason[/i] to [xref]b[/xref]accuse Him.
But He [xref]a[/xref]knew their reasonings and said to the man who had the withered hand, Rise and stand in the midst. And he rose up and stood.
And Jesus said to them, I ask you, Is it [xref]a[/xref]lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do evil, to save a [note]1[/note]life or to destroy [i]it?[/i]
verse.note: Lit., soul; referring to the soul-life.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]looking around at all of them, He said to him, Stretch out your hand. And he did, and his hand was restored.
But they were filled with [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rage and [xref]b[/xref]discussed with one another what they might do to Jesus.
verse.note: Or, folly; implying senseless rage. As a sign that tests people, the Man-Savior caused people to be exposed ([link]2:34-35[/link]); some were humble and received grace, and others were haughty and became enraged.

verse.text: And in these days He went out to the mountain to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]pray, and He spent the whole night in [note]2[/note]prayer to God.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].
Lit., the prayer of God.

verse.text: And when it became day, He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]called His [xref]b[/xref]disciples to [i]Him,[/i] and He chose from them twelve, whom He also named [xref]c[/xref]apostles:
verse.note: For [link]vv. 13-16[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 10:1-4[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Simon, whom He also named [xref]b[/xref]Peter, and [xref]c[/xref]Andrew his brother and [xref]d[/xref]James and John and [xref]e[/xref]Philip and Bartholomew
