And [xref]a[/xref]Matthew and Thomas and James [i]the son[/i] of Alphaeus and Simon, who was called Zealot,
And [xref]a[/xref]Judas [i]the[/i] [note]1[/note][i]brother[/i] of James, and Judas Iscariot, who became the traitor.
verse.note: Or, son.

verse.text: And He came down with them and stood on a level place; and there was a [xref]a[/xref]great crowd of His disciples, and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem and the seacoast of [xref]b[/xref]Tyre and Sidon, who had come to hear Him and to be healed of their diseases.
And those who were troubled by unclean [xref]a[/xref]spirits were healed.
And all the crowd sought to [xref]a[/xref]touch Him, because [xref]b[/xref]power was going out from Him and healing all.

And He [xref]a[/xref]lifted up His eyes to His disciples and [xref]b[/xref]said, [note]1[/note]Blessed are the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]poor, for yours is the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]kingdom of God.
verse.note: Whatever was decreed in [link]Matt. 5-7[/link], as the constitution of the kingdom of the heavens, constitutes the reality of the kingdom of the heavens. Whatever is cited here in [link]vv. 20-49[/link], as principles of the character of God's children, governs and measures the behavior of the believers, who have been born of God and possess His life and nature. At the time it was spoken, this entire portion (except [link]vv. 24-26[/link], [link]39[/link]) applied to the believing remnant of the Jews. In terms of the standard of character, the principles contained in this portion far surpassed the law that the Jews received from Moses.
For [link]vv. 20-23[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 5:3-12[/link].
See note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: Blessed are those who [xref]a[/xref]hunger now, for you shall be satisfied. Blessed are those who [xref]b[/xref]weep now, for you shall laugh.

Blessed are you when men [xref]a[/xref]hate you and when they separate you from [i]them[/i] and [xref]b[/xref]reproach [i]you[/i] and [xref]c[/xref]cast out your name as evil, for the Son of Man's sake.
[xref]a[/xref]Rejoice in that day and leap for joy, for behold, your reward is great in heaven; for so their fathers did to the [xref]b[/xref]prophets.
[note]1[/note]But [xref]a[/xref]woe to you who are [xref]b[/xref]rich, for you have [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]received your consolation in full.
verse.note: At the time they were spoken, [link]vv. 24-26[/link] could have applied to the unbelieving Jews, who hardened their hearts and rejected the Savior.
In Greek this word was used in a commercial sense to acknowledge receipt of full payment.

verse.text: Woe to you who are satiated now, for you shall [xref]a[/xref]hunger. Woe [i]to you[/i] who are [xref]b[/xref]laughing now, for you shall mourn and weep.
Woe [i]to you[/i] when all men speak well of you, for so their fathers did to the false [xref]a[/xref]prophets.
But to you who hear I say, [note]1[/note]Love your [xref]a[/xref]enemies; do well to those who hate you;
verse.note: For [link]vv. 27-36[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 5:38-48[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Bless those who curse you; [xref]b[/xref]pray for those who revile you.
To him who [xref]a[/xref]beats you on the cheek, offer the other also; and from him who takes away your cloak, do not withhold your tunic either.
To everyone who asks of you, [xref]a[/xref]give; and from him who takes away your things, do not require their return.
And just as you want men to [xref]a[/xref]do to you, do to them likewise.
And if you [xref]a[/xref]love those who love you, what [note]1[/note]thanks is it to you? For even sinners love those who love them.
verse.note: Lit., favor. So in the succeeding verses. [i]Thanks[/i] corresponds with a reward, and [i]what[/i] refers to the quality of the reward; hence, [i]what thanks[/i] means [i]what kind of reward.[/i]

verse.text: For if you also do good to those who do good to you, what thanks is it to you? Even sinners do the same.
And if you [xref]a[/xref]lend [i]to those[/i] from whom you hope to receive, what thanks is it to you? Even sinners lend to sinners that they may get back the equal [i]amount.[/i]

But love your [xref]a[/xref]enemies, and do good and [xref]b[/xref]lend, [note]1[/note]expecting nothing in return, and your reward will be great, and you will be [xref]c[/xref]sons of the [xref]d[/xref]Most High; for He is kind to the unthankful and evil.
verse.note: Or, considering nothing as loss.

verse.text: Be full of compassion, even [xref]a[/xref]as your Father also is full of [xref]b[/xref]compassion.

And [note]1[/note]do [xref]a[/xref]not judge, and you shall by no means be judged; and do [xref]b[/xref]not condemn, and you shall by no means be condemned; [xref]c[/xref]release, and you will be released;
verse.note: For [link]vv. 37-38[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 7:1-2[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Give, and it will be given to you; a good measure, pressed down, shaken together, [i]and[/i] running over, they will give into your [note]1[/note]bosom. For with what [xref]b[/xref]measure you measure, it shall be measured to you in return.
verse.note: "The gathered fold of the wide upper garment, bound together with the girdle, and thus forming a pouch" (Vincent).

verse.text: And He also spoke a parable to them: [note]1[/note]A [note]2[/note]blind man cannot [xref]a[/xref]guide a blind man, can he? Will not both fall into a pit?
verse.note: At the time it was spoken, this word could have applied to the leaders among the Jews.
See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 15[/link].

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]disciple is not above the teacher, but everyone who has been perfected will be like his teacher.
And why do you [note]1[/note]look at the [xref]a[/xref]splinter which is in your brother's eye, but the beam which is in your [xref]b[/xref]own eye you do not consider?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 41-42[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 7:3-5[/link].

verse.text: How can you say to your brother, Brother, let me remove the splinter which is in your eye, you yourself not seeing the beam which is in your eye? [note]1[/note]Hypocrite, first remove the beam from your eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the splinter which is in your brother's eye.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].

verse.text: For there is [xref]a[/xref]no good tree that produces corrupt fruit, nor again a corrupt tree that produces good fruit.
For each tree is [xref]a[/xref]known by its own fruit. For [i]men[/i] do not collect figs from thorns, nor do they pick grapes from a thornbush.

The good man, out of the [xref]a[/xref]good treasure of his heart, brings forth that which is good, and the evil man, out of the evil treasure of his heart, brings forth that which is evil; for [xref]b[/xref]out of the abundance of [i]his[/i] heart his mouth speaks.
And why do you call Me, [xref]a[/xref]Lord, Lord, and do not do the things that I say?
[note]1[/note]Everyone who comes to Me and [xref]a[/xref]hears My words and does them, I will show you whom he is like.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 47-49[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 7:24-27[/link].

verse.text: He is like a man building a house, who dug and went deep and laid a foundation on the rock. And when a flood came, the river broke out against that house, yet it was not strong enough to shake it, because it had been built well.

But he who hears and does not do is like a man who built a house upon the earth without a foundation, against which the river broke out, and immediately it [xref]a[/xref]collapsed, and the crash of that house was great.
After He completed all His words in the [note]1[/note]hearing of the people, He [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]entered into [xref]b[/xref]Capernaum.
verse.note: Lit., ears.
For [link]vv. 1-10[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 8:5-13[/link].

verse.text: And a certain [xref]a[/xref]centurion's slave, who was highly valued by him, was ill and about to die.
And when he heard about Jesus, he sent to Him some elders of the Jews, requesting that He would come and [note]1[/note]completely heal his slave.
verse.note: Lit., save his slave thoroughly.

verse.text: And when they came to Jesus, they entreated Him earnestly, saying, He is worthy of Your granting this [i]to him,[/i]
For he loves our nation, and he himself built the [xref]a[/xref]synagogue for us.

And Jesus went with them. But already, when He was not far from the house, the centurion sent friends, saying to Him, Lord, do [xref]a[/xref]not trouble Yourself, for I am not fit for You to enter under my roof;
Therefore, I did not count even myself worthy to come to You. But speak a [xref]a[/xref]word, and let my servant be healed.
For I also am a man set under authority, having soldiers under me. And I say to this one, Go, and he goes; and to another, Come, and he comes; and to my slave, Do this, and he does [i]it.[/i]
And when Jesus heard these things, He marveled at him, and turning to the crowd following Him, He said, I say to you, Not even in Israel have I found such great [xref]a[/xref]faith.
And when those who had been sent returned to the house, they found the slave in good health.
And [note]1[/note]soon afterward He went into a city called Nain, and His disciples went with Him, as well as a large crowd.
verse.note: Or, on the next day.

verse.text: And as He came near the gate of the city, behold, one who had died was being carried out, an [xref]a[/xref]only son of his mother, and she was a widow; and a considerable crowd from the city was with her.
And when the Lord saw her, He was [note]1[/note]moved with [xref]a[/xref]compassion for her and said to her, Do [xref]b[/xref]not weep.
verse.note: This case is unique in the misery it portrays — a widow's only son was being carried in a coffin. The Savior's compassion also was unique in His loving sympathy — in His tender mercy He offered His power of resurrection to raise the widow's son from death, without being asked to do so. This indicates His unique commission, which was to come to save lost sinners ([link]19:10[/link]), and shows the high standard of His morality, as a Man-Savior, in saving sinners.

verse.text: And He came near and touched the bier, and those carrying [i]it[/i] stood still. And He said, Young man, to you I say, [xref]a[/xref]Arise.
And the [xref]a[/xref]dead man sat up and began to speak. And He [xref]b[/xref]gave him to his mother.
And [xref]a[/xref]fear took hold of all, and they [xref]b[/xref]glorified God, saying, A great [xref]c[/xref]prophet has been raised up among us, and, God has [xref]d[/xref]visited His people!
And this report concerning Him went out in the whole of [note]1[/note]Judea and in all the surrounding region.
verse.note: A common name of the country of the Jews, including Galilee, where the city of Nain was (see note [link]44[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]).

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]John's [xref]a[/xref]disciples [xref]b[/xref]reported to him concerning all these things.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 18-35[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 11:2-19[/link].

verse.text: And John called a certain two of his disciples to [i]him[/i] and sent [i]them[/i] to [note]1[/note]the Lord, saying, Are You the [xref]a[/xref]Coming One, or should we expect another?
verse.note: Some MSS read, Jesus.

verse.text: And the men came to Him and said, John the Baptist sent us to You, saying, Are You the Coming One, or should we expect another?
In that hour He [xref]a[/xref]healed many from diseases and afflictions and evil spirits, and to many who were [xref]b[/xref]blind He graciously gave sight.

And He answered and said to them, Go and report to John what you have seen and heard: the [xref]a[/xref]blind receive their sight, the [xref]b[/xref]lame walk, the [xref]c[/xref]lepers are cleansed and the [xref]d[/xref]deaf hear, the [xref]e[/xref]dead are raised, the [xref]f[/xref]poor have the gospel [note]1[/note]announced to them.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]blessed is he who is not [xref]a[/xref]stumbled because of Me.
verse.note: When it looks as if the Lord will not act on our behalf, we are blessed if we are not stumbled.

verse.text: And when the messengers of John went away, He began to say to the crowds concerning John, What did you go out into the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness to look at? A reed shaken by the wind?
But what did you go out to see? A man arrayed in soft garments? Behold, those who live in splendid apparel and luxury are in royal palaces.
But what did you go out to see? A [xref]a[/xref]prophet? Yes, I say to you, and much more than a prophet.
This is he concerning whom it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"Behold, I send My messenger before Your face, who will prepare Your way before You."
I say to you, Among those born of women there is no one greater than John, yet he who is least in the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God is greater than he.

And when all the people and the tax collectors heard [i]this,[/i] they [xref]a[/xref]acknowledged that God was righteous, since they had been [xref]b[/xref]baptized with the [xref]c[/xref]baptism of John.
But the [xref]a[/xref]Pharisees and the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]lawyers [note]2[/note]rejected the [xref]c[/xref]counsel of God for themselves since they had not been baptized by him.
verse.note: Not practitioners of law but scholars in the Mosaic law.
Or, set aside, nullified.

verse.text: [i]And Jesus said,[/i] To what then shall I liken the men of this generation, and what are they like?

They are like little children sitting in the [xref]a[/xref]marketplace and calling to one another, who say, We have played the flute to you, and you did not dance; we have sung a dirge, and you did not weep.
For John the Baptist has come neither [xref]a[/xref]eating bread [xref]b[/xref]nor drinking wine, and you say, He has a demon.
The Son of Man has come [xref]a[/xref]eating and drinking, and you say, Behold, a gluttonous man and a drunkard, a [xref]b[/xref]friend of tax collectors and sinners.
Yet wisdom is justified by all her children.
Now a certain one of the Pharisees asked Him to [xref]a[/xref]eat with him. And He entered into the Pharisee's house and reclined [i]at table.[/i]

And behold, there was a woman in the city who was a sinner, and when she learned that He was reclining [i]at table[/i] in the Pharisee's house, she [note]1[/note]brought an alabaster flask of [xref]a[/xref]ointment.
verse.note: Or, provided.

verse.text: And she stood behind [i]Him[/i] at His feet weeping and began to wet His feet with her tears and wiped [i]them[/i] with the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]hair of her head, and she kissed His feet [note]2[/note]affectionately and anointed [i]them[/i] with the [note]3[/note]ointment.
verse.note: The hair is the glory of the woman ([link]1 Cor. 11:15[/link]) and is at the top of her body. With her top part she wiped the Savior's feet, the lowest part of His body, loving Him with her glory.
In love.
Indicating the woman's appreciation of the Savior's great worth and sweetness. Even the Savior's feet were precious and sweet to her affection.

verse.text: But when the [xref]a[/xref]Pharisee who had invited Him saw [i]this,[/i] he said within himself, This man, [note]1[/note]if He were a [xref]b[/xref]prophet, would know [xref]c[/xref]who and what sort of woman [i]this is[/i] who is touching Him, because she is a sinner.
verse.note: A large crowd in Nain, having witnessed the Savior's power of resurrection, recognized the Savior as a great prophet ([link]v. 16[/link]). Yet the Pharisee wondered if He was a prophet. He not only doubted the Savior but also despised the woman as a sinner.

verse.text: And Jesus [note]1[/note]answered and said to him, Simon, I have something to say to you. And he said, Teacher, say [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: Showing the Savior's omniscience.

verse.text: A certain moneylender had [note]1[/note]two [xref]a[/xref]debtors: one owed five hundred [note]2[/note]denarii and the other fifty.
verse.note: Simon considered only the woman, not himself, a sinner and doubted that the Savior knew that she was a sinner. But the Savior's parable indicated that both Simon and the woman were sinners — debtors to Him — and that both needed His forgiveness.
See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in John 6[/link].

verse.text: But since they had [note]1[/note]nothing [i]with which[/i] to repay, he graciously [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]forgave them both. Which of them [note]3[/note]therefore will love him more?
verse.note: Indicating that sinners have nothing with which to repay their debt to God their Savior.
Indicating that the Savior had already forgiven both of them.
Indicating that their love for the Savior was the issue, not the cause, of the Savior's forgiveness.

verse.text: Simon answered and said, I suppose the one whom he graciously forgave the more. And He said to him, You have judged correctly.

And turning to the woman, He said to Simon, Do you see this woman? I entered into your house; you did not [note]1[/note]give Me water for My [xref]a[/xref]feet, but she, with her tears, has wet My feet and with her hair has wiped [i]them.[/i]
verse.note: The Savior's word in [link]vv. 44-46[/link] indicates that Simon should have taken the woman as an example and learned of her.

verse.text: You did not give Me a [xref]a[/xref]kiss, but she, from the time I entered, has not stopped kissing My feet affectionately.
You did not anoint My head with [xref]a[/xref]oil, but she has anointed My feet with ointment.
For this reason I say to you, Her sins which are [xref]a[/xref]many are forgiven, because she [note]1[/note]loved much; but to whom little is forgiven, he [note]1[/note]loves little.
verse.note: Her loving much was a proof that her many sins had been forgiven; Simon's loving little testified that he had been forgiven only a little.

verse.text: And He said to her, [note]1[/note]Your sins are [xref]a[/xref]forgiven.
verse.note: This case and the case in Nain of the widow's only son ([link]vv. 11-17[/link]) are found only in this Gospel. These cases display the Savior's tender care for the dead and sinful and convey the principle of morality as the unique characteristic of this Gospel.

verse.text: And those who were reclining [i]at table[/i] with [i]Him[/i] began to say within themselves, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Who is this who even forgives sins?
verse.note: Those who were reclining at the table with Him did not realize that this Man-Savior was the very God, who had authority to forgive man's sins. See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 2[/link].

verse.text: But He said to the woman, Your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith has saved you. Go [note]2[/note]in [xref]b[/xref]peace.
verse.note: The forgiven woman had not only love toward the Savior but also faith in Him, which operated through love ([link]Gal. 5:6[/link]) and issued in peace. The faith that saved her brought her to the Savior in love and resulted in her going forward in peace. Faith, love, and peace are three crucial virtues in experiencing and enjoying the Savior's salvation. Faith is brought forth by knowing the Savior in His saving power and virtue. Love comes out of this faith and brings in peace; then we follow the Savior. In following the Savior in our living, faith and love bring us peace that we may enjoy the Lord's life and grow in it.
Lit., into.

verse.text: And soon afterward He journeyed from city to city and [xref]a[/xref]village to village, [note]1[/note]preaching and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]announcing the gospel of the kingdom of God; and the twelve were with Him,
verse.note: Proclaiming as a herald.
See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: As well as certain [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]women who were healed of evil spirits and infirmities: Mary, who was called Magdalene, from whom [xref]b[/xref]seven demons had gone out,
verse.note: The twelve called ones were following the Savior ([link]v. 1[/link]), and the healed women were ministering to the Savior and His followers out of their own possessions ([link]v. 3[/link]). A beautiful picture!

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Joanna, the wife of Chuza, Herod's steward, and Susanna, and many other women, who ministered to [note]1[/note]them out of their possessions.
verse.note: Some MSS read, Him.

verse.text: And while a great crowd was coming together and those from city to city were journeying to Him, He spoke by way of a [xref]a[/xref]parable:
The [note]1[/note]sower went out to sow his seed. And as he sowed, some [i]seed[/i] fell beside the way, and it was trampled underfoot, and the birds of heaven devoured it.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 5-15[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 13:3-23[/link] and [link]Mark 4:2-20[/link].

verse.text: And other [i]seed[/i] fell on the rock, and as it grew, it withered because it had no moisture.
And other [i]seed[/i] fell in the midst of the [xref]a[/xref]thorns, and the thorns grew with [i]it[/i] and choked it off.

And other [i]seed[/i] fell into the good earth, and when it grew, it produced fruit a [xref]a[/xref]hundredfold. When He had said these things, He called out, He who has ears to hear, let him [xref]b[/xref]hear.
And His disciples questioned Him as to what this parable might be.

And He said, To you it has been given to know the [xref]a[/xref]mysteries of the [note]1[/note]kingdom of God, but to the rest [i]they are[/i] in parables, in order that [xref]b[/xref]seeing they may not see, and hearing they may not understand.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: Now the [xref]a[/xref]parable is this: The seed is the [xref]b[/xref]word of God.
And those beside the way are those who heard; then the devil comes and takes away the word from their heart, so that they would not believe and be [xref]a[/xref]saved.

And those on the rock are those who, when they hear, receive the word with [xref]a[/xref]joy; yet these have no root, who believe [i]only[/i] for a while, and in time of [xref]b[/xref]trial they draw back.

And that which fell into the thorns, these are those who heard and, going away, are utterly choked by [xref]a[/xref]anxieties and [xref]b[/xref]riches and [xref]c[/xref]pleasures of this [note]1[/note]life, and do not bring [i]any fruit[/i] to maturity.
verse.note: Gk. [i]bios,[/i] meaning [i]life[/i] and referring to one's material living.

verse.text: But that which is in the good earth, these are those who in a [xref]a[/xref]noble and good heart hear the word and hold [i]it[/i] fast and [xref]b[/xref]bear fruit with [xref]c[/xref]endurance.

Now [xref]a[/xref]no one who has lit a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]lamp covers it with a vessel or puts [i]it[/i] underneath a bed, but he puts [i]it[/i] on a lampstand in order that those who come in may see the light.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 16-18[/link], see notes in [link]Mark 4:21-25[/link].

verse.text: For nothing is [xref]a[/xref]hidden which shall not become manifest, nor concealed which shall not by all means be made known and come into the open.

[xref]a[/xref]Take heed therefore how you [xref]b[/xref]hear, for whoever [xref]c[/xref]has, it shall be given to him, and whoever does not have, even what he thinks he has shall be taken away from him.
And His [note]1[/note]mother and [xref]a[/xref]brothers [xref]b[/xref]came up to Him and were not able to get to Him because of the crowd.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 19-21[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 12:46-50[/link] and [link]Mark 3:31-35[/link].

verse.text: And it was reported to Him, Your mother and Your brothers are standing outside wanting to see You.
But He answered and said to them, My mother and My brothers are these who [xref]a[/xref]hear the word of God and do [i]it.[/i]

And on one of the days He and His disciples [note]1[/note]got into a [xref]a[/xref]boat. And He said to them, Let us go over to the [xref]b[/xref]other side of the [xref]c[/xref]lake. And they launched out.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 22-25[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 8:23-27[/link] and [link]Mark 4:36-41[/link].

verse.text: And while they were sailing, He fell asleep. And a windstorm came down upon the lake, and they began to fill with [i]water[/i] and were in danger.

And they came to [i]Him[/i] and woke Him, saying, [note]1[/note]Master, Master, we are perishing! And being awakened, He [xref]a[/xref]rebuked the wind and the surging of the water, and they [xref]b[/xref]ceased, and there was a [xref]c[/xref]calm.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: And He said to them, Where is your faith? And they [xref]a[/xref]became frightened and marveled, saying to one another, Who then is this, that He orders even the winds and the water, and they obey Him?
And they [note]1[/note]sailed down to the region of the [xref]a[/xref]Gerasenes, which is across from Galilee.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 26-39[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 8:28-34[/link] and [link]Mark 5:1-20[/link].

verse.text: And when He went out onto the land, a certain man out of the city, who had demons, met [i]Him,[/i] and for a considerable time he had not put on clothes and did not remain in a house but among the tombs.

And when he saw Jesus, he [xref]a[/xref]cried out and fell before Him and said in a loud voice, What do I have to do with You, Jesus, Son of the [xref]b[/xref]Most High God? I beseech You, do not torment me.

For He had charged the [xref]a[/xref]unclean spirit to come out from the man; for many times it had seized him and he had been bound with chains and shackles and was kept under watch, yet [i]every time[/i] he tore the bonds apart and was driven by the demon into the wilderness.
And Jesus questioned him, What is your name? And he said, Legion, because many demons had entered into him.
And they entreated Him not to order them to depart into the [xref]a[/xref]abyss.
Now there was a herd of many [xref]a[/xref]hogs feeding there on the mountain. And they entreated Him to permit them to enter into them, and He gave them permission.
And the demons came out from the man and entered into the hogs, and the herd rushed down the steep slope into the [xref]a[/xref]lake and was drowned.
And when those who were feeding [i]them[/i] saw what had happened, they fled and reported [i]it[/i] in the city and in the countryside.

And [i]the people[/i] went out to see what had happened. And they came to Jesus and found the man from whom the demons had come out, [xref]a[/xref]sitting at the feet of Jesus, clothed and sane, and they became frightened.
And those who had seen [i]it[/i] reported to them how the demon-possessed man had been [note]1[/note]healed.
verse.note: Lit., saved.

verse.text: And all the multitude from the surrounding region of the Gerasenes asked Him to [xref]a[/xref]depart from them, for they were seized with great [xref]b[/xref]fear; and He got into a boat and returned.
And the man from whom the demons had come out begged to be with Him, but He sent him away, saying,
Return to your house, and relate what great things God has done for you. And he departed, proclaiming throughout the whole city what great things Jesus had done for him.
Now as Jesus was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]returning, the crowd welcomed Him, for they were all waiting for Him.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link].

verse.text: And behold, a [note]1[/note]man came whose name was Jairus, and this man was a [xref]a[/xref]ruler of the synagogue. And he fell at Jesus' feet and entreated Him to enter into his house,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 41-56[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 9:18-26[/link] and [link]Mark 5:22-43[/link].

verse.text: Because he had an [xref]a[/xref]only daughter, about twelve years old, and she was dying. And as He went, the crowds [note]1[/note]pressed against Him.
verse.note: Or, were stifling Him.

verse.text: And a woman who had a [xref]a[/xref]flow of blood for twelve years [i]and[/i] who [note]1[/note]had spent all her livelihood on physicians and yet could not be healed by anyone,
verse.note: Some MSS omit, had spent all her livelihood on physicians and yet.

verse.text: Approached [i]Him[/i] from behind and touched the [xref]a[/xref]fringe of His garment, and instantly her flow of blood stopped.
And Jesus said, Who is the one who touched Me? And when all denied [i]it,[/i] Peter[note]1[/note] said, Master, the crowds are pressing and crushing You.
verse.note: Some MSS add, and those with him.

verse.text: But Jesus said, Someone touched Me, for I perceived that [xref]a[/xref]power had gone out from Me.

And when the woman saw that she had not escaped notice, she came trembling and fell down before Him and declared before all the people the reason why she had touched Him and how she had been instantly healed.
And He said to her, Daughter, your [xref]a[/xref]faith has [note]1[/note]healed you. Go [note]2[/note]in peace.
verse.note: Lit., saved. So also in [link]v. 50[/link].
Lit., into. Before a person is saved, he does not know the way of peace ([link]Rom. 3:17[/link]). The Lord's salvation brings man to the way of peace ([link]1:79[/link]).

verse.text: While He was still speaking, someone came from [i]the house of[/i] the ruler of the synagogue, saying, Your daughter has died; do [xref]a[/xref]not trouble the [xref]b[/xref]Teacher any longer.
But Jesus, hearing it, answered him, Do not be afraid — only believe, and she will be healed.
And He came to the house and did not allow anyone to enter with Him, except [xref]a[/xref]Peter and [note]1[/note]John and James and the father of the child and the mother.
verse.note: Some MSS read, James and John.

verse.text: And all were weeping and mourning for her; but He said, Do [xref]a[/xref]not weep, for she has not died but is [xref]b[/xref]sleeping.
And they laughed scornfully at Him, knowing that she had died.
But He [xref]a[/xref]took hold of her hand and called out, saying, Child, [xref]b[/xref]arise!
And her [xref]a[/xref]spirit returned and she rose up instantly; and He directed that [i]something[/i] be given to her to eat.
And her parents were amazed, but He charged them to tell [xref]a[/xref]no one what had happened.
And He [xref]a[/xref]called together the twelve[note]1[/note] and gave them power and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]authority over all the demons and to heal diseases.
verse.note: Some MSS add, apostles.
See notes [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link] and [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]sent them to proclaim the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God and to [xref]c[/xref]heal the sick.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]. So throughout the chapter.

verse.text: And He said to them, [xref]a[/xref]Take nothing for the journey, neither a staff nor a bag [note]1[/note]nor bread nor money, nor have two tunics apiece.
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: And into whatever house you enter, remain there and from there go out.
And as many as do not receive you, as you go out from that city, [xref]a[/xref]shake off the dust from your feet for a [xref]b[/xref]testimony against them.
And they went out and passed through village after village, announcing the gospel and healing everywhere.
And [xref]a[/xref]Herod the tetrarch [xref]b[/xref]heard of all that was happening and was utterly perplexed, because it was said by some that John had been raised from the dead,
And by some that [xref]a[/xref]Elijah had appeared, and by others that a certain prophet of the ancients had risen up.
And Herod said, John I [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]beheaded, but who is this concerning whom I hear such things? And he [xref]b[/xref]sought to see Him.
verse.note: See note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 6[/link].

verse.text: And when the apostles returned, they [xref]a[/xref]related to Him the things they had done. And [xref]b[/xref]taking them aside, He withdrew privately into a city called Bethsaida.
But the [xref]a[/xref]crowds found out and followed Him, and He welcomed them and spoke to them concerning the [xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God; and those who had need of healing He [xref]c[/xref]healed.

And the [note]1[/note]day began to decline, and the twelve came and said to Him, [xref]a[/xref]Send the crowd away so that they may go into the surrounding villages and [note]2[/note]countryside to lodge and find provisions, because we are here in a deserted place.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 12-17[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 14:15-21[/link].
Or, farms.

verse.text: But He said to them, You [xref]a[/xref]give them [i]something[/i] to eat. But they said, We have no more than [xref]b[/xref]five loaves and two fish, unless we go and buy food for all these people.
For there were about five thousand men. And He said to His disciples, Make them recline in [note]1[/note]groups of about fifty each.
verse.note: In the same way that people gather for a meal in a home, sitting in groups, table by table.

verse.text: And they did so and made [i]them[/i] all recline.
And He took the five loaves and the two fish, and [xref]a[/xref]looking up to heaven, He [xref]b[/xref]blessed and broke them and gave [i]them[/i] to the disciples to set before the crowd.
And they ate and were all satisfied. And what was left over among them was taken up, [note]1[/note]twelve handbaskets of broken pieces.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 6[/link].

verse.text: And as He was praying alone, the disciples were with Him, and He [note]1[/note]questioned them, saying, [xref]a[/xref]Who do the crowds say that I am?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 18-27[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 16:13-28[/link].

verse.text: And they answered and said, [xref]a[/xref]John the Baptist, and others [xref]b[/xref]Elijah, and others that a certain prophet of the ancients has risen up.
And He said to them, But you, who do you say that I am? And Peter answered and said, The [xref]a[/xref]Christ of God.
But He charged them and commanded [i]them[/i] to tell this to [xref]a[/xref]no one,

[xref]a[/xref]Saying, The [xref]b[/xref]Son of Man must suffer many things, and be [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]rejected of the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and on the [xref]d[/xref]third day be raised.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]to be rejected on trial,[/i] implying deliberate rejection.

verse.text: And He said to [i]them[/i] all, If anyone wants to come after Me, let him deny himself and take up his [xref]a[/xref]cross [xref]b[/xref]daily and follow Me.
For whoever wants to save his soul-life shall [note]1[/note]lose it; but whoever [note]1[/note]loses his soul-life for My sake, this one shall save it.
verse.note: Or, destroy...destroys.

verse.text: For what is a man profited if he [note]1[/note]gains the whole world but loses or [note]1[/note]forfeits himself?
verse.note: A word used by merchants.

verse.text: For whoever is [xref]a[/xref]ashamed of Me and of My words, of this one will the Son of Man be ashamed when He [xref]b[/xref]comes in His glory and [i]the glory[/i] of the Father and of the [xref]c[/xref]holy angels.
But I say to you truly, There are some of those standing here who shall by [xref]a[/xref]no means [xref]b[/xref]taste death until they see the kingdom of God.
And about [note]1[/note]eight days after these words, He [xref]a[/xref]took with [i]Him[/i] [xref]b[/xref]Peter and John and James, and went up into the mountain to [xref]c[/xref]pray.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 28-36[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 17:1-9[/link].

verse.text: And as He prayed, the appearance of His face became [xref]a[/xref]different, and His garment [note]1[/note]dazzling [xref]b[/xref]white.
verse.note: Lit., flashing like lightning.

verse.text: And behold, two men were conversing with Him, who were Moses and Elijah,
Who appeared in glory and spoke of His [xref]a[/xref]departure, which He was about to complete in Jerusalem.
Now Peter and those with him had been overcome with [xref]a[/xref]sleep, but when they had fully woken up, they saw His [xref]b[/xref]glory and the two men who were standing with Him.

And as they were departing from Him, Peter said to Jesus, Master, it is good for us to be here; and let us make three [xref]a[/xref]tents, one for You and one for Moses and one for Elijah — not knowing what he was saying.
And while he said these things, a [xref]a[/xref]cloud appeared and overshadowed them; and they became frightened as they entered into the cloud.
And a [xref]a[/xref]voice came out of the cloud, [note]1[/note]saying, This is My Son, the [note]2[/note]Chosen One. [xref]b[/xref]Hear Him!
verse.note: This was God's word of revelation. It interrupted Peter's nonsensical word in [link]v. 33[/link].
Some MSS read, Beloved.

verse.text: And when the voice [note]1[/note]had spoken, Jesus was found alone. And they kept silent and reported to [xref]a[/xref]no one in those days anything of what they had seen.
verse.note: Lit., occurred.

verse.text: And on the following day, when they came down from the mountain, a great crowd met Him.
And behold, a [xref]a[/xref]man from the crowd called out, saying, Teacher, I beg You to look upon my son, for he is my [xref]b[/xref]only child.
And behold, a spirit takes him, and suddenly he cries out, and it [xref]a[/xref]throws him into convulsions with foaming; and it hardly goes away from him, [i]all the time[/i] crushing him.
And I begged Your disciples to [xref]a[/xref]cast it out, and they could not.
And Jesus answered and said, O unbelieving and [xref]a[/xref]perverted generation! How long shall I be [xref]b[/xref]with you and bear with you? Bring your son here.

And just as he was coming to [i]Him,[/i] the demon threw him down and greatly convulsed [i]him.[/i] But Jesus [xref]a[/xref]rebuked the [xref]b[/xref]unclean spirit and healed the child and [xref]c[/xref]gave him back to his father.
And all were astounded at the [xref]a[/xref]majesty of God.[separator]And while all were marveling at all the things which He did, He [xref]b[/xref]said to His disciples,
Put these words into your ears; for the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man is about to be [xref]b[/xref]delivered into the hands of men.
But they did [xref]a[/xref]not understand this saying, and it was [xref]b[/xref]concealed from them so that they would not perceive it; and they were afraid to ask Him concerning this saying.
And [xref]a[/xref]reasoning came in among them as to which of them was [xref]b[/xref]greatest.
And Jesus, seeing the reasoning of their [xref]a[/xref]heart, took hold of a little child and stood him beside Himself,

And He said to them, Whoever [xref]a[/xref]receives this little child [note]1[/note]because of My name receives Me; and whoever receives Me receives Him who sent Me; for he who is least among you all, this one is [xref]b[/xref]great.
verse.note: Lit., upon, or, on; i.e., based on, according to.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]John answered and said, Master, we saw someone casting out demons [xref]b[/xref]in Your name, and we [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]forbade him because he does not follow with us.
verse.note: See note [link]38[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 9[/link].

verse.text: But Jesus said to him, Do [note]1[/note]not forbid [i]him,[/i] for [note]2[/note]he who is [xref]a[/xref]not against you is for you.
verse.note: See note [link]39[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 9[/link].
See note [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 9[/link].

verse.text: And as the days were being fulfilled for Him to be [xref]a[/xref]taken up, He steadfastly set His face to go to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 10[/link].

verse.text: And He sent messengers [xref]a[/xref]before His face. And they went and entered into a village of the [xref]b[/xref]Samaritans to prepare for Him.
And they did not receive Him, because His [xref]a[/xref]face was [i]set[/i] to go to Jerusalem.
And seeing [i]this,[/i] the disciples James and John said, Lord, do You want us to [note]1[/note]command [xref]a[/xref]fire to come down from heaven and consume them[note]2[/note]?
verse.note: James and John were called "sons of thunder," indicating their impetuosity ([link]Mark 3:17[/link] and note 1). Their impetuous word here was against the virtue and morality of the Savior whom they accompanied (see note [link]38[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 9[/link]).
Some MSS add, as also Elijah did.

verse.text: But turning, He rebuked them [note]1[/note]and said, [note]2[/note]You do not know of what kind of spirit you are.
verse.note: Most ancient MSS omit, and said...you are.
This word, "You do not know of what kind of spirit you are," which shows the high morality of the Man-Savior, is found only in Luke.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]The Son of Man has not come to destroy men's [note]2[/note]lives but to save [i]them.[/i] And they went into another village.
verse.note: Most ancient MSS omit, The Son...save them.
Lit., souls.

verse.text: And as they went along the road, [note]1[/note]someone said to Him, I will [xref]a[/xref]follow You wherever You go.
verse.note: He was one of the scribes ([link]Matt. 8:19[/link]), who usually lived comfortably. He saw crowds being attracted to the Savior ([link]Matt. 8:18[/link]) and wanted to follow Him out of curiosity, without counting the cost (see note [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 8[/link]). Hence, the Savior cautioned him by pointing out that although crowds were attracted to Him, He had nowhere to rest, indicating to the scribe that to follow Him would cost him considerable suffering.

verse.text: And Jesus said to him, The foxes have holes, and the birds of heaven [i]have[/i] roosts, but the Son of Man does [note]1[/note]not have [i]a place[/i] where He may lay His head.
verse.note: The Savior's human life was one of suffering. In the inn, at His birth, there was no room in which He could lie ([link]2:7[/link]); and in His marvelous ministry there was no place for Him to rest. Suffering was a sign of His human life ([link]2:12[/link]).

verse.text: And He said to [note]1[/note]another, Follow Me. But he said, Lord, permit me to go first and bury my father.
verse.note: This one was called by the Savior to follow Him. But he considered his duty to his dead father and would not follow Him immediately. Hence, the Savior encouraged him to pay the price (see note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 8[/link]) that he might become a follower in His great commission to announce the kingdom of God.

verse.text: But He said to him, Let the [note]1[/note]dead bury their own dead, but you go and [note]2[/note]announce the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God everywhere.
verse.note: The burying one was spiritually dead ([link]John 5:25[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:1[/link]), and the one to be buried was physically dead. To engage in such a burial was to do a dead work.
To announce the kingdom of God is a living deed, a deed that makes the dead alive so that they can enter into the kingdom of God.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]another also said, I will follow You, Lord; but first [xref]a[/xref]permit me to say farewell to those in my house.
verse.note: This third one volunteered to follow the Savior, but would not do so before bidding farewell to his family. Hence, the Savior warned him not to let anything hold him back from the kingdom of God.

verse.text: But Jesus said to him, No one who puts his hand on the [note]1[/note]plow and looks [xref]a[/xref]behind is fit for the [xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God.
verse.note: To plow, one must concentrate all his attention on the line being plowed. Being distracted just a little, to say nothing of looking back, may lead the plower off the straight line. To follow the Savior, we must forget everything else and press straight ahead for the kingdom of God.

verse.text: Now after these things, the Lord appointed [note]1[/note]seventy others and [xref]a[/xref]sent them [note]2[/note]two by two before His face into every city and place where He Himself was about to come.
verse.note: Some MSS read, seventy-two. (So in [link]v. 17[/link].) The Savior appointed seventy disciples to share His ministry, even as Moses appointed seventy elders to share his burden, as God had charged him to do ([link]Num. 11:16-17[/link]; [link]Exo. 24:1[/link], [link]9[/link]).
As witnesses ([link]Deut. 17:6[/link]; [link]19:15[/link]; [link]Matt. 18:16[/link]).

verse.text: And He said to them, The [xref]a[/xref]harvest is great, but the workers few; therefore, [note]1[/note]beseech the Lord of the harvest that He would thrust out workers [note]2[/note]into His harvest.
verse.note: See note [link]38[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link].
See note [link]38[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link].

verse.text: Go; behold, I send you as [xref]a[/xref]lambs in the midst of wolves.
Do [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]not carry a purse, nor a bag, nor sandals; and greet [xref]b[/xref]no one on the way.
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: And into whatever house you enter, first say, [xref]a[/xref]Peace to this house.
And if a [note]1[/note]son of peace is there, your peace shall rest upon [note]2[/note]it; but if not, it shall [xref]a[/xref]return upon you.
verse.note: The Lord sent the disciples to preach the gospel by going to every city and place and visiting people in their homes. This may serve to confirm our preaching of the gospel today by knocking on doors and visiting people from door to door. The Lord sent the disciples as lambs entering into the midst of wolves ([link]v. 3[/link]). However, among the wolves there were sons of peace, that is, sheep that the Lord was concerned about ([link]Matt. 9:36[/link]) and the harvest that He desired to reap ([link]v. 2[/link]; [link]Matt. 9:37-38[/link]). Because these sheep and the harvest, both of which belonged to the Lord, were scattered and mixed with the wolves, it was necessary for the Lord's disciples to go into the midst of the wolves to seek them out house by house and to reap them. It is the same today. Preaching the gospel by going out to every place to visit people in their homes is ordained by God. It is absolutely different from today's religious way of holding large gatherings to carry out gospel campaigns.
Or, him.

verse.text: And in that house [xref]a[/xref]remain, [xref]b[/xref]eating and drinking the things from them, for the [xref]c[/xref]worker is worthy of his wages. Do not move from house to house.
And into whatever city you enter and they receive you, eat what is [xref]a[/xref]set before you;
And [xref]a[/xref]heal the sick who are in it and say to them, The [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God has drawn near to you.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: But into whatever city you enter and they do not receive you, go out into its streets and say,
Even the [xref]a[/xref]dust from your city which clings to our feet, we wipe off against you; yet know this, that the kingdom of God has drawn near.
I say to you that it will be [note]1[/note]more tolerable for [xref]a[/xref]Sodom in that day than for that city.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: Woe to you, [xref]a[/xref]Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the [xref]b[/xref]works of power which took place in you had taken place in [xref]c[/xref]Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in [xref]d[/xref]sackcloth and ashes.
Yet it will be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon in the judgment than for you.
And you, Capernaum, who have been [xref]a[/xref]exalted to heaven, to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Hades you will be [xref]c[/xref]brought down.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].

verse.text: He who hears you hears Me, and he who [xref]a[/xref]rejects you rejects Me, and he who rejects Me rejects Him who [xref]b[/xref]sent Me.
And the seventy returned with joy, saying, Lord, even the demons are subject to us [xref]a[/xref]in Your name.
And He said to them, I was watching Satan [note]1[/note]fall like lightning out of heaven.
verse.note: At the time of his rebellion against God, before the creation of man, Satan was judged and sentenced to be cast into Sheol (Hades), to the recesses (the deepest part) of the pit ([link]Isa. 14:15[/link]; [link]Ezek. 28:17[/link]). Then God began to execute the sentence He had imposed on him. He has executed, and will execute, this sentence on different occasions and to different degrees, such as through the seventy disciples in this chapter, through Christ on the cross ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]; [link]John 12:31[/link]), through the man-child and Michael before the great tribulation, when Satan will be cast down to the earth ([link]Rev. 12:5[/link], [link]7-10[/link], [link]13[/link]), and through the angel before the millennium, when Satan will be cast into the abyss, the bottomless pit ([link]Rev. 20:1-3[/link]). Finally, Satan will be cast into the lake of fire to suffer the punishment of eternal fire after the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:10[/link]) for eternity.

verse.text: Behold, I have given you the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]authority to tread upon [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]serpents and [note]2[/note]scorpions and over all the [note]1[/note]power of the enemy, and nothing shall by any means hurt you.
verse.note: What the Lord gave to the disciples was authority; what the enemy had was power. Authority subdues power.

Serpents may signify Satan and his angels ([link]Eph. 2:2[/link]; [link]6:11-12[/link]); scorpions may signify the demons ([link]vv. 17[/link], [link]20[/link]). By the authority of the Lord the disciples subdued their evil power.

verse.text: However do not rejoice in this, that the [xref]a[/xref]spirits are subject to you, but rejoice that your names are [xref]b[/xref]recorded in the heavens.

[note]1[/note]In that hour He exulted in the Holy Spirit and [xref]a[/xref]said, I extol You, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because You have hidden these things from the [xref]b[/xref]wise and intelligent and have revealed them to [xref]c[/xref]babes. Yes, Father, for thus it has been [xref]d[/xref]well pleasing in Your sight.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 21-22[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 11:25-27[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]All things have been delivered to Me by My Father; and no one knows who the Son is except the Father, and who the Father is [xref]b[/xref]except the Son and him to whom the Son wills to [xref]c[/xref]reveal [i]Him.[/i]
And turning to the disciples, He said privately, [xref]a[/xref]Blessed are the eyes which see the things that you see.

For I tell you that many [xref]a[/xref]prophets and kings have wanted to [xref]b[/xref]perceive the things that you see, and have not perceived [i]them,[/i] and to hear the things that you hear, and have not heard [i]them.[/i]
And behold, a certain lawyer stood up and put Him to the [note]1[/note]test, [xref]a[/xref]saying, Teacher, [note]2[/note]what should I do to [note]3[/note]inherit eternal life?
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].
Lit., having done what, may I inherit eternal life?
See notes [link book="Matt." chapter="19"]29[sup]3[/sup][/link] and [link]17[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 19[/link].

verse.text: And He said to him, What is written in the law? How do you read [i]it?[/i]

And he answered and said, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall love the Lord your God from your whole heart and [note]1[/note]with your whole soul and [note]1[/note]with your whole strength and [note]1[/note]with your whole mind, and [xref]b[/xref]your neighbor as yourself."
verse.note: Lit., in.

verse.text: And He said to him, You have answered correctly; [xref]a[/xref]do this, and you shall have life.
But he, wanting to [note]1[/note]justify himself, said to Jesus, And who is my neighbor?
verse.note: He must have been one of the self-justified Pharisees ([link]16:14-15[/link]; [link]18:9-10[/link]).

verse.text: Jesus, taking up [i]the question,[/i] said, A [note]1[/note]certain man was going [note]2[/note]down from [note]3[/note]Jerusalem to [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]Jericho, and he fell among [note]4[/note]robbers, who having both [note]5[/note]stripped him and [note]6[/note]beaten [i]him,[/i] went away, [note]7[/note]leaving [i]him[/i] half dead.
verse.note: This is one of the parables narrated only by Luke. It conveys the principle of high morality in the Savior's full salvation. The Savior intended the "certain man" to be a figure of the self-justified lawyer ([link]v. 29[/link]) as a sinner who had fallen from the foundation of peace (Jerusalem) to the condition of curse (Jericho).
Indicating a fall from the city of the foundation of peace to the city of curse.
[i]Jerusalem[/i] means [i]foundation[/i] of peace (cf. [link]Heb. 7:2[/link]); Jericho was a city of curse ([link]Josh. 6:26[/link]; [link]1 Kings 16:34[/link]).
Signifying the legalistic teachers of the Judaic law ([link]John 10:1[/link]), who used the law ([link]1 Cor. 15:56[/link]) to rob lawkeepers such as the self-justified lawyer.
Signifying the stripping caused by the Judaistic teachers' misuse of the law.
Lit., laid blows upon; signifying the killing by the law ([link]Rom. 7:9-10[/link]).
Signifying that the Judaistic teachers left the lawkeeper in a dead condition ([link]Rom. 7:11[/link], [link]13[/link]).

verse.text: And by coincidence a certain [note]1[/note]priest was going down on that road; and when he saw him, he passed by on the opposite side.
verse.note: The one who should have cared for God's people by teaching them the law of God ([link]Deut. 33:10[/link]; [link]2 Chron. 15:3[/link]) was going down on the same road and was thus unable to render any help to the beaten one.

verse.text: And likewise also a [note]1[/note]Levite, when he came to the place and saw [i]him,[/i] passed by on the opposite side.
verse.note: One of those who helped God's people in their worship to God ([link]Num. 1:50[/link]; [link]3:6-7[/link]; [link]8:19[/link]) was coming to the same place, and he too was unable to render any help to the dying one.

verse.text: But a certain [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Samaritan, who was journeying, came upon him; and when he saw him, he was moved with [xref]b[/xref]compassion;
verse.note: Signifying the Man-Savior, who apparently was a layman of low estate. He was despised and slandered as a low and mean Samaritan ([link]John 8:48[/link]; [link]4:9[/link] and note 1) by the self-exalted and self-justified Pharisees, including the one to whom He was speaking here ([link]vv. 25[/link], [link]29[/link]). Such a Man-Savior, in His lost-one-seeking and sinner-saving ministry journey ([link]19:10[/link]), came down to the place where the wounded victim of the Judaistic robbers lay in his miserable and dying condition. When He saw him, He was moved with compassion in His humanity with His divinity and rendered him tender healing and saving care, fully meeting his urgent need ([link]vv. 34-35[/link]).

verse.text: And he came to [i]him[/i] and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bound up his wounds and poured oil and wine on [i]them.[/i] And placing him on his own beast, he brought him to an inn and took care of him.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 34-35[/link] all the aspects of the good Samaritan's care for the dying one portray the Man-Savior in His merciful, tender, and bountiful care, in His humanity with His divinity, for a sinner condemned under law, showing to the uttermost His high standard of morality in His saving grace: (1) He bound up his wounds — healing him; (2) He poured oil and wine on his wounds — giving him the Holy Spirit and the divine life ([link]Matt. 9:17[/link] and note 1; [link]John 2:9[/link] and note 1); (3) He placed him on his own beast (a donkey) — carrying him by lowly means in a lowly way ([link]Zech. 9:9[/link]); (4) He brought him to an inn — bringing him to the church; (5) He took care of him — taking care of him through the church; (6) He paid the inn for him — blessing the church on his behalf; (7) He said that he would repay at his return whatever the inn spent — declaring that whatever the church spends in this age on one who is saved by the Lord will be repaid at the Savior's coming back.

verse.text: And on the next day he took out two [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]denarii and gave [i]them[/i] to the innkeeper and said, Take care of him; and whatever you spend in addition [i]to this,[/i] when I return, I will repay you.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in John 6[/link].

verse.text: Which of these three, does it seem to you, has [note]1[/note]become a neighbor to him who fell into [i]the hands[/i] of the robbers?
verse.note: The self-justified lawyer thought that he could love another as his neighbor ([link]v. 29[/link]), not knowing, under the blindness of self-justification, that he himself needed a neighbor, the Man-Savior, to love him.

verse.text: And he said, [note]1[/note]The one who showed mercy to him. And Jesus said to him, Go, and you do likewise.
verse.note: Or, The one who dealt mercifully with him. The self-justified one was helped to know that he needed a loving neighbor (such as the good Samaritan, who was a figure of the Man-Savior) to love him, not a neighbor for him to love. The Savior intended to unveil to him through this story (1) that he was condemned to death under the law and was unable to take care of himself, much less love others, and (2) that the Man-Savior was the One who would love him and render him full salvation.

verse.text: Now as they went, He entered into a certain [note]1[/note]village, and a certain woman named [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Martha [xref]b[/xref]received Him into her home.
verse.note: Bethany ([link]John 12:1[/link] and note 1; [link]Mark 11:1[/link]; [link]Matt. 21:17[/link] and note 1).
Probably from Aramaic, meaning [i]she was rebellious.[/i]

verse.text: And she had a sister called [note]1[/note]Mary, who also sat at the Lord's [xref]a[/xref]feet and was listening to His word.
verse.note: Gk. [i]Maria[/i] for Heb. [i]Miriam,[/i] meaning [i]their rebellion[/i] ([link]Num. 12:1[/link], [link]10-15[/link]). The meaning of [i]Martha[/i] and [i]Mary[/i] conveys the thought of rebellion, perhaps pointing to the natural life of Martha and Mary. The Lord's salvation can transform the rebellious into the submissive, as portrayed in this story. One like the rebellious Miriam in the Old Testament becomes one like the submissive Mary in the New Testament.

verse.text: But Martha was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]being drawn about with much serving, and she came up to [i]Him[/i] and said, Lord, does it not matter to You that my sister has left me to serve alone? Tell her then to do her part with me.
verse.note: Meaning [i]to be drawn around in different directions.[/i]

verse.text: But the Lord answered and said to her, Martha, Martha, you are [xref]a[/xref]anxious and troubled about many things;
But there is need of [xref]a[/xref]one thing, for Mary has chosen the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]good part, which shall not be taken away from her.
verse.note: The Lord prefers that His saved ones who love Him listen to Him ([link]v. 39[/link]) that they may know His desire, rather than do things for Him without knowing His will (cf. [link]1 Sam. 15:22[/link]; [link]Eccl. 5:1[/link]).[br][br]It is quite significant that this story of Martha and Mary immediately follows the parable of the good Samaritan. The parable shows the compassion and love of the Savior, who is a man and becomes the sinners' neighbor; the story of Martha and Mary unveils the desire and preference of the Lord, who is God and becomes the believers' Master. The Savior gives us His compassion and love so that we can be saved by Him; the Lord expresses His desire and preference so that we can serve Him. After receiving salvation from the Savior, we should render service to the Lord. For our salvation we need to realize the Savior's compassion and love; for our service we need to know the Lord's desire and preference.

verse.text: And while He was in a certain place praying, when He ceased, a certain one of His disciples said to Him, Lord, teach us to pray, even as John also taught his disciples.
And He said to them, [xref]a[/xref]When you [note]1[/note]pray, say, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Father, Your name be [xref]c[/xref]sanctified; Your [xref]d[/xref]kingdom come.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 2-4[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 6:9-13[/link].
Some MSS read, Our Father who is in the heavens.

verse.text: Give us each day our daily [xref]a[/xref]bread.
And [xref]a[/xref]forgive us our sins, for we also forgive everyone [xref]b[/xref]indebted to us. And do not bring us into [xref]c[/xref]temptation[note]1[/note].
verse.note: Some MSS add, but deliver us from the evil one (or, from evil).

verse.text: And He said to them, Who among you will have a friend and will go to him at midnight and say to him, Friend, lend me three loaves,
Since a friend of mine has come to me from a journey and I have nothing to set before him;
And that one, from inside, will answer and say, Do not trouble me; the door is already shut and my children are with me in bed; I cannot rise up and give you [i]anything?[/i]
I say to you, Even though he will not rise up and give him [i]anything[/i] because he is his friend, surely because of his shameless persistence he will rise and give him what he needs.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]And I say to you, [xref]b[/xref]Ask and it shall be given to you; [xref]c[/xref]seek and you shall find; knock and it shall be opened to you.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 9-13[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 7:7-11[/link].

verse.text: For everyone who asks receives, and he who seeks finds, and to him who knocks it shall be opened.
But what father among you [note]1[/note][i]whose[/i] son shall ask for a fish will instead of a fish hand him a snake?
verse.note: Some MSS read, whose son asks for bread, will hand him a stone? Or if also for a fish, will instead...?

verse.text: Or [i]if[/i] he shall also ask for an egg will hand him a scorpion?

If you then being [xref]a[/xref]evil know [i]how[/i] to give good gifts to your children, how much more will the Father who is from heaven give the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Holy Spirit to those who [note]2[/note]ask Him!
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 7[/link].

Before His death the Lord told the disciples to ask for the Holy Spirit; after His death and resurrection He told them to receive the Holy Spirit ([link]John 20:22[/link]). Regarding the commandments in the Scriptures for which the requirements have not been fulfilled, we must ask; regarding the commandments for which the requirements have been fulfilled, we must receive.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And [i]once[/i] He was [xref]a[/xref]casting out a demon, and it was dumb. And when the demon had gone out, the dumb man spoke, and the crowds marveled.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 14-15[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 9:32-34[/link] and [link]12:22-24[/link].

verse.text: But some of them said, By [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Beelzebul, the ruler of the demons, He casts out the demons.
verse.note: See note [link]25[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: And others, [xref]a[/xref]tempting [i]Him,[/i] [xref]b[/xref]sought from Him a sign out of heaven.

[note]1[/note]But [xref]a[/xref]He, [xref]b[/xref]knowing their [note]2[/note]thoughts, said to them, Every kingdom divided against itself becomes desolate, and a house [i]divided[/i] against a house falls.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 17-23[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 12:25-30[/link] and [link]Mark 3:23-27[/link].
In the sense of machinations.

verse.text: And if Satan also is divided against himself, how shall his kingdom stand? For you say that [i]it is[/i] by Beelzebul [i]that[/i] I cast out the demons.
But if I by Beelzebul [xref]a[/xref]cast out the demons, by whom do your sons cast [i]them[/i] out? Therefore they shall be your judges.
But if I by the [note]1[/note]finger of God cast out the demons, then the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God has come upon you.
verse.note: A Hebraic expression. The finger ([link]v. 46[/link]) is smaller than the hand and the arm. The casting out of demons does not require the hand of God ([link]John 10:28-29[/link]) or the arm of God ([link]Isa. 53:1[/link]); the finger of God is powerful enough to do it. Still, it is done by the Spirit of God ([link]Matt. 12:28[/link]).

verse.text: When the [xref]a[/xref]strong man, fully armed, guards his own [note]1[/note]homestead, his possessions are in peace.
verse.note: Lit., courtyard.

verse.text: But when one [note]1[/note]stronger than he comes upon [i]him[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]overcomes him, he takes away his whole armor in which he had trusted and [xref]b[/xref]distributes his spoil.
verse.note: Christ, the Son of God, is much stronger than Satan, the strong man. Thus, He can subdue and overcome Satan for us.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]He who is not with Me is against Me, and he who does not gather with Me scatters.
verse.note: See note [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 9[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]When the unclean [xref]a[/xref]spirit goes out from the man, it roams through waterless places, seeking rest, and not finding [i]it,[/i] it says, I will return to my house from which I came out.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 24-26[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 12:43-45[/link].

verse.text: And it comes and finds [i]it[/i] swept and decorated.

Then it goes and takes along other spirits more evil than itself, seven [i]of them,[/i] and they enter and settle down there. And the last [i]state[/i] of that man becomes [xref]a[/xref]worse than the first.
And as He said these things, a certain woman out of the crowd lifted up [i]her[/i] voice and said to Him, [xref]a[/xref]Blessed is the womb that bore You and the breasts at which You nursed.
But He said, Blessed rather are those who [xref]a[/xref]hear the word of God and keep [i]it.[/i]

[note]1[/note]And as the crowds were thronging together, He began to say, [xref]a[/xref]This generation is an evil generation; it [xref]b[/xref]seeks a sign, and a sign shall not be given to it except the sign of [xref]c[/xref]Jonah.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 29-32[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 12:38-42[/link].

verse.text: For even as Jonah became a sign to the Ninevites, so also will the Son of Man be to this generation.

The [xref]a[/xref]queen of the south will rise up in the judgment with the men of this generation and will [xref]b[/xref]condemn them, because she came from the ends of the earth to hear the [xref]c[/xref]wisdom of Solomon, and behold, something [xref]d[/xref]more than Solomon is here.

[xref]a[/xref]Ninevite men will stand up in the judgment with this generation and will condemn it, because they [xref]b[/xref]repented at the preaching of Jonah, and behold, something more than Jonah is here.

No one, after lighting a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lamp, puts [i]it[/i] in the cellar or under the [note]2[/note]bushel, but on the [note]3[/note]lampstand, in order that those who enter in may see the light.
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 4[/link].
See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].
See note [link]15[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]lamp of the body is your eye. When your eye is [note]1[/note]single, your whole body also is [note]2[/note]full of light; but when it is [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]evil, your body also is dark.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].
Or, illuminated.
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].

verse.text: Watch out therefore that the [note]1[/note]light which is in you is not darkness.
verse.note: The light in us, with which the eye illuminates the whole body ([link]v. 34[/link]), is the light in our heart, which should be kept pure for God ([link]Matt. 5:8[/link]). See note [link]23[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].

verse.text: If therefore your whole body is full of light and does not have any dark part, the whole will be full of light as when the lamp with its rays illuminates you.
Now as He spoke, a Pharisee asked Him to have the [note]1[/note]morning [xref]a[/xref]meal with him; and He went in and reclined [i]at table.[/i]
verse.note: Primarily, the first meal, taken early in the morning (so in [link]v. 38[/link]).

verse.text: But the Pharisee, seeing [i]it,[/i] marveled that He had not first [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]washed before the meal.
verse.note: Lit., baptized (indicating a ceremonial washing).

verse.text: But the Lord said to him, Again, you Pharisees [xref]a[/xref]cleanse the outside of the cup and of the platter, but your inside is full of extortion and wickedness.
[xref]a[/xref]Foolish ones! Did not He who made the outside make the inside also?
But [xref]a[/xref]give the things which are [note]1[/note]within as alms, and behold, all things are [xref]b[/xref]clean to you.
verse.note: [i]Within[/i] refers to the contents of the cup and to the items on the platter ([link]v. 39[/link]); these signify what was in the heart of the Pharisees. They had covetousness within their heart; hence, they were full of extortion and wickedness ([link]v. 39[/link]). Therefore, the Lord commanded them to give as alms what they were coveting in their heart, that all things might be clean to them.

verse.text: But woe to you, Pharisees! For you [xref]a[/xref]give a tenth of the [xref]b[/xref]mint and the rue and every herb, and pass by [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]justice and love for God. But these you should have done and [note]2[/note]not passed by the others.
verse.note: Or, judgment.
See note [link]23[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 23[/link].

verse.text: Woe to you, Pharisees! For you love the [xref]a[/xref]chief seat in the synagogues and the greetings in the [xref]b[/xref]marketplaces.
Woe to you! For you are like the unseen [xref]a[/xref]tombs, and the men who walk over [i]them[/i] do not know [i]it.[/i]
And one of the [xref]a[/xref]lawyers answered and said to Him, Teacher, by saying these things, you [note]1[/note]insult us also.
verse.note: Or, outrage.

verse.text: And He said, Woe to you lawyers also! For you burden men with burdens [xref]a[/xref]hard to bear, yet you yourselves do not [note]1[/note]touch the burdens with one of your fingers.
verse.note: A term used by medical writers for gently feeling a sore or tender part of the body.

verse.text: Woe to you! For you [xref]a[/xref]build up the [note]1[/note]tombs of the prophets, and your fathers [xref]b[/xref]killed them.
verse.note: Or, monuments (so in [link]v. 48[/link]).

verse.text: You are witnesses then and fully approve of the works of your fathers, because they killed them, and you build up [i]their tombs.[/i]
Therefore the [note]1[/note]wisdom of God also has said, I will [xref]a[/xref]send to them [xref]b[/xref]prophets and apostles, and some of them they will [xref]c[/xref]kill and persecute,
verse.note: Referring to Christ as the wisdom of God in God's New Testament economy ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]); He is the "I" in [link]Matt. 23:34[/link]. The Lord's word in [link]Matt. 23:34-36[/link] and [link]Luke 11:49-51[/link] was based on the record in [link]2 Chron. 24:20-22[/link] concerning the slaying of Zechariah, and it expanded the word in [link]2 Chron. 24:19[/link], applying it to those who were sent by God in both the Old Testament and the New Testament.

verse.text: In order that the [xref]a[/xref]blood of all the prophets which has been poured out [xref]b[/xref]from the foundation of the world may be [xref]c[/xref]required of this generation,
From the blood of [xref]a[/xref]Abel to the blood of [xref]b[/xref]Zachariah, who perished between the altar and the house. Yes, I tell you, it will be required of [note]1[/note]this generation.
verse.note: Required not only of the individual but also of that generation collectively.

verse.text: Woe to you [xref]a[/xref]lawyers! For you have taken away the key of [xref]b[/xref]knowledge; you yourselves did not enter, and those who were entering, you [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]hindered.
verse.note: Or, prevented, forbade.

verse.text: And when He went out from there, the scribes and the Pharisees began to be very hostile and to provoke Him to speak concerning many things,
[xref]a[/xref]Lying in wait for Him in order to [note]1[/note]catch [xref]b[/xref]something out of His mouth.
verse.note: I.e., to ensnare in hunting ([link]Matt. 22:15[/link]). The religionists, who claimed to be devout, did this to the One who expressed God.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Meanwhile, when the myriads of the crowd were gathered together so that they trampled on one another, He began to say to His disciples first, Beware of the [xref]a[/xref]leaven of the Pharisees, which is [xref]b[/xref]hypocrisy.
verse.note: Or, In these circumstances.

verse.text: But there is nothing [xref]a[/xref]covered up which will not be revealed, and [xref]b[/xref]hidden which will not be known.
Therefore what you have said in the darkness will be heard in the light, and what you have spoken in the ear in the private rooms will be proclaimed on the [xref]a[/xref]housetops.
And I say to you My [xref]a[/xref]friends, Do not [xref]b[/xref]fear those who kill the body and afterward have nothing more that they can do.
But I will [note]1[/note]show you whom you should fear: fear [note]2[/note]Him who, after killing, has authority to [xref]a[/xref]cast into [note]3[/note]Gehenna; yes, I tell you, fear this One.
verse.note: Lit., show you secretly.
See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].
See note [link]22[sup]8[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: Are not five sparrows sold for two [note]1[/note]assaria? And not one of them is forgotten before God.
verse.note: The second-smallest coin in the Greco-Roman coinage of Palestine.

verse.text: But even the [xref]a[/xref]hairs of your head have all been numbered. Do not be afraid; you are of [xref]b[/xref]more value than many [xref]c[/xref]sparrows.

Moreover, I tell you, Everyone who [xref]a[/xref]confesses [note]1[/note]in Me before men, the [xref]b[/xref]Son of Man will also [xref]c[/xref]confess [note]2[/note]in him before the [xref]d[/xref]angels of God;
verse.note: Implying his union with the Lord.
Implying the Lord's union with him.

verse.text: But he who [xref]a[/xref]denies Me before men will be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]denied before the angels of God.
verse.note: In Greek this word is stronger than the word translated [i]denies[/i] in this verse. See note [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: And everyone who will say a word against the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man, it will be forgiven him; but he who [note]1[/note]blasphemes against the [xref]b[/xref]Holy Spirit will not be forgiven.
verse.note: See notes [link book="Matt." chapter="12"]31[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]32[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 12[/link].

verse.text: And when they bring you before the [xref]a[/xref]synagogues and the [xref]b[/xref]rulers and the authorities, do not be [xref]c[/xref]anxious about how or what you should reply in defense, or what you should say;
For the Holy [note]1[/note]Spirit will teach you in that hour what should be said.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: And someone out of the crowd said to Him, Teacher, tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me.
But He said to him, Man, [xref]a[/xref]who appointed Me a judge or a divider over you?
And He said to them, [xref]a[/xref]Watch and guard yourself from all [xref]b[/xref]covetousness, for no one's life is in the abundance of his possessions.
And He told them a parable, saying, The land of a certain [xref]a[/xref]rich man brought forth abundantly.
And he reasoned in himself, saying, What shall I do, for I have no [i]place[/i] where I may gather my [note]1[/note]crops?
verse.note: Or, fruits.

verse.text: And he said, I will do this: I will tear down my barns and build larger ones, and I will gather there all my wheat and my goods.
And I will say to my soul, Soul, you have many goods laid up for many [xref]a[/xref]years; rest, [xref]b[/xref]eat, drink, be merry.

But God said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Foolish one, this night [note]1[/note]they are requiring your [xref]b[/xref]soul from you; and the things which you have [xref]c[/xref]prepared, [xref]d[/xref]whose will they be?
verse.note: The expression is indefinite, referring probably to the angels, God's messengers.

verse.text: So is he who stores up [xref]a[/xref]treasure for himself and is not [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]rich toward God.
verse.note: How precious it is to be rich toward God! This requires that we not store up treasure for ourselves.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He said to His disciples, Therefore I say to you, Do not be [xref]a[/xref]anxious for your [note]2[/note]life, what you should eat; nor for your body, what you should put on;
verse.note: For [link]vv. 22-31[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 6:25-33[/link].
Lit., soul; referring to the soul-life (so in [link]v. 23[/link]).

verse.text: For the life is more than food, and the body [i]more[/i] than clothing.
Consider the [xref]a[/xref]ravens. They neither sow nor reap, they have neither storehouse nor barn; yet God nourishes them. How much [xref]b[/xref]more valuable are you than the birds!
And which of you by being anxious can add a cubit to his stature?
If then you cannot do even the least, why are you anxious about the rest?
Consider the lilies, how they grow; they do not toil nor even spin [i]thread;[/i] but I tell you, Not even [xref]a[/xref]Solomon in all his glory was clothed like one of these.
Now if God so arrays the grass in the field, which is [i]here[/i] today and tomorrow is cast into the furnace, how much more [i]will He clothe[/i] you, you of [xref]a[/xref]little faith!
And you, do not seek what you shall eat and what you shall drink, and do not [note]1[/note]be [xref]a[/xref]unsettled.
verse.note: Or, be anxious.

verse.text: For all these things the Gentiles of the world are anxiously seeking, but your Father knows that you [xref]a[/xref]need these things.
However, seek His [xref]a[/xref]kingdom, and these things shall be [xref]b[/xref]added to you.
Do not [xref]a[/xref]be afraid, little [xref]b[/xref]flock, because your Father has been [xref]c[/xref]well pleased to give you the [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]kingdom.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Sell your possessions and [xref]b[/xref]give alms; make for yourselves purses which do not become old, an unfailing [note]1[/note]treasure in the heavens, where thief does not come near nor even moth corrupts;
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].

verse.text: For where your treasure is, there also your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]heart will be.
verse.note: Our heart is attached to our treasure. If we lay up for ourselves treasures on earth, it will be difficult for our heart to be in heaven or to be for our beloved Lord and His interest.

verse.text: Let your loins be [xref]a[/xref]girded and your [xref]b[/xref]lamps burning,
And you be like men waiting for their own master when he returns from the wedding feast, so that when he comes and [xref]a[/xref]knocks they may open to him immediately.

Blessed are those slaves whom the master, when he comes, will find [xref]a[/xref]watching. Truly I tell you that he will [xref]b[/xref]gird himself and will have them [xref]c[/xref]recline [i]at table,[/i] and he will [note]1[/note]come to [i]them[/i] and [xref]d[/xref]serve them.
verse.note: Or, come beside.

verse.text: And if he comes in the second watch, or if in the third, and finds [i]them[/i] so, blessed are those [i]slaves.[/i]
