[note]1[/note]But [note]2[/note]know this, that if the [xref]a[/xref]master of the house had [note]2[/note]known in what hour the [xref]b[/xref]thief was coming, he would[note]3[/note] not have allowed his house to be [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]broken into.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 39-46[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:43-51[/link].

In Greek the first [i]know[/i] here is the same as the first [i]know[/i] in [link]Heb. 8:11[/link]; the second [i]know[/i] (here, [i]known[/i]) is the same as the second there. See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup][/link] there.
Some MSS add, have watched and.
Lit., dug through.

verse.text: You also, be [xref]a[/xref]ready, because at an hour when you do not expect [i]it,[/i] the Son of Man is [xref]b[/xref]coming.
And Peter said, Lord, are You saying this parable to us, or also to [xref]a[/xref]all?

And the Lord said, Who then is the [xref]a[/xref]faithful [i]and[/i] [xref]b[/xref]prudent [xref]c[/xref]steward, whom the master will set over his service to give [i]them[/i] their portion of food at the proper time?
[xref]a[/xref]Blessed is that slave whom his master, when he comes, will find so doing.
Truly I tell you that he will [xref]a[/xref]set him over all his possessions.

But if that slave says in his heart, My master is [xref]a[/xref]delaying [i]his[/i] coming, and begins to beat the male servants and the female servants and to eat and to drink and become [xref]b[/xref]drunk,

The master of that slave will come on a [xref]a[/xref]day when he does not expect [i]him[/i] and at an hour which he does not know, and will cut him asunder, and will appoint his portion with the unbelievers.
And that slave who knew his master's will and did not prepare or do according to his will, will receive many [xref]a[/xref]lashes;

But he who did [xref]a[/xref]not know, yet did things worthy of stripes, will receive few lashes. But to everyone to whom [xref]b[/xref]much has been given, much will be required from him; and to whom much has been [note]1[/note]committed, they will ask of him all the more.
verse.note: Or, entrusted, deposited.

verse.text: I have come to cast [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fire on the earth, and [note]2[/note]how I wish that it were already kindled!
verse.note: The impulse of the spiritual life. This impulse comes from the Lord's released divine life (see note [link]50[sup]2[/sup][/link]) and causes the divisions mentioned in [link]vv. 51-53[/link].
Or, what can I desire if it has already been kindled?

verse.text: But I have a [note]1[/note]baptism to be baptized with, and how I am [note]2[/note]pressed until it is accomplished!
verse.note: See note [link]38[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 10[/link].

Or, constrained. The Lord was constrained in His flesh, which He put upon Himself in His incarnation. He needed to undergo physical death, to be baptized, that His unlimited and infinite divine being with His divine life might be released from His flesh. His divine life, after being released through His physical death, became the impulse of His believers' spiritual life in resurrection.

verse.text: Do you think that I have [xref]a[/xref]come to give peace on the earth? No, I tell you, but rather [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]division.
verse.note: This is because the satanic life in the unbelievers is struggling against the divine life in the believers — a conflict between the satanic kingdom and the kingdom of God. See note [link]34[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: For from now on there will be five in one house divided, three against two and two against three.

They will be divided: father against son and [xref]a[/xref]son against father; mother against her daughter and daughter against her mother; mother-in-law against her daughter-in-law, and daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law.
And He said also to the crowds, When you see a cloud rising in the west, immediately you say that a [xref]a[/xref]shower is coming, and so it happens.
And when [i]you see[/i] a [xref]a[/xref]south wind blowing, you say that there will be scorching heat, and it happens.

[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hypocrites, you know how to [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]discern the [note]3[/note]face of the earth and of the sky. [note]4[/note]How is it then that you do not know [i]how[/i] to [note]5[/note]discern this time?
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].
Or, prove by testing.
I.e., appearance.
Or, but this time you do not know how to discern.

I.e., discern the signs of the time ([link]Matt. 16:3[/link]). The signs were (1) that, as prophesied ([link]3:2-6[/link], [link]15-17[/link]), John the Baptist had come to announce the coming of Messiah, and (2) that Messiah was there, ministering Himself that the people might receive Him and be saved.

verse.text: And why do you not [xref]a[/xref]judge also of [note]1[/note]yourselves what is right?
verse.note: Even without the teaching of the Lord, the Jews had seen enough signs to judge of themselves the right way to follow and the right thing to do at that time, that is, to receive the Lord and follow Him.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For as you are going with your [xref]a[/xref]opponent at law to a magistrate, [note]2[/note]endeavor to be released from him on the way, lest he drag you to the judge; and the judge will deliver you up to the officer, and the officer will throw you into prison.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that [link]vv. 58-59[/link] are a continuation of [link]v. 57[/link]. In this continuation the Man-Savior charged the Jews that while they were still on the way (were going), under the law (their opponent — [link]John 5:45[/link]), to meet God (the magistrate) and be judged by Christ (the judge — [link]John 5:22[/link]; [link]Acts 17:31[/link]), they should endeavor to be released from their opponent that they might not be judged by Christ and thrown into the lake of fire (prison — [link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]) by the angel (the officer — cf. [link]Matt. 13:41[/link]). If that were to happen, they would by no means come out forever ([link]v. 59[/link]). The word in these two verses was spoken to the crowds ([link]v. 54[/link]) that they might repent and be saved. But in [link]Matt. 5:25-26[/link] this word was applied to the disciples that they might live the kingdom life (see notes there).
Or, take pains.

verse.text: I tell you, You shall by no means come out from there until you have paid the very last [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lepton.
verse.note: The smallest coin in the Greco-Roman coinage of Palestine.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Now there were some present at the same time who reported to Him concerning the [xref]a[/xref]Galileans whose blood [xref]b[/xref]Pilate had mixed with their sacrifices.
verse.note: [i]Now[/i] indicates that [link]vv. 1-9[/link], which deal further with the matter of repentance, continue the last verses of [link]ch. 12[/link]. The Lord used the two incidents in [link]vv. 1-5[/link] to remind the Jews that now was the time for them to repent and that if they did not, they would all perish like the victims of those two incidents.

verse.text: And He answered and said to them, Do you think that these Galileans were sinners beyond all the Galileans because they suffered these things?
No, I tell you; but unless you [xref]a[/xref]repent, you shall all likewise [xref]b[/xref]perish.
Or those eighteen on whom the tower in [xref]a[/xref]Siloam fell and killed them, do you think that they were debtors beyond all the men dwelling in Jerusalem?
No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you shall all similarly perish.
[note]1[/note]And He told [note]2[/note]this parable: A certain man had a [xref]a[/xref]fig tree planted in his [xref]b[/xref]vineyard. And he came seeking fruit on it and did not find [i]any.[/i]
verse.note: [i]And[/i] indicates that [link]vv. 6-9[/link] are a continuation of the foregoing verses concerning repentance.

This parable indicates that God as the owner came in the Son to seek fruit from the Jewish people, who were likened to a fig tree (see note [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 21[/link]) planted in God's promised land, the vineyard (cf. [link]Matt. 21:33[/link] and note 1). He had been seeking fruit for three years ([link]v. 7[/link]) but had not found any. He wanted to cut the Jews down, but God the Son as the vinedresser prayed for them, asking God the Father to tolerate them until the Son died for them (dug the ground around the fig tree) and gave them fertilizer (threw on manure), at which point, He hoped, they would repent and produce fruit. Otherwise, they would be cut down. [link chapter="11"]Verses 29-32[/link] and [link]42-52[/link] in [link]ch. 11[/link], two sections that unveil the Jewish people as an evil generation, confirm this interpretation.

verse.text: And he said to the vinedresser, Behold, for three years I have come seeking fruit on this fig tree, and I have not found [i]any.[/i] [xref]a[/xref]Cut it down therefore. Why does it also [note]1[/note]make the ground useless?
verse.note: I.e., deplete the soil, intercept the sun, and take up room (Bengel).

verse.text: But he answered and said to him, Master, leave it this year also, until I dig around it and throw on manure.
And if it produces fruit in the future, [i]good;[/i] otherwise, cut it down.
And He was teaching in one of the [xref]a[/xref]synagogues on the Sabbath.
And behold, there was a woman who had a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit of infirmity eighteen years, and she was [note]2[/note]bent double and could not stand erect at all.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

Lit., bending together. This signifies a person's being oppressed by a demon to an extreme, so that the person is bent toward the satanic world only and is unable to stand erect to look into the heavens.

verse.text: And Jesus, seeing her, called [i]her[/i] to [i]Him[/i] and said to her, Woman, you are released from your infirmity.
And He [xref]a[/xref]laid His hands on her, and instantly she was made erect and began to [xref]b[/xref]glorify God.

But the [xref]a[/xref]ruler of the synagogue, being [note]1[/note]indignant because Jesus had healed on the Sabbath, answered and said to the crowd, There are [xref]b[/xref]six days in which [i]man[/i] should work; therefore, come on them and be healed, and [xref]c[/xref]not on the Sabbath day.
verse.note: Satan used not only the evil spirit to possess the woman but also the religious ruler to oppose her being released by the Lord. Religion is much used by the usurper to keep God's chosen people under his oppression.

verse.text: But the Lord answered him and said, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hypocrites! Does not each of you on the [xref]b[/xref]Sabbath untie his ox or his donkey from the manger and lead [i]it[/i] away and water [i]it?[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].

verse.text: And this woman, being a [note]1[/note]daughter of [xref]a[/xref]Abraham whom [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Satan has bound, behold, for eighteen years, should she not have been released from this bond on the [note]3[/note]Sabbath day?
verse.note: One of God's chosen people.
The demon's possessing of people is Satan's binding of them. Hence, the casting out of a demon is the defeat of Satan ([link]Matt. 12:29[/link] and note 4).
The Sabbath was ordained by God so that man could rest ([link]Gen. 2:3[/link]), not so that man would remain under bondage.

verse.text: And when He said these things, all those opposing Him were put to [xref]a[/xref]shame, and all the crowd rejoiced over all the [xref]b[/xref]glorious things that were being done by Him.
[note]1[/note]He said therefore, What is the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God like, and to what shall I liken it?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 18-21[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 13:31-33[/link].

verse.text: It is like a [xref]a[/xref]mustard seed, which a man took and threw into his own garden, and it grew and became a tree, and the birds of heaven roosted in its branches.
And again He said, To what shall I liken the kingdom of God?
It is like [xref]a[/xref]leaven, which a woman took and hid in [xref]b[/xref]three measures of meal until the [xref]c[/xref]whole was leavened.
And He journeyed throughout the cities and [xref]a[/xref]villages, teaching and making His way toward [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem.
And someone said to Him, Lord, are there [i]only[/i] a few who are being [xref]a[/xref]saved?
And He said to them, [xref]a[/xref]Struggle to enter through the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]narrow door, because many, I tell you, will seek to enter, yet will not be [note]2[/note]able.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 7[/link].
Or, strong enough.

verse.text: Once the Master of the house has risen and [xref]a[/xref]shuts the door, and you begin to stand outside and knock on the door, saying, [xref]b[/xref]Lord, open to us, then He will answer and say to you, I do not know you, [i]nor[/i] where you are from.
Then you will begin to say, We [xref]a[/xref]ate in Your presence and drank, and You taught in our streets.
And He will say, I tell you, I do not know where you are from. [xref]a[/xref]Go away from Me, all [i]you[/i] workers of unrighteousness.

There will be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]weeping and gnashing of teeth there when you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the [note]2[/note]kingdom of God, but you being cast [xref]b[/xref]outside.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 8[/link].

See note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]. The Jews asked about salvation ([link]v. 23[/link]). But the Lord answered concerning participation in the kingdom of God in the millennium (see note [link]11[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 8[/link]), which will be the most enjoyable part of God's full salvation before the enjoyment of the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth ([link]Rev. 21:1-3a[/link], [link]5-7[/link]; [link]22:1-5[/link]).

verse.text: And they will come from the east and the west, and from the north and the south, and will recline [i]at table[/i] in the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God.
And behold, there are [i]some[/i] [note]1[/note]last who will be first, and there are [i]some[/i] [note]2[/note]first who will be last.
verse.note: Referring to the saved Gentiles, who will receive the Savior before some of the saved Jews and will participate in the kingdom of God in the millennium ([link]v. 29[/link]).

Referring to the Jews who will believe in the Lord after the Gentiles believe ([link]Rom. 11:25-26[/link]). The word in this verse is applied in another sense in [link]Matt. 19:30[/link]; [link]20:16[/link]; and [link]Mark 10:31[/link] (see note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 20[/link]).

verse.text: In the same hour some [xref]a[/xref]Pharisees came up, saying to Him, Get out and go from here, for [xref]b[/xref]Herod wants to [note]1[/note]kill you.
verse.note: This was a threat made by the opposers.

verse.text: And He said to them, Go and tell that fox, Behold, I cast out demons and accomplish healings [note]1[/note]today and tomorrow, and on the [xref]a[/xref]third day I [note]2[/note]am [xref]b[/xref]perfected.
verse.note: This indicates that the Lord had a set schedule to carry out His ministry, to end His course, and to reach His goal through His death and resurrection, and that no one, not even Herod, could prevent Him from accomplishing it.
Or, end My course, reach My goal.

verse.text: However, I [note]1[/note]must journey today and tomorrow and on the following day because it is not acceptable for a [xref]a[/xref]prophet to perish outside of [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem.
verse.note: The threat ([link]v. 31[/link]) did not prevent the Lord from journeying to Jerusalem to accomplish His redemptive death. Rather, He was bold to proceed there ([link]Mark 10:33[/link]) to reach the goal of His entire ministry.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who [note]1[/note]kills the prophets and [xref]b[/xref]stones those who are sent to her! How often I desired to [xref]c[/xref]gather your children together, the way a hen [i]gathers[/i] her own brood under her [xref]d[/xref]wings, and you [xref]e[/xref]would not!
verse.note: For [link]vv. 34-35[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 23:37-39[/link].

verse.text: Behold, your [note]1[/note]house is left to you. And I say to you, You shall by no means see Me until [i]the time[/i] comes when you say, [xref]a[/xref]Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord!
verse.note: This house (singular in Greek) was God's house, God's temple. Because the Jews rejected the Lord, that is, God's coming in the Son, the Lord rejected the temple, considering it the house of the Jews themselves and leaving it to them that it might suffer the coming destruction and become desolate.

verse.text: And as He went into the house of one of the rulers of the Pharisees on a Sabbath to [xref]a[/xref]eat bread, they were [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]watching Him closely.
verse.note: With an evil intention to accuse Him ([link]Mark 3:2[/link]).

verse.text: And behold, there was before Him a certain man suffering from [note]1[/note]dropsy.
verse.note: A disease that causes the body to swell because of the forming of fluid in the cavities and tissues. This signifies the abnormal inner function of life that causes spiritual death before God.

verse.text: And Jesus answered and spoke to the [xref]a[/xref]lawyers and Pharisees, saying, Is it lawful to heal on the [xref]b[/xref]Sabbath or not?
But they were quiet. And He took hold of [i]him[/i] and healed him and sent [i]him[/i] away.
And He said to them, Which of you [i]having[/i] a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]donkey or an ox [i]that[/i] falls into a well will not immediately pull it out on the Sabbath day?
verse.note: Some MSS read, son.

verse.text: And they were [xref]a[/xref]not able to reply to these things.
And He told a parable to those who had been invited, when He noticed how they were choosing the [xref]a[/xref]places of honor, saying to them,
When you are invited by anyone to a wedding feast, do not recline in the place of honor, lest someone more honorable than you may have been invited by him,
And he who invited you and him come and say to you, Give this one [i]that[/i] place; and then you begin with shame to occupy the last place.

But when you are invited, go and recline in the last place, so that when the one who has invited you comes, he may say to you, Friend, [xref]a[/xref]come up higher. Then you will have glory before all those reclining with you.
For everyone who exalts himself shall be [xref]a[/xref]humbled, and he who [xref]b[/xref]humbles himself shall be exalted.

And He said also to the one who had invited Him, When you make a morning meal or a dinner, do not call your friends or your brothers or your relatives or rich neighbors, lest they also invite you in return and it become a [xref]a[/xref]repayment to you.
But when you give a reception, invite the [note]1[/note]poor, the crippled, the lame, the blind,
verse.note: These are the people whom God invited to His salvation ([link]v. 21[/link]).

verse.text: And you will be blessed, because they do not have [i]anything with which[/i] to repay you; for it will be repaid to you in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]resurrection of the righteous.
verse.note: This refers to the resurrection of life ([link]John 5:29[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4-6[/link]), at which time God will reward the saints ([link]Rev. 11:18[/link]) at the Lord's coming back ([link]1 Cor. 4:5[/link]).

verse.text: And one of those reclining [i]at table[/i] with [i]Him,[/i] hearing these things, said to Him, [xref]a[/xref]Blessed is he who shall eat bread in the [xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God.
And He said to him, A certain man was making a [note]1[/note]great dinner and invited many;
verse.note: This great dinner is different from the wedding feast in [link]Matt. 22:2-14[/link], which was for the reward of the kingdom. This great dinner is for God's full salvation. God, as the "certain man," prepared His full salvation as a great dinner and sent the first apostles as His slaves to invite the Jews ([link]vv. 16-17[/link]). But because they were occupied by their riches, such as land, cattle, or a wife, they refused His invitation ([link]vv. 18-20[/link]). Then God sent the apostles to invite the people on the streets — the poor, the crippled, the blind, and the lame. Because of their poverty and misery, they accepted God's invitation ([link]vv. 21-22a[/link]). Yet God's salvation still had room for more; so He sent His slaves to go out farther, to the Gentile world, signified by the roads and hedges, to compel the Gentiles to come in and fill up the house of His salvation ([link]vv. 22b-23[/link]; [link]Acts 13:46-48[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:25[/link]).

verse.text: And he sent his slave at the dinner hour to say to those who had been invited, Come, for all things are now ready.
And they all with one consent began to make excuses. The first said to him, I have bought a piece of land, and I need to go out and see it. I ask you, have me excused.
And another said, I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I am going to prove them. I ask you, have me excused.
And another said, I have [xref]a[/xref]married a wife, and because of this I cannot come.

And the slave came up and reported these things to his master. Then the master of the house became angry and told his slave, Go out quickly into the streets and lanes of the city, and bring in here the [xref]a[/xref]poor and crippled and blind and lame.
And the slave said, Master, what you commanded has been done, and still there is room.
And the master said to the slave, Go out into the roads and hedges and compel [i]them[/i] to come in, so that my house may be filled.
For I tell you that none of those men who were invited shall taste of my dinner.
And there were great crowds going along with Him, and He turned and said to them,

[note]1[/note]If anyone [xref]a[/xref]comes to Me and does not hate his own father and mother and wife and children and brothers and sisters, and moreover, even his own [xref]b[/xref]soul-life, he cannot be My disciple.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 26-33[/link] the Lord unveiled to the crowds who went along with Him ([link]v. 25[/link]) the cost of following Him. To receive salvation is to be saved ([link]13:23[/link]); to follow the Lord is to enjoy Him as the blessing of God's salvation. This requires us to renounce all, even our life, and to carry our own cross ([link]vv. 26-27[/link], [link]33[/link]).

verse.text: Whoever does not carry his own [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cross and come after Me cannot be My disciple.
verse.note: The aim of the cross is not suffering but the termination of the person. The believers in Christ have been crucified (terminated) with Him ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:6[/link]). After being organically united with Him through faith, they should remain on the cross, keeping their old man under the termination of the cross (cf. [link]Rom. 6:3[/link]; [link]Col. 2:20-21[/link]). This is to carry their own cross. Christ first carried the cross and then was crucified ([link]John 19:17-18[/link]). But the believers in Him are first crucified and then carry the cross that they may remain in the termination of their old man, thus experiencing and enjoying Christ as their life and life supply.

verse.text: For which of you, wanting to build a tower, does not first sit down and calculate the cost, whether he has [note]1[/note][i]enough[/i] to complete [i]it?[/i]
verse.note: The Lord's word here and that in [link]v. 31[/link] indicate that to make a career of following the Lord, we must give to it all we have and all we can do; otherwise, we will be a failure, becoming the tasteless salt and being thrown out of the glorious realm into a sphere of shame ([link]vv. 34-35[/link]).

verse.text: Lest perhaps, once he has laid a foundation and is not able to finish, all those looking on will begin to mock him,
Saying, This man began to build and was not able to finish.
Or what king, going to engage another king in war, will not first sit down and deliberate whether he is able with ten thousand to meet the one coming against him with twenty thousand?
Otherwise, while he is yet at a distance, he sends an envoy and asks for the [i]terms[/i] of peace.
In the same way therefore everyone of you who does not [xref]a[/xref]forsake all his own possessions cannot be My disciple.
[note]1[/note]Therefore [note]2[/note]salt is good; but if even the salt becomes tasteless, with what will its saltiness be restored?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 34-35[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 5:13[/link] and note [link]50[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 9[/link].

The believers in Christ are the salt of the earth used by God to kill and eliminate the earth's corruption. Their taste depends on their renouncing of earthly things. The more they renounce the things of earth, the more powerful will be their taste. They will lose their taste by not being willing to renounce all the things of the present life. If this happens, they will be fit neither for the land, signifying the church as God's farm ([link]1 Cor. 3:9[/link]), which issues in the coming kingdom ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]), nor for the manure pile, signifying hell, the filthy place in the universe ([link]Rev. 21:8[/link]; [link]22:15[/link]). They will be thrown out from the kingdom of God, especially from the glory of the kingdom in the millennium (see note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 8[/link]). They are saved from eternal perdition, but because they have failed to renounce the earthly things, they lose their function in the kingdom of God, thus being unfit for the coming kingdom and needing to be put aside for discipline (see note [link]32[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link]).

verse.text: It is fit neither for the land nor for the manure pile; they will throw it [xref]a[/xref]out. He who has ears to hear, let him [xref]b[/xref]hear.
Now all the [xref]a[/xref]tax collectors and sinners were drawing near to Him to hear Him.
And both the Pharisees and the [xref]a[/xref]scribes [xref]b[/xref]murmured among [i]themselves,[/i] saying, This man welcomes [xref]c[/xref]sinners and [xref]d[/xref]eats with them.
And He told them this [note]1[/note]parable, saying,
verse.note: In answering the self-righteous Pharisees and scribes, who condemned Him for eating with sinners, the Savior spoke three parables, unveiling and depicting how the Divine Trinity works to bring sinners back, through the Son by the Spirit, to the Father. The Son came in His humanity as the Shepherd to find the sinner as a lost sheep and bring him back home ([link]vv. 4-7[/link]). The Spirit seeks the sinner as a woman carefully seeks a lost coin until she finds it ([link]vv. 8-10[/link]). And the Father receives the repenting and returned sinner as the "certain man" here receives his prodigal son ([link]vv. 11-32[/link]). The entire Divine Trinity treasures the sinner and participates in bringing him back to God. All three parables stress the love of the Divine Trinity more than the fallen condition and repentance of the penitent sinner. The divine love is fully expressed in the Son's tender care as the good shepherd, in the Spirit's fine seeking as the treasure-lover, and in the Father's warm receiving as a loving father.

verse.text: Which man of you, who has a [xref]a[/xref]hundred sheep and has lost one of them, does not leave the ninety-nine in the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]wilderness and go after the one which is [xref]c[/xref]lost until he [xref]d[/xref]finds it?
verse.note: Signifying the world. This indicates that the Son has come to the world to be with men ([link]John 1:14[/link]).

verse.text: And when he finds [i]it,[/i] he [note]1[/note]lays [i]it[/i] on his [xref]a[/xref]shoulders, rejoicing.
verse.note: This shows the Savior's saving strength and His saving love.

verse.text: And when he comes into his house, he calls together his friends and his neighbors, saying to them, Rejoice with me, for I have found my sheep that was [xref]a[/xref]lost.
I tell you that in the same way there will be [i]more[/i] joy in heaven over one [xref]a[/xref]sinner repenting than over ninety-nine [xref]b[/xref]righteous persons who have no need of repentance.

Or what woman having ten [note]1[/note]silver coins, if she loses one silver coin, does not light a [note]2[/note]lamp and [note]3[/note]sweep the house and [note]4[/note]seek carefully until she finds [i]it?[/i]
verse.note: One silver coin was equivalent to a day's wages (so in [link]v. 9[/link]).
Signifying the word of God ([link]Psa. 119:105[/link], [link]130[/link]), which is used by the Spirit to illuminate and expose the sinner's position and condition that he may repent.
To search and cleanse the sinner's inward parts.

In [link]v. 4[/link] the Son's finding took place outside the sinner and was completed at the cross through His redemptive death; here the Spirit's seeking is inward and is carried out by His working within the repenting sinner.

verse.text: And when she finds [i]it,[/i] she calls together her friends and neighbors, saying, Rejoice with me, for I have found the coin which I lost.
In the same way, I tell you, there is joy in the presence of the [xref]a[/xref]angels of God over one sinner repenting.
And He said, A certain man had two sons.
And the younger of them said to the father, Father, give me the [note]1[/note]share of the estate that falls to [i]me.[/i] And he [xref]a[/xref]distributed to them his [note]2[/note]living.
verse.note: Referring to the inheritance that was his by birth.

[i]His living[/i] refers to the father's means of support, the father's livelihood, substance ([link]v. 30[/link]). The Greek word for [i]living[/i] means [i]life,[/i] i.e., the present state of existence, as in [link]8:14[/link], and, by implication, livelihood, as here and in [link]Mark 12:44[/link].

verse.text: And not many days after, the younger son, having gathered everything together, went abroad to a [note]1[/note]distant country and there squandered his estate by living [note]2[/note]dissolutely.
verse.note: Signifying the satanic world.
Lit., unsavingly; indicating a debauched, profligate living.

verse.text: And when he had spent all, a severe famine occurred throughout that country, and he began to be in want.
And he went and joined himself to one of the citizens of that country; and he sent him into his fields to [note]1[/note]feed hogs.
verse.note: Hogs are unclean ([link]Lev. 11:7[/link]). Feeding hogs is a dirty job; it signifies the unclean business in the satanic world.

verse.text: And he longed to be [xref]a[/xref]satisfied with the [note]1[/note]carob pods which the hogs were eating, and no one gave him [i]anything.[/i]
verse.note: The carob is an evergreen tree. Its pod, also called the carob bean, was used as fodder to feed animals and destitute persons. An interesting rabbinical saying is that "when the Israelites are reduced to carob pods, then they repent." A tradition says that John the Baptist fed on carob pods in the wilderness; hence, they are called "St. John's bread."

verse.text: But when he [xref]a[/xref]came to himself, he said, [note]1[/note]How many of my father's hired servants abound in bread, but I am perishing here in famine!
verse.note: This was due to the enlightening and searching of the Spirit ([link]v. 8[/link]) within him.

verse.text: I will [note]1[/note]rise up and go [xref]a[/xref]to my father, and I will say to him, Father, [note]2[/note]I have sinned against [xref]b[/xref]heaven and [xref]c[/xref]before you.
verse.note: This is the result of the Spirit's seeking in [link]v. 8[/link].
The Lord's parable here implies that when a sinner sins, he sins against heaven and before God the Father, who is in heaven.

verse.text: I am [note]1[/note]no longer worthy to be called your son; make me like one of your [note]2[/note]hired servants.
verse.note: The prodigal son did not know the father's love.

Once he has repented, a fallen sinner always thinks of working for God or of serving God to obtain His favor, not knowing that this thought is against God's love and grace and is an insult to His heart and intent.

verse.text: And he rose up and came to his own father. But while he was still a [xref]a[/xref]long way off, his father [note]1[/note]saw him and was moved with compassion, and he [note]2[/note]ran and [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]fell on his neck and kissed him affectionately.
verse.note: This did not happen by chance; the father went out of the house to look for the prodigal's return.
God the Father ran to receive the returning sinner. What eagerness this shows!

A warm and loving reception. The prodigal son's return to the Father was due to the Spirit's seeking ([link]v. 8[/link]); the Father's receiving of the returned son was based on the Son's finding in His redemption ([link]v. 4[/link]).

verse.text: And the son said to him, Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you; I am no longer worthy to be called your son.

[note]1[/note]But the father said to his slaves, Bring out [note]2[/note]quickly [note]3[/note]the [note]4[/note]best [note]5[/note]robe and put [i]it[/i] on him, and put a [note]6[/note]ring on his hand and [note]7[/note]sandals on his feet.
verse.note: "But"! What a word of love and grace! It countered the prodigal's own thinking and stopped his nonsensical talk.
To match the father's running ([link]v. 20[/link]).
[i]The[/i] indicates a particular robe prepared for this particular purpose at this particular time.
Lit., first.

Signifying Christ the Son as the God-satisfying righteousness to cover the penitent sinner ([link]Jer. 23:6[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; cf. [link]Isa. 61:10[/link]; [link]Zech. 3:4[/link]). The best robe, which was also the first robe, replaced the rags ([link]Isa. 64:6[/link]) of the returned prodigal.
Signifying the sealing Spirit as the God-given seal upon the accepted believer ([link]Eph. 1:13[/link]; cf. [link]Gen. 24:47[/link]; [link]41:42[/link]).

Signifying the power of God's salvation to separate the believers from the dirty earth. Both the ring and the sandals were signs of a free man. The adornment, consisting of the robe on the body, the ring on the hand, and the sandals on the feet, allowed the poor prodigal to match his rich father and qualified him to enter the father's house and feast with the father. God's salvation adorns us with Christ and the Spirit that we may enjoy the riches in His house.

verse.text: And bring the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fattened calf; [note]2[/note]slaughter [i]it,[/i] and let us eat and be merry,
verse.note: Signifying the rich Christ ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]), killed on the cross for the believer's enjoyment. God's salvation has two aspects: the outward, objective aspect, signified by the best robe, and the inward, subjective aspect, signified by the fattened calf. Christ as our righteousness is our salvation outwardly; Christ as our life for our enjoyment is our salvation inwardly. The best robe enabled the prodigal son to meet his father's requirements and satisfy his father, and the fattened calf satisfied the son's hunger. Hence, the father and the son could be merry together.
Or, sacrifice (so in [link]vv. 27[/link], [link]30[/link]).

verse.text: Because this son of mine was [note]1[/note]dead and [xref]a[/xref]lives again; he was [note]1[/note]lost and has been found. And they began to be merry.
verse.note: All lost sinners are dead in the eyes of God ([link]Eph. 2:1[/link], [link]5[/link]). When they are saved, they are made alive ([link]John 5:24-25[/link]; [link]Col. 2:13[/link]).

verse.text: Now his [note]1[/note]older son was in the field. And as he came and drew near to the house, he heard music and dancing,
verse.note: Signifying the Pharisees and scribes ([link]v. 2[/link]) and representing the unbelieving Jews, who pursue the law of righteousness ([link]Rom. 9:31-32[/link]) by their work, signified by [i]in the field.[/i]

verse.text: And calling to [i]him[/i] one of the servants, he inquired what these things might be.
And he said to him, Your brother has come, and your father has slaughtered the fattened calf because he has received him back healthy.
But he became angry and was not willing to enter. And his father came out and entreated him.

But he answered and said to his father, Behold, so many years I have been [note]1[/note]slaving for you and have never [note]2[/note]neglected a command of yours, and you have never given me a goat that I might be merry with my friends;
verse.note: Signifying slavery under the law ([link]Gal. 5:1[/link]).
Or, transgressed.

verse.text: But when this son of yours came, who devoured your [note]1[/note]living with [xref]a[/xref]harlots, you slaughtered for him the fattened calf.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And he said to him, Child, you are always with me, and all that is mine is yours.
But we had to be merry and rejoice, because this brother of yours was [note]1[/note]dead and has come to life, and he was lost and has been found.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He said also to the disciples, There was a certain rich man who had a [note]2[/note]steward, and this one was accused to him of squandering his possessions.
verse.note: Indicating continuation. In the preceding chapter the Lord spoke three parables concerning a sinner's salvation. In this chapter He continued with one more parable, this one concerning the believer's service. After a sinner becomes a believer, he needs to serve the Lord as a prudent steward.

Illustrating how the believers, saved by the love and grace of the Triune God, are the Lord's stewards ([link]12:42[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 4:1-2[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 4:10[/link]), to whom the Lord has committed His possessions.

verse.text: And he called him and said to him, What is this I hear concerning you? Render the account of your stewardship, for you can no longer be steward.
And the steward said within himself, What shall I do, because my master is taking the stewardship away from me? I am not strong enough to [note]1[/note]dig; I am ashamed to [note]2[/note]beg.
verse.note: As a farmer, who digs in the field.
As a beggar, who begs for help.

verse.text: I know what I will do so that when I am removed from the stewardship they may [note]1[/note]receive me into their own houses.
verse.note: Signifying being received into the eternal tabernacles ([link]v. 9[/link]).

verse.text: And when he had called to [i]him[/i] each one of his master's debtors, he said to the first, How much do you owe my master?
And he said, A hundred [note]1[/note]measures of oil. And he said to him, Take your bill and sit down quickly and write fifty.
verse.note: Among the Hebrews, a liquid measure of between eight and nine gallons.

verse.text: Then to another he said, And you, how much do you owe? And he said, A hundred [note]1[/note]measures of wheat. He said to him, Take your bill and write eighty.
verse.note: A dry measure of between ten and twelve bushels.

verse.text: And the master praised the [xref]a[/xref]unrighteous steward because he had acted [note]1[/note]prudently; for the [note]2[/note]sons of [xref]b[/xref]this age are more [xref]c[/xref]prudent [i]in their dealings[/i] with their own generation than the [note]3[/note]sons of [xref]d[/xref]light.
verse.note: The praise is not for the steward's unrighteous act but for his prudence.
The unsaved ones, the worldlings.
The saved ones, the believers ([link]John 12:36[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 5:5[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:8[/link]).

verse.text: And I say to you, [note]1[/note]Make friends for yourselves by means of the mammon of [note]2[/note]unrighteousness, so that when it [note]3[/note]fails, they may receive you into the [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]eternal tabernacles.
verse.note: To use money to do things to help others according to God's leading.

Mammon, i.e., money, is of the satanic world. It is unrighteous in its position and existence. The steward in the parable exercised his prudence by his unrighteous act. The Lord teaches us, His believers, to exercise our prudence in the use of unrighteous mammon.
After the satanic world is over, mammon will be of no use in the kingdom of God.

I.e., eternal habitations. The prudent believers will be received into the eternal habitations by those who shared the benefit of their prudence. This will be fulfilled in the coming kingdom age (cf. [link]14:13-14[/link]; [link]Matt. 10:42[/link]).

verse.text: He who is [xref]a[/xref]faithful in the [note]1[/note]least is faithful also in [note]1[/note]much; and he who is unrighteous in the least is unrighteous also in much.
verse.note: [i]Least[/i] refers to mammon, the possessions of this age; [i]much[/i] refers to the rich possessions in the next age (cf. [link]Matt. 25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]).

verse.text: If therefore you have not become faithful in the unrighteous mammon, who will entrust to you what is [note]1[/note]true?
verse.note: Referring to the true possessions in the coming kingdom age (cf. [link]Matt. 24:47[/link]).

verse.text: And if you have not become faithful in that which belongs to [note]1[/note]another, who will give to you that which is [note]2[/note]your own?
verse.note: In His New Testament economy God does not intend that the New Testament believers care for material possessions. Though the material things of this world were created by God and belong to Him ([link]1 Chron. 29:14[/link], [link]16[/link]), they have been corrupted by man's fall ([link]Rom. 8:20-21[/link]) and usurped by Satan, the evil one ([link]1 John 5:19[/link]); hence, they belong to fallen man and are unrighteous ([link]v. 9[/link]). While God does supply the believers with their daily necessities from the material things of this age ([link]Matt. 6:31-33[/link]) and commits to them as His stewards a portion of these material goods for their exercise and learning that He might prove them in this age, none of these goods should be considered theirs until the restitution of all things in the next age ([link]Acts 3:21[/link]). Not until then will the believers inherit the world ([link]Rom. 4:13[/link]) and have an abiding possession ([link]Heb. 10:34[/link]) for themselves. In this age they should exercise to be faithful in the temporary material things God has given them that they may learn to be faithful toward their eternal possession in the coming age.
Some MSS read, our own.

verse.text: No household servant can [note]1[/note]serve [xref]a[/xref]two masters; for either he will hate the one and [note]2[/note]love the other, or he will [note]2[/note]hold to one and despise the other. You cannot [note]1[/note]serve God and [note]3[/note]mammon.
verse.note: Lit., Serve as a slave.

In Greek, [i]hold to one[/i] means [i]cleave to the one as against the other.[/i] This indicates that to serve the Lord requires us to love Him, giving our heart to Him, and cleave to Him, giving our entire being to Him. Thus we are released from being occupied and usurped by mammon, that we may serve the Lord wholly and fully. The Lord emphasizes here that to serve Him we must overcome the enticing, deceitful mammon of unrighteousness.
See note [link]24[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]Pharisees, being [xref]b[/xref]lovers of money, heard all these things and [note]1[/note]were [xref]c[/xref]sneering at Him.
verse.note: Lit., were turning up the nose.

verse.text: And He said to them, You are those who [xref]a[/xref]justify yourselves in the [xref]b[/xref]sight of men, but God knows your [xref]c[/xref]hearts; for that which is exalted among men is an [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]abomination in the sight of God.
verse.note: The self-justifying of the Pharisees was a prideful exalting of self; hence, it was an abomination in the sight of God.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]law and the prophets were [note]2[/note]until John; from that time the [note]3[/note]kingdom of God is proclaimed as the [note]4[/note]gospel, and everyone [note]5[/note][xref]a[/xref]forces his way into it.
verse.note: [i]The law and the prophets[/i] refers to the Old Testament.
Indicating the change of dispensation from the law to the gospel. See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].
See note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

To the Pharisees, the money lovers, the Savior preached the kingdom of God as the gospel ([link]v. 14[/link]). Money and sexual lust, which is incited by money, held them back from entering into the kingdom of God. Hence, the Savior's preaching hit these two things purposely and strongly in [link]vv. 18-31[/link].

For the Pharisees to force their way into the kingdom of God, they needed to humble themselves (cf. [link]v. 15[/link]) and to divorce their money (cf. [link]v. 14[/link]), not their wives (cf. [link]v. 18[/link]), that is, to overcome money and lust, which is incited by money.

verse.text: But it is easier for heaven and earth to [xref]a[/xref]pass away than for one [note]1[/note]serif of the law to [note]2[/note]fail.
verse.note: The minute, horn-like projection that distinguishes various Hebrew letters.
Or, fall.

verse.text: Everyone who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery, and he who marries a woman who is divorced from [i]her[/i] husband commits [xref]b[/xref]adultery.
verse.note: Lit., releases.

verse.text: Now there was [note]1[/note]a certain rich man, and he clothed himself in [xref]a[/xref]purple and fine linen, making merry every day in splendor.
verse.note: This is not a parable, because it mentions names such as Abraham, Lazarus, and Hades. It is a story used by the Savior as an illustrative answer to the money-loving and self-justifying Pharisees ([link]vv. 14-15[/link]); it is a warning to them, unveiling that their future will be miserable, like that of the rich man, as a result of their rejecting of the Savior's gospel because of their love for money.

verse.text: And a certain beggar named Lazarus was laid at his gate, covered with sores
And longing to be [xref]a[/xref]satisfied with the things falling from the rich man's [xref]b[/xref]table; moreover, even the dogs came and licked his sores.
And the beggar died, and he was carried away by the [xref]a[/xref]angels into [note]1[/note]Abraham's [xref]b[/xref]bosom; and the rich man also died and was buried.
verse.note: A rabbinical phrase, equivalent to being with Abraham in Paradise. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Cor. 12[/link].

verse.text: And in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hades he lifted up his eyes, being in [xref]b[/xref]torment, and saw Abraham from afar and Lazarus in his bosom.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].

verse.text: And he called out and said, [xref]a[/xref]Father Abraham, have mercy on me and send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my [xref]b[/xref]tongue, because I am in anguish in this [xref]c[/xref]flame.
But Abraham said, Child, remember that in your lifetime you fully received your good things, and Lazarus likewise bad things; but now he is comforted here, and you are in anguish.
And besides all these things, between us and you a great [note]1[/note]chasm is fixed, so that those wanting to pass from here to you cannot, neither from there to us may [i]any[/i] cross over.
verse.note: A gulf that divides Hades into two sections: the pleasant section, where Abraham, Lazarus, and all the saved saints are ([link]v. 22[/link]), and the section of torment, where the rich man and all the perished sinners are ([link]vv. 23a[/link], [link]28[/link]). The two sections are cut off from each other and have no bridge between them for passage. Yet those in the two sections can see and even talk to one another ([link]vv. 23-25[/link]).

verse.text: And he said, Then I ask you, Father, to send him to the house of my father —
For I have five brothers — so that he may solemnly testify to them, lest they also come to this place of torment.
But Abraham said, They have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Moses and the prophets; let them hear them.
verse.note: Referring to the law of Moses and the books of the prophets (cf. [link]v. 16[/link]), which are the word of God ([link]Matt. 4:4[/link]). Whether one hears the word of God or not determines whether one is saved or perishes. The poor man was saved not because he was poor but because he heard the word of God ([link]John 5:24[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:13[/link]). The rich man perished not because he was rich but because he rejected the word of God ([link]Acts 13:46[/link]).

verse.text: But he said, No, Father Abraham; but if someone [i]risen[/i] from the dead would go to them, they will repent.
But he said to him, If they do [note]1[/note]not hear Moses and the prophets, neither will they be persuaded if someone rises from the dead.
verse.note: If people do not hear what the word of God says, they will not be persuaded even if someone miraculously rises from the dead. The Savior's word here implied that if the Jews, represented by the Pharisees, did not hear the word of God spoken through Moses and the prophets in the Old Testament, they would not be persuaded even though He would rise from the dead. This very tragedy occurred after His resurrection ([link]Matt. 28:11-15[/link]; [link]Acts 13:30-40[/link], [link]44-45[/link]).

verse.text: And He said to His disciples, It is impossible for causes of [xref]a[/xref]stumbling not to come, but [xref]b[/xref]woe [i]to him[/i] through [xref]c[/xref]whom they come.
It is [i]more[/i] profitable for him if a [xref]a[/xref]millstone is put around his neck and he is hurled into the sea than to stumble one of these little ones.
[xref]a[/xref]Take heed to yourselves. If your brother [xref]b[/xref]sins, [xref]c[/xref]rebuke him; and if he repents, [xref]d[/xref]forgive him.
And if he sins against you [xref]a[/xref]seven times in a day and turns again to you seven times, saying, I repent, you shall forgive him.
And the apostles said to the Lord, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Increase our faith.
verse.note: Or, Add to us faith.

verse.text: But the Lord said, If you have [xref]a[/xref]faith like a [xref]b[/xref]mustard seed, you would have said to this [xref]c[/xref]sycamine tree, Be uprooted and be planted in the sea; and it would have obeyed you.
But which of you, having a slave who is plowing or tending sheep, will say to him when he has come in from the field, Come immediately and recline [i]at table?[/i]
Will he not rather say to him, Prepare something that I may dine, and [xref]a[/xref]gird yourself and serve me until I eat and drink; and after that you will eat and drink?
He does not thank the slave because he did the things which were ordered, does he?
So also you, when you do all the things which are ordered you, say, We are [xref]a[/xref]unprofitable slaves; we have done what we ought to have done.
And as He was going to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem, He passed between [xref]b[/xref]Samaria and [xref]c[/xref]Galilee.
And as He entered into a certain village, ten [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]leprous men, who stood at a distance, met Him.
verse.note: See note [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: And they raised [i]their[/i] voice, saying, Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!
And when He saw [i]them,[/i] He said to them, Go and show yourselves to the [xref]a[/xref]priests. And as they [note]1[/note]went, they were cleansed.
verse.note: This was their believing and obeying. Hence, they were cleansed.

verse.text: And one of them, when he saw that he was healed, returned, [xref]a[/xref]glorifying God with a loud voice;
And he [xref]a[/xref]fell on [i]his[/i] face at His feet, thanking Him. And he was a [xref]b[/xref]Samaritan.
And Jesus answered and said, Were not the ten cleansed? But the nine, where [i]are they?[/i]
Were none found who returned to [xref]a[/xref]give glory to God except this foreigner?
And He said to him, Rise up and go; your [xref]a[/xref]faith has [note]1[/note]healed you.
verse.note: Lit., saved.

verse.text: And when He was questioned by the [xref]a[/xref]Pharisees [i]as to[/i] [xref]b[/xref]when the kingdom of God was coming, He answered them and said, The [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]kingdom of God does [note]2[/note]not come with observation;
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

Indicating that the kingdom of God is not material but spiritual. It is the Savior in His first coming ([link]vv. 21-22[/link]), in His second coming ([link]vv. 23-30[/link]), in the rapture of His overcoming believers ([link]vv. 31-36[/link]), and in His destroying of the Antichrist ([link]v. 37[/link]) to recover the whole earth for His reign there ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]).

verse.text: Nor will they say, Behold, [xref]a[/xref]here [i]it is![/i] or, There! For behold, the [note]1[/note]kingdom of God is in the midst of [note]2[/note]you.
verse.note: [link]Verses 22-24[/link] prove that the kingdom of God is the Savior Himself, who was among the Pharisees when He was questioned by them. Wherever the Savior is, there the kingdom of God is. The kingdom of God is with Him, and He brings it to His disciples ([link]v. 22[/link]). He is the seed of the kingdom of God to be sown into God's chosen people to develop into God's ruling realm (see note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]). Since His resurrection He has been within His believers ([link]John 14:20[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:10[/link]). Hence, the kingdom of God is within the church today ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]).
Referring to the questioning Pharisees ([link]v. 20[/link]). The Savior as the kingdom of God was not within them but only in the midst of them.

verse.text: And He said to the disciples, The [xref]a[/xref]days will come when you will long to see one of the [xref]b[/xref]days of the Son of Man, and you will [note]1[/note]not see [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: This indicates the Savior's absence. During His absence, the world, having rejected Him, will be an evil generation, living in the indulgence of lust ([link]vv. 23-30[/link]), and an opponent of His followers, persecuting them because of their testimony concerning Him ([link]18:1-8[/link]). Hence, His followers need to overcome the stupefying effect of the world's indulgent living by losing their soul-life in this age ([link]vv. 31-33[/link]). Also, they need to deal with the world's persecution by being long-suffering and praying persistently in faith ([link]18:7-8[/link]), that they may be raptured as overcomers and enter into the enjoyment of the kingdom of God at the Savior's coming back ([link]vv. 34-37[/link]).

verse.text: And they will say to you, Behold, there! Behold, here! Do not go away, nor run after [i]them.[/i]
For just as [note]1[/note]lightning flashing from [i]one end[/i] [note]2[/note]of heaven shines to the [i]other end[/i] [note]2[/note]of heaven, so will the Son of Man be in His [xref]a[/xref]day.
verse.note: See note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link].
Lit., under.

verse.text: But first He must suffer many things and be [xref]a[/xref]rejected by this generation.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]And even as it happened in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]days of Noah, so will it be also in the [xref]c[/xref]days of the Son of Man:
verse.note: For [link]vv. 26-27[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:37-39[/link].

The conditions of evil living that stupefied the generation of Noah before the deluge and the generation of Lot before the destruction of Sodom portray the perilous condition of man's living before the Lord's parousia (presence, coming) and the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:3[/link], [link]21[/link]). To participate in the overcomers' rapture that we may enjoy the Lord's parousia and escape the great tribulation, we must overcome the stupefying effect of man's living today.

verse.text: They were eating, they were drinking, they were marrying, they were being given in marriage, until the day in which Noah entered into the [xref]a[/xref]ark and the [xref]b[/xref]flood came and destroyed them all.
Likewise, even as it happened in the [xref]a[/xref]days of [xref]b[/xref]Lot: they were eating, they were drinking, they were buying, they were selling, they were planting, they were building;
But on the day in which Lot went out from [xref]a[/xref]Sodom, it rained fire and [xref]b[/xref]brimstone from heaven and destroyed them all.
It will be in the same way on the day in which the Son of Man is [xref]a[/xref]revealed.

In that day, he who will be on the [xref]a[/xref]housetop and his goods in the house, let him [note]1[/note]not come down to take them away; and he who is in the field, likewise, let him not turn back to the things behind.
verse.note: To linger in the earthly and material things will cause us to miss the overcomers' rapture revealed in [link]vv. 34-36[/link].

verse.text: Remember [note]1[/note]Lot's wife.
verse.note: Lot's wife became a pillar of salt because she took a lingering look backward at Sodom, indicating that she loved and treasured the evil world that God was going to judge and utterly destroy. She was rescued from Sodom, but she did not reach the safe place that Lot reached ([link]Gen. 19:15-30[/link]). She did not perish; neither was she fully saved. Like the salt that becomes tasteless ([link]14:34-35[/link] and note [link]34[sup]2[/sup][/link]), she was left in a place of shame. This is a solemn warning to the world-loving believers.

verse.text: Whoever seeks to [note]1[/note]preserve his [xref]a[/xref]soul-life will lose it, and whoever loses [i]it[/i] will preserve it alive.
verse.note: See note [link]39[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link]. Preserving our soul-life is related to lingering in the earthly and material things, as mentioned in [link]v. 31[/link]. We linger in the earthly things because we care for our soul's enjoyment in this age. This will cause us to lose our soul; that is, our soul will suffer the loss of its enjoyment in the coming kingdom age.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I tell you, In that night there will be [xref]a[/xref]two on one bed; the one will be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]taken and the other will be left.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 34-36[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:40-41[/link]. In these verses the rapture of the overcoming believers is revealed. It will occur secretly and unexpectedly, at night for certain believers who are sleeping, and in the daytime for certain sisters grinding at home and certain brothers working in the field. They are chosen because they have overcome the stupefying effect of the age. In [link]14:25-35[/link] the Savior charges us to pay the price, insofar as we are able, that we may follow Him. In [link]16:1-13[/link] He charges us to overcome mammon that we may serve Him prudently as faithful stewards. In [link]vv. 22-37[/link] of this chapter, He charges us to overcome the stupefying effect of self-indulgent living in this age that we may be raptured into the enjoyment of His parousia (presence, coming). All these charges are related to the believers' overcoming in their practical living.
This is the rapture of the overcomers (see note [link]36[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 21[/link]), who do not preserve their soul-life by loving the worldly things of this age ([link]vv. 26-32[/link]).

verse.text: There will be two women [xref]a[/xref]grinding together; the one will be taken but the other will be left.
[note]1[/note]Two men will be in the field; one will be taken and the other will be left.
verse.note: Some MSS omit this verse.

verse.text: And they answered and said to Him, Where, Lord? And He said to them, Where the [note]1[/note]body is, there also will the [xref]a[/xref]vultures be gathered together.
verse.note: I.e., corpse. See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link].

verse.text: And He told them a [xref]a[/xref]parable to the end that they ought always to [xref]b[/xref]pray and [xref]c[/xref]not lose heart,
Saying, There was a certain judge in a certain city who did [xref]a[/xref]not fear God and did not regard man.
And there was a [note]1[/note]widow in that city, and she kept coming to him, saying, [note]2[/note]Avenge me of my [note]3[/note]opponent.
verse.note: In a sense, the believers in Christ are a widow in the present age because their Husband, Christ ([link]2 Cor. 11:2[/link]), is absent from them.
Or, procure justice for.

We believers in Christ have an opponent, Satan the devil, concerning whom we need God's avenging. We ought to pray persistently for this avenging (cf. [link]Rev. 6:9-10[/link]) and should not lose heart.

verse.text: And for a time he would not; but afterward he said within himself, Even though I do not fear God nor regard man,
Yet because this widow causes me trouble, I will avenge her, lest by continually coming she wear me out.
And the Lord said, Hear what the [xref]a[/xref]unrighteous judge says.
And will not God by all means carry out the [xref]a[/xref]avenging of His [xref]b[/xref]chosen ones, who cry to Him [xref]c[/xref]day and night, though He is [xref]d[/xref]long-suffering over them?
I tell you that He will carry out their avenging quickly. Nevertheless, when the Son of Man [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]comes, will He find [note]2[/note]faith on the earth?
verse.note: God's avenging us of our enemy will take place at the Savior's coming back ([link]2 Thes. 2:6-9[/link]).
The persistent faith for our persistent prayer, like the faith of the widow. Hence, it is the subjective faith, not the objective faith.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]He told this parable also to certain ones who [xref]a[/xref]trusted in themselves that they were [xref]b[/xref]righteous and despised the rest:
verse.note: What is covered in [link]vv. 9-30[/link] may be considered the conditions and requirements for entering into the kingdom of God: (1) to humble oneself as a sinner before God, realizing the need of God's propitiation ([link]vv. 9-14[/link]); (2) to be like a little child, without any preoccupying concept ([link]vv. 15-17[/link]); and (3) to follow the Savior by overcoming being occupied by riches and all other material matters ([link]vv. 18-30[/link]).

verse.text: Two men [xref]a[/xref]went up to the temple to pray, the one a [xref]b[/xref]Pharisee and the other a tax collector.

The Pharisee [xref]a[/xref]stood and prayed these things to himself: God, I thank You that I am [note]1[/note]not like the rest of men — extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even like this tax collector.
verse.note: This does not sound like a prayer but like an accusing of others.

verse.text: I [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fast twice a [note]2[/note]week; I [xref]b[/xref]give a tenth of all that I get.
verse.note: This does not sound like a prayer but like an arrogant boast to God. Such boasting is an utterly detestable sin.

The same Greek word as for [i]Sabbath[/i] in [link]Matt. 28:1[/link] and for [i]week[/i] in [link]John 20:1[/link]. This seven-day week is the week of the Sabbath established by the Jews according to [link]Gen. 2[/link].

verse.text: But the tax collector, standing at a distance, would [xref]a[/xref]not even lift up his eyes to heaven, but [xref]b[/xref]beat his breast, saying, God, be [note]1[/note]propitiated to me, the [xref]c[/xref]sinner!
verse.note: The tax collector realized how his sinfulness offended God; hence, he asked God to be propitiated, to be appeased toward him by a propitiatory sacrifice for sins, that God might be merciful and gracious to him (see notes [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 3[/link], [link]17[sup]4[/sup] in Heb. 2[/link], and [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in 1 John 2[/link]).

verse.text: I tell you, This man went down to his house [xref]a[/xref]justified rather than that one; for everyone who exalts himself shall be [xref]b[/xref]humbled, but he who humbles himself shall be exalted.
And they were bringing to Him also their [xref]a[/xref]babies that He might touch them. But when the disciples saw [i]this[/i] they [xref]b[/xref]rebuked them.

But Jesus called them to [i]Him,[/i] saying, Allow the little children to come to Me, and do not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]forbid them, for of such is the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God.
verse.note: Or, prevent, hinder.
See note [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: Truly I say to you, Whoever does not receive the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God like a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]little child shall by no means enter into it.
verse.note: A little child, not filled with and occupied by old concepts, can easily receive a new thought. Hence, people need to be like little children and, with an unoccupied heart, receive the kingdom of God as a new thing.

verse.text: And a [note]1[/note]certain ruler questioned Him, [xref]a[/xref]saying, Good Teacher, [note]2[/note]what shall I do to [xref]b[/xref]inherit [xref]c[/xref]eternal life?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 18-30[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 19:16-29[/link].
See note [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: But Jesus said to him, Why do you call Me good? No one is good except One — God.
You know the commandments: "Do [xref]a[/xref]not commit adultery, do not murder, do not steal, do not bear false witness, [xref]b[/xref]honor your father and mother."
And he said, [xref]a[/xref]All these things I have kept from [i]my[/i] youth.

And hearing [i]this,[/i] Jesus said to him, Still you lack one thing: all that you have, [xref]a[/xref]sell and distribute to the [xref]b[/xref]poor, and you will have treasure in the [xref]c[/xref]heavens; and come, [xref]d[/xref]follow Me.
But when he [xref]a[/xref]heard these things, he became very sorrowful, for he was exceedingly rich.
And Jesus, seeing that he became very sorrowful, said, How difficult it is for those who have [xref]a[/xref]riches to go into the kingdom of God.
For it is easier for a camel to enter through the eye of a [note]1[/note]needle than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.
verse.note: The Greek word here for [i]needle[/i] is different from that in Matthew and Mark. This is the word used by surgeons.

verse.text: And those who heard said, [note]1[/note]Then who can be saved?
verse.note: Lit., And.

verse.text: But He said, The things that are impossible with men are [xref]a[/xref]possible with God.
And Peter said, Behold, we have [xref]a[/xref]left our own things and have [xref]b[/xref]followed You.

And He said to them, Truly I say to you that there is no one who has left house or wife or [xref]a[/xref]brothers or parents or children [note]1[/note]for the sake of the [xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God,
verse.note: [link]Matthew 19:29[/link] has "for My name's sake." This indicates that the Savior is the kingdom of God (see note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link]).

verse.text: Who shall not by all means receive back many times as much in [note]1[/note]this time, and in the [xref]a[/xref]coming age, [xref]b[/xref]eternal life.
verse.note: The present age.

verse.text: And taking the [xref]a[/xref]twelve aside, He said to them, Behold we are [xref]b[/xref]going up to [xref]c[/xref]Jerusalem, and all things which have been written through the prophets regarding the Son of Man will be [xref]d[/xref]accomplished,
For He will be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]delivered up to the Gentiles and will be [xref]b[/xref]mocked and outrageously treated and [xref]c[/xref]spat upon;
verse.note: See notes [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 20[/link] and [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 10[/link].

verse.text: And when they have [xref]a[/xref]scourged [i]Him,[/i] they will kill Him; and on the [xref]b[/xref]third day He will rise.
And they understood none of these things, and this saying was [xref]a[/xref]hidden from them, and they did not know what was being said.
And as He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]drew near to [xref]b[/xref]Jericho, a certain [xref]c[/xref]blind man was sitting by the road, begging.
verse.note: This means that the Savior healed the blind man before He entered Jericho. But according to [link]Matt. 20:29[/link] and [link]Mark 10:46[/link], the healing occurred at His going out from Jericho. Luke's narrative has a spiritual significance. The blind man's receiving of sight was followed in [link book="Luke"]19:1-9[/link] by the salvation of Zaccheus. This indicates that to receive salvation one must first have sight to see the Savior. These two cases, occurring at Jericho one after the other, should be considered, spiritually, as one complete case. A sinner in darkness needs to receive sight that he may realize that he needs salvation ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]).[br][br]What is covered in [link]18:35-19:10[/link] shows how one can fulfill the conditions revealed in [link]vv. 9-30[/link] for entering the kingdom of God — first, one must receive sight from the Savior ([link]vv. 35-43[/link]), and then one must receive the Savior as the dynamic salvation ([link]19:1-10[/link]). In this way the blind man could be like the repenting tax collector and the unoccupied little child and receive the Savior, and Zaccheus could renounce all his riches and follow Him. The way to enter into all spiritual things is to receive sight from the Lord and to receive the Lord Himself.

verse.text: And hearing a crowd going by, he inquired what this might be.
And they told him that Jesus the [xref]a[/xref]Nazarene was passing by.
And he shouted, saying, Jesus, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Son of David, have mercy on me!
verse.note: See note [link]30[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 20[/link].

verse.text: And those going before [xref]a[/xref]rebuked him so that he would be silent, but he cried out much more, Son of David, have mercy on me!
And Jesus, standing still, commanded that he be led to Him. And when he drew near, He questioned him,
[note]1[/note]What do you want Me to [xref]a[/xref]do for you? And he said, Lord, that I may receive my sight!
verse.note: See note [link]51[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 10[/link].

verse.text: And Jesus said to him, Receive your sight; your [xref]a[/xref]faith has [note]1[/note]healed you.
verse.note: Lit., saved.

verse.text: And instantly he received his sight and followed Him, [xref]a[/xref]glorifying God. And all the people, seeing [i]it,[/i] gave [xref]b[/xref]praise to God.
And He entered and was passing through [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Jericho.
verse.note: See note [link]30[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: And behold, [i]there was[/i] a man whose name was called Zaccheus; and he was a chief [note]1[/note]tax collector, and he was rich.
verse.note: See note [link]46[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: And he was seeking to [xref]a[/xref]see Jesus, who He was, and could not because of the crowd, for he was small in stature.
And he ran on ahead and climbed up in a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sycamore tree in order to see Him, for He was about to pass through that way.
verse.note: Or, fig-mulberry. Its leaves are like those of the mulberry, and its fruit like that of the fig tree.

verse.text: And as He came to the place, Jesus looked up and said to him, Zaccheus, hurry and come down, for today I must stay in your house.
And he hurried and came down, and received Him, rejoicing.
And when they saw [i]it,[/i] they all [xref]a[/xref]murmured, saying, He has gone in to lodge with a sinful man.

And Zaccheus stood and said to the Lord, Behold, the [note]1[/note]half of my possessions, Lord, I give to the [xref]a[/xref]poor, and if I have [note]2[/note]taken anything from anyone by false accusation, I restore [note]3[/note]four times as much.
verse.note: Once a sinner receives the Savior, the issue of his dynamic salvation is that he deals with material possessions and clears his past sinful life.

The same Greek word as in [link]3:14[/link]. It is a mild way of saying "extorted." The tax collectors would put an excessive value on property or income, or increase the tax of those unable to pay, and would then practice usury.
This was according to the law's requirements for restoration ([link]Exo. 22:1[/link]; [link]2 Sam. 12:6[/link]).

verse.text: And Jesus said to him, Today [xref]a[/xref]salvation has come to this house, because he [note]1[/note]also is a son of [xref]b[/xref]Abraham.
verse.note: However evil this tax collector was, he nevertheless was a son of Abraham, a chosen heir of God's promised inheritance ([link]Gal. 3:7[/link], [link]29[/link]).

verse.text: For the Son of Man has come to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]seek and to save that which is [xref]b[/xref]lost.
verse.note: This indicates that the Savior's coming to Jericho was not accidental but purposeful; He came to seek this unique lost sinner, just as He sought the sinful woman in Samaria ([link]John 4:4[/link]).

verse.text: And as they were listening to these things, He spoke [note]1[/note]further a parable, because He was near [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem and they supposed that the [xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God was to [note]2[/note]appear immediately.
verse.note: Spiritually, this further parable is a continuation of the preceding case of salvation. It depicts how the saved ones should serve the Lord that they may inherit the coming kingdom.
Or, be shown forth, be made to appear.

verse.text: He said therefore, A [note]1[/note]certain man of noble birth [note]2[/note]went to a distant country to receive for himself a kingdom and to [note]3[/note]return.
verse.note: Signifying the Savior, who is of the highest status — the God-man, both honorable in His deity and noble in His humanity.
Signifying the Savior's going to heaven after His death and resurrection ([link]24:51[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 3:22[/link]).
Signifying the Savior's coming back with the kingdom ([link]Dan. 7:13-14[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:1[/link]).

verse.text: And he called [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ten of his own slaves and gave them ten [note]2[/note]minas, and he said to them, Do business [note]3[/note]until I come.
verse.note: In the parable in [link]Matt. 25:14-30[/link], the slaves are given a varying number of talents according to their individual ability; here the parable emphasizes the common portion given equally to each slave based on the common salvation. However, the point of both parables is the same: the faithfulness of the slaves will determine their portion as their reward in the coming kingdom.
A mina is equal to one hundred drachmas, or one hundred days' wages.
Lit., while I am coming.

verse.text: But his [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]citizens hated him and sent an envoy after him, saying, [note]2[/note]We do not want this man to reign over us.
verse.note: Signifying the unbelieving Jews.
This was fulfilled in [link]Acts 2-9[/link].

verse.text: And when he came back, having received the kingdom, he commanded that those slaves to whom he had given the money should be called to him so that he might know what they had gained by doing business.
And the first appeared, saying, Master, your mina has gained ten minas.
And he said to him, Well [i]done,[/i] good slave. Because you have become [xref]a[/xref]faithful in the least, [note]1[/note]have authority [xref]b[/xref]over ten cities.
verse.note: Signifying the overcomers' reigning over the nations ([link]Rev. 2:26[/link]; [link]20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]).

verse.text: And the second came, saying, Your mina, master, has made five minas.
And he said to this one as well, And you, be over [note]1[/note]five cities.
verse.note: Indicating that the overcoming saints' reigning in the coming kingdom as a reward will differ in extent.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And the other came, saying, Master, behold your mina, which I [note]2[/note]kept laid away in a [xref]a[/xref]handkerchief;
verse.note: For [link]vv. 20-26[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 25:24-29[/link].

Signifying that the unfaithful believers keep their salvation in an idle way instead of using it productively. To keep the Lord's salvation laid away is to not make use of it. Such idleness toward the Lord will cause the unfaithful believers to be condemned and to suffer loss.

verse.text: For I was afraid of you, because you are a [note]1[/note]harsh man: you withdraw what you did not deposit, and you reap what you did [xref]a[/xref]not sow.
verse.note: Demanding strictly; not as strong as [i]hard[/i] in [link]Matt. 25:24[/link] (see note 3 there).

verse.text: He said to him, Out of your mouth I will [note]1[/note]judge you, [xref]a[/xref]wicked slave. You knew that I am a harsh man, withdrawing what I did not deposit and reaping what I did not sow.
verse.note: Or, condemn.

verse.text: Why then did you not put my money [note]1[/note]in the bank, and when I came, I would have collected it with interest?
verse.note: Lit., on the table (of the moneychanger).

verse.text: And to those standing by he said, Take the mina away from him, and give [i]it[/i] to the one who has the ten minas.
And they said to him, Master, he has ten minas.
I tell you that to everyone who [xref]a[/xref]has, [i]more[/i] shall be given, but from him who does not have, even that which he has shall be taken away.
However, these enemies of mine, who did not want me to reign over them, bring [i]them[/i] here and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]slay them before me.
verse.note: Signifying that all the unbelieving Jews who reject the Savior will perish.

verse.text: And having said these things, He went on before [i]them,[/i] [note]1[/note]going up to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem.
verse.note: In the preceding verse the Savior finished His ministry. Now the time came when He needed to go up to Jerusalem to present Himself to the death ordained by God for the accomplishing of God's eternal redemption (see notes [link book="Mark" chapter="10"]1[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 10[/link]). Although He knew that the leaders of Judaism were seeking the opportunity to kill Him, He still went straight ahead boldly.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And as He drew near to [xref]a[/xref]Bethphage and [xref]b[/xref]Bethany, near the [xref]c[/xref]mount which is called Olivet, He [xref]d[/xref]sent two of the disciples,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 29-38[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 21:1-9[/link].

verse.text: Saying, Go into the village opposite [i]you,[/i] in which, as you are entering, you will find a colt tied, on which [xref]a[/xref]no man has ever yet sat; untie it and lead [i]it here.[/i]
And if anyone asks you, Why are you untying [i]it?[/i] thus shall you say, Because the Lord has need of it.
And those who were sent went away and [xref]a[/xref]found [i]it[/i] even as He had told them.
And as they were untying the [xref]a[/xref]colt, its masters said to them, Why are you untying the colt?
And they said, Because the Lord has need of it.
And they brought it to Jesus. And when they had thrown their garments on the colt, they put Jesus on [i]it.[/i]
And as He went, they [note]1[/note]spread their own [xref]a[/xref]garments in the road.
verse.note: Lit., were spreading out under.

verse.text: And as He was already drawing near to the descent of the Mount of Olives, all the multitude of the disciples began to rejoice and [xref]a[/xref]praise God with a loud voice for all the works of power which they had [xref]b[/xref]seen,
Saying, Blessed is the [xref]a[/xref]King who comes in the [xref]b[/xref]name of the Lord! Peace in heaven and glory in the [xref]c[/xref]highest!
And some of the Pharisees from the crowd [xref]a[/xref]said to Him, Teacher, rebuke Your disciples.
And He answered and said, I tell you, If these shall be silent, the [xref]a[/xref]stones will cry out.
And as He drew near, He saw the city and [xref]a[/xref]wept over it,
Saying, If you knew in this day, even you, the [xref]a[/xref]things that are for [i]your[/i] [note]1[/note]peace! But now they have been hidden from your eyes.
verse.note: This will be in the restoration of Israel ([link]Acts 1:6[/link]) after the Savior's return.
