verse.text: For [i]the[/i] days will come upon you when your enemies will throw up a [xref]a[/xref]rampart before you, and will [xref]b[/xref]encircle you, and will press you in on every side,

And they will [note]1[/note]level you to the ground and your children within you, and they will not leave a [xref]a[/xref]stone upon a stone in you, because you did not know the time of your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]visitation.
verse.note: This was fulfilled in A.D. 70 through the Roman prince Titus with his army.

The Savior's first coming, when He visited them in grace in the acceptable year of the Lord ([link]2:10-14[/link]; [link]4:18-22[/link]). To miss the Lord's visitation of grace and thereby lose the opportunity to repent and be saved will cause a person to be judged and to regret forever.

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]entered into the temple and began to cast out those who were selling,
Saying to them, It is written, "And My [xref]a[/xref]house shall be a house of prayer," but you have made it a den of [xref]b[/xref]robbers.
And He [xref]a[/xref]taught daily in the temple. But the chief priests and the scribes and the leaders of the people sought to [xref]b[/xref]destroy Him;
Yet they could not find anything that they might do, for all the people were hanging upon Him, listening.

And on one of the days, as [note]1[/note]He was [xref]a[/xref]teaching the people in the [xref]b[/xref]temple and announcing the good news, the chief priests and the scribes with the elders [xref]c[/xref]came upon [i]Him,[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 11[/link].

verse.text: And spoke, saying to Him, Tell us by what [xref]a[/xref]authority You do these things, or who is the one who gave You this authority?
And He answered and said to them, I also will ask you [i]one[/i] thing, and you tell Me:
The [xref]a[/xref]baptism of John, was it from [xref]b[/xref]heaven or from men?
And they reasoned together among themselves, saying, If we say, From heaven, He will say, Why did you [xref]a[/xref]not believe him?
But if we say, From men, all the people will stone us to death, for they are persuaded that John was a [xref]a[/xref]prophet.
And they answered that they did not know where it was from.
And Jesus said to them, [note]1[/note]Neither do I tell you by what authority I do these things.
verse.note: See note [link]27[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 21[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He began to speak to the people this [xref]a[/xref]parable: A certain man [xref]b[/xref]planted a [xref]c[/xref]vineyard and leased it out to [xref]d[/xref]vinedressers and went [xref]e[/xref]abroad for a considerable time.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 9-19[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 21:33-46[/link] and [link]Mark 12:1-12[/link].

verse.text: And at [i]the proper[/i] time he [xref]a[/xref]sent a slave to the vinedressers so that they might give him some of the fruit of the vineyard; but the vinedressers [xref]b[/xref]beat [i]him[/i] and sent him away empty-handed.
And he went on to send another slave, but they beat that one also, and dishonored [i]him,[/i] and sent [i]him[/i] away empty-handed.
And he went on to send a third, but that one also they wounded and threw out.
And the master of the vineyard said, What shall I do? I will send my son, the [xref]a[/xref]beloved; they will [note]1[/note]probably respect this one.
verse.note: An expression of one's reasonable hope.

verse.text: But when the vinedressers saw him, they reasoned with one another, saying, This is the [xref]a[/xref]heir; let us kill him that the inheritance may become ours.
And they threw him [xref]a[/xref]out of the vineyard and [xref]b[/xref]killed [i]him.[/i] What then will the master of the vineyard do to them?
He will come and [xref]a[/xref]destroy these vinedressers and will give the vineyard to [xref]b[/xref]others. And when they heard [i]this,[/i] they said, May it never happen!
But He looked at them, and said, What then is this that is written, [xref]a[/xref]"The stone which the builders rejected, this has become the head of the corner"?
Everyone who falls on that [xref]a[/xref]stone shall be broken to pieces; but on whomever it falls, it shall crush him to powder and scatter him like [xref]b[/xref]chaff.
And the scribes and the chief priests sought to lay hands on Him in that hour; yet they feared the people, for they perceived that [i]it was[/i] with them in view [i]that[/i] He spoke this parable.

[note]1[/note]And they [xref]a[/xref]watched [i]Him[/i] closely and [xref]b[/xref]sent spies who [xref]c[/xref]feigned themselves to be righteous, in order that they might lay hold on some [xref]d[/xref]word of His, so as to [xref]e[/xref]deliver Him up to the rule and authority of the [xref]f[/xref]governor.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 20-26[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 22:15-22[/link].

verse.text: And they questioned Him, saying, Teacher, we know that You speak and teach correctly, [note]1[/note]and do not accept [i]man's[/i] [xref]a[/xref]person, but teach the [xref]b[/xref]way of God in truth.
verse.note: Lit., and do not accept a face.

verse.text: Is it lawful for us to pay [xref]a[/xref]taxes to [xref]b[/xref]Caesar, or not?
But He perceived their [xref]a[/xref]craftiness and said to them,
Show Me a [xref]a[/xref]denarius. Whose image and inscription does it have? And they said, Caesar's.
And He said to them, Therefore [xref]a[/xref]render the things that are Caesar's to Caesar, and the things that are God's to God.
And they were not able to lay hold of a [xref]a[/xref]saying of His in the presence of the people; and marveling at His answer, they kept silent.
[note]1[/note]And some of the [xref]a[/xref]Sadducees, who say there is no [xref]b[/xref]resurrection, came to [i]Him[/i] and [xref]c[/xref]questioned Him,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 27-38[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 22:23-32[/link].

verse.text: Saying, Teacher, Moses wrote for us, If anyone's brother has a [xref]a[/xref]wife and dies, and this one is childless, his brother should take the wife and raise up seed to his brother.
There were then seven brothers. And the first took a wife and died childless;
And the second[note]1[/note];
verse.note: Some MSS add, took the wife, and this one died childless.

verse.text: And the third took her; and similarly the seven also did not leave children and died.
Finally the woman also died.
In the resurrection, therefore, which one's wife does the woman become? For the seven had her as wife.
And Jesus said to them, The [xref]a[/xref]sons of this age [xref]b[/xref]marry and are given in marriage,
But those who are counted [xref]a[/xref]worthy to obtain that [note]1[/note]age and the resurrection from the dead neither marry nor are given in marriage;
verse.note: The coming age of the kingdom ([link]13:28-29[/link]; [link]22:18[/link]) and the resurrection of life ([link]John 5:29[/link]; [link]Luke 14:14[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]) are eternal blessings and enjoyments in the eternal life for the believers who are counted worthy ([link]18:29-30[/link]; [link]Matt. 19:28-29[/link]).

verse.text: For neither can they [xref]a[/xref]die anymore, for they are equal to [xref]b[/xref]angels, and they are [xref]c[/xref]sons of God, being sons of the [xref]d[/xref]resurrection.

But that the dead are raised, even Moses disclosed [i]in the section[/i] concerning the [xref]a[/xref]bush, when he calls the Lord the God of [xref]b[/xref]Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob.
Now He is not the God of the dead, but of the living, for to Him all men are [xref]a[/xref]living.
And some of the scribes answered and said, Teacher, You have spoken [xref]a[/xref]well.
For they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]no longer dared to question Him about anything.
verse.note: The faultfinding opposers' insidious questions exposed their evil, subtlety, and meanness, which were the exact opposites of the Man-Savior's perfection, wisdom, and dignity. This vindicated Him in His human perfection with His divine splendor and muzzled them in their hateful plot and their Satan-instigated conspiracy (see note [link]46[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 22[/link]). They were trying to find fault with the Man-Savior, but eventually they were subdued by Him, the perfect and blameless One.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He [xref]a[/xref]said to them, How [i]is it that[/i] they say that the Christ is [xref]b[/xref]David's son?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 41-44[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 22:41-45[/link].

verse.text: For David himself says in the book of Psalms, [xref]a[/xref]"The Lord said to my Lord, [xref]b[/xref]Sit at My right hand,
Until I set Your enemies as a footstool for Your feet."
David therefore calls Him Lord, and how is He [xref]a[/xref]his [note]1[/note]son?
verse.note: See note [link]37[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 12[/link].

verse.text: And as all the people were listening, He [xref]a[/xref]said to His disciples,

[note]1[/note]Beware of the scribes, who like to walk around in long robes, and love [xref]a[/xref]greetings in the [xref]b[/xref]marketplaces and chief seats in the synagogues and [xref]c[/xref]places of honor at the dinners,
verse.note: After muzzling all His opposers, the Savior warned His disciples of the hypocrisy and evils of the scribes, indicating that they were condemned by the One in whom they tried their best to find fault.

verse.text: Who devour widows' houses, and for a [note]1[/note]pretense make long prayers. These shall receive [xref]a[/xref]greater [note]2[/note]judgment.
verse.note: Down through the ages prayer has been offered as a pretense and has been misused by man.
Or, punishment, condemnation.

verse.text: And He looked up and [note]1[/note]saw the [xref]a[/xref]rich [xref]b[/xref]casting their [note]2[/note]gifts into the [xref]c[/xref]treasury.
verse.note: See note [link]41[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 12[/link].
Things offered to God (so in [link]v. 4[/link]).

verse.text: And He saw a certain [note]1[/note]impoverished widow casting there two [xref]a[/xref]lepta.
verse.note: A stronger word than [i]poor,[/i] indicating a penniless condition.

verse.text: And He said, Truly I tell you that this [xref]a[/xref]poor widow has cast in more than all [i]of them,[/i]
For all these out of their surplus have cast in [i]something[/i] into the gifts, but she out of her lack has cast in all the [xref]a[/xref]living that she had.
[note]1[/note]And as some were speaking about the [xref]a[/xref]temple, that it was adorned with [note]2[/note]beautiful stones and [note]3[/note]consecrated offerings, He said,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 5-19[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:1-13[/link] and [link]Mark 13:1-13[/link].
The things for God that have a beautiful appearance but no reality will be rejected by God.
Or, votive gifts.

verse.text: As for these things which you are looking at, the days will come in which there will not be left a [xref]a[/xref]stone upon a stone which will not be thrown down.
And they questioned Him, saying, Teacher, when therefore will these things be? And what will be the sign [xref]a[/xref]when these things are about to take place?
And He said, [xref]a[/xref]See that you are not led astray, for many will come in My [xref]b[/xref]name, saying, I am [i]the Christ![/i] and, The time has drawn near! Do not go after them.
And when you hear of wars and revolutions, do not be terrified, for these things must take place first; but the end [i]does[/i] not [i]come[/i] immediately.
Then He said to them, Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom;
And there will be great [xref]a[/xref]earthquakes, and in various places [xref]b[/xref]famines and pestilences; and there will be terrors and great [xref]c[/xref]signs from heaven.

But before all these things they will lay their hands on you and persecute [i]you,[/i] [xref]a[/xref]delivering [i]you[/i] up to the synagogues and [xref]b[/xref]prisons, [xref]c[/xref]bringing [i]you[/i] before [xref]d[/xref]kings and governors for the sake of My name.
It will turn out to you for a testimony.
Settle [i]it[/i] therefore in your hearts not to [xref]a[/xref]take thought beforehand how to reply in defense,
For I will give you a [xref]a[/xref]mouth and wisdom which all those opposing you will not be able to [xref]b[/xref]resist or refute.
And you will be [note]1[/note]delivered up even by parents and brothers and relatives and friends, and they will put some of you to death.
verse.note: Or, betrayed. So throughout the book.

verse.text: And you will be [xref]a[/xref]hated by all because of My name,
Yet a [xref]a[/xref]hair of your head shall by no means perish.
In your [xref]a[/xref]endurance you will [note]1[/note]possess your souls.
verse.note: Or, acquire, keep intact.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But when you [xref]a[/xref]see Jerusalem [xref]b[/xref]surrounded by armies, then know that her desolation has drawn near.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 20-28[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:15-31[/link].

verse.text: Then let those in Judea flee to the mountains, and let those in her midst get out, and let not those in the country enter into her,
Because these are days of [xref]a[/xref]vengeance, that all the things written may be fulfilled.
Woe to those who are [xref]a[/xref]pregnant and to those nursing babies in those days, for there will be great [note]1[/note]distress upon the land and [xref]b[/xref]wrath to this people.
verse.note: Or, necessity.

verse.text: And they will fall by the edge of the sword and will be led captive into all the nations; and Jerusalem will be [xref]a[/xref]trampled by the [note]1[/note]Gentiles until the times of the [note]1[/note]Gentiles are [xref]b[/xref]fulfilled.
verse.note: Or, nations.

verse.text: And there will be signs in the [xref]a[/xref]sun and moon and stars, and upon the earth anguish of nations in perplexity at the [xref]b[/xref]roaring of the sea and the billows,
Men [note]1[/note]fainting from fear and expectation of the things coming upon the [note]2[/note]inhabited earth, for the powers of the heavens will be [xref]a[/xref]shaken.
verse.note: Lit., stopping breathing.
Referring to the earth at the time of the great tribulation, which will come in the last three and a half years of this age ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:10[/link]).

verse.text: And then they will see the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man [xref]b[/xref]coming in a cloud with power and great [xref]c[/xref]glory.
And when these things begin to happen, stand erect and lift up your heads, because your [xref]a[/xref]redemption is drawing near.
[note]1[/note]And He told them a parable: Look at the [xref]a[/xref]fig tree and all the trees.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 29-33[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:32-35[/link].

verse.text: As soon as they sprout [i]leaves,[/i] you see [i]it[/i] and know of yourselves that the summer is already near.
So also you, when you see these things happening, know that the kingdom of God is near.
Truly I tell you that [xref]a[/xref]this generation shall by no means pass away until all things happen.
Heaven and earth shall [xref]a[/xref]pass away, but My [xref]b[/xref]words shall by no means pass away.

But [xref]a[/xref]take heed to yourselves lest perhaps your hearts be weighed down with [note]1[/note]debauchery and [xref]b[/xref]drunkenness and the [xref]c[/xref]anxieties of life, and that day come upon you [note]2[/note]suddenly as a [xref]d[/xref]snare.
verse.note: Indicating a drunken hangover.
Or, unexpectedly.

verse.text: For it will come in upon all those [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dwelling on the face of all the earth.
verse.note: Lit., sitting.

verse.text: But be [xref]a[/xref]watchful at every time, [xref]b[/xref]beseeching that you would [note]1[/note]prevail to [note]2[/note]escape [note]3[/note]all these things which are about to happen and [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]stand before the Son of Man.
verse.note: Have strength and ability. The strength and ability to escape the great tribulation come from watchfulness and beseeching.

To be taken, raptured, before the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]; [link]Luke 17:34-36[/link] and note [link]34[sup]2[/sup][/link]), which will be a severe trial upon the whole inhabited earth ([link]Rev. 3:10[/link]). To be thus raptured is to be kept "out of the hour of trial, which is about to come on the whole inhabited earth, to try them who dwell on the earth" ([link]Rev. 3:10[/link]).
All the things of the great tribulation.

Corresponding with [i]standing[/i] in [link]Rev. 14:1[/link], indicating that the raptured overcomers will stand before the Savior on Mount Zion in the heavens before the great tribulation (cf. [link]Rev. 12:5-6[/link], [link]14[/link]).

verse.text: Now during the day He was in the temple [xref]a[/xref]teaching, but during the night He [xref]b[/xref]went out and stayed on the mountain called [xref]c[/xref]Olivet.
And all the people would come early in the [xref]a[/xref]morning to Him in the temple to hear Him.
[note]1[/note]Now the Feast of Unleavened Bread, which is called the [xref]a[/xref]Passover, was drawing [xref]b[/xref]near.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-2[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 26:2-5[/link].

verse.text: And the chief priests and the scribes were seeking a way to [xref]a[/xref]do away with Him, for they [xref]b[/xref]feared the people.
And [xref]a[/xref]Satan entered into [xref]b[/xref]Judas who was called [xref]c[/xref]Iscariot and was of the number of the twelve.
And he went away and conferred with the chief priests and [xref]a[/xref]officers [i]as to[/i] how he might deliver Him up to them.
And they rejoiced and promised to give him [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]money.
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 14[/link].

verse.text: And he consented and sought opportunity to [xref]a[/xref]deliver Him up to them apart from the crowd.
And the day of [note]1[/note]Unleavened Bread came, on which the [xref]a[/xref]passover had to be [note]2[/note]sacrificed.
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 26[/link].
See note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 14[/link].

verse.text: And He sent Peter and John, saying, Go and prepare the passover for us, so that we may eat [i]it.[/i]
And they said to Him, Where do You want us to prepare [i]it?[/i]
And He told them, Behold, as you are entering into the city, a man carrying an earthen jar of water will meet you. Follow him into the house which he enters.
And you shall say to the master of the house, The [xref]a[/xref]Teacher says to you, Where is the guest room where I may eat the passover with My disciples?
And that one will show you a large [xref]a[/xref]upper room furnished; prepare there.
And they left and [xref]a[/xref]found [i]it[/i] even as He had told them, and they prepared the passover.
And when the hour came, He [xref]a[/xref]reclined [i]at table,[/i] and the apostles with Him.
And He said to them, With desire I have desired to [note]1[/note]eat this passover with you before I suffer,
verse.note: The eating and drinking in [link]vv. 15-18[/link] were the keeping of the last Feast of the Passover before the instituting of the Lord's supper in [link]vv. 19-20[/link].

verse.text: For I tell you that I shall by no means eat it until [note]1[/note]it is fulfilled in the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God.
verse.note: [i]It,[/i] and what is mentioned in [link]v. 18[/link], refer to the last passover in [link]v. 15[/link], which will be fully fulfilled in the coming kingdom of God, when the Savior will feast with the overcoming saints ([link]v. 30[/link]; [link]13:28-29[/link]).

verse.text: And He received a cup and gave [xref]a[/xref]thanks and said, Take this and divide [i]it[/i] among yourselves;
For I tell you, I shall by no means drink from now on of the [note]1[/note]product of the vine until the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God comes.
verse.note: Referring to the juice of the grape.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He took a [xref]a[/xref]loaf and gave thanks, and He broke [i]it[/i] and gave [i]it[/i] to them, saying, This is My [xref]b[/xref]body which is being given for you; do this in remembrance of Me.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 19-20[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 26:26-28[/link] and [link]Mark 14:22-24[/link].

verse.text: And similarly the cup after they had dined, saying, This cup is the [xref]a[/xref]new covenant [i]established[/i] in My [xref]b[/xref]blood, which is being poured out for you.
But behold, the [xref]a[/xref]hand of the [note]1[/note]one [xref]b[/xref]betraying Me is [xref]c[/xref]with Me at the table.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 14[/link].

verse.text: For the Son of Man is going according to what has been [xref]a[/xref]determined, but woe to that man through whom He is betrayed!
And they began to discuss among themselves who then of them it was who was about to do this.
[note]1[/note]And a [note]2[/note]contention [note]1[/note]also occurred among them as to which of them seemed to be [xref]a[/xref]greatest.
verse.note: In the preceding verse the disciples had a discussion; here they had a contention also.
The word shows a love of strife, an eagerness to contend.

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]said to them, The kings of the Gentiles lord it over them, and those who have authority over them are called benefactors.
But you shall not be so; but let the [xref]a[/xref]greatest among you become like the youngest, and the one who [xref]b[/xref]leads like the one who [note]1[/note]serves.
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 20[/link].

verse.text: For who is greater, the one who reclines [i]at table[/i] or the one who serves? Is it not the one who reclines [i]at table?[/i] But I am in your midst as the one who [xref]a[/xref]serves.
But you are those who have remained with Me throughout My [xref]a[/xref]trials.
And I [note]1[/note]appoint to you, even as My Father has [note]1[/note]appointed to Me, a [xref]a[/xref]kingdom,
verse.note: Or, covenant to...covenanted to.

verse.text: That you may eat and drink at My [note]1[/note]table in My [xref]a[/xref]kingdom; and you will sit on [xref]b[/xref]thrones [xref]c[/xref]judging the twelve [xref]d[/xref]tribes of Israel.
verse.note: This is the feast in the parable in [link]Matt. 22:1-4[/link] and the marriage feast in [link]Rev. 19:9[/link], which is for the overcoming saints (see note [link]16[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Simon, Simon, behold, [xref]a[/xref]Satan has asked to have you [i]all[/i] to [xref]b[/xref]sift [i]you[/i] as wheat.
verse.note: Some MSS add, And the Lord said.

verse.text: But I have [xref]a[/xref]made petition concerning you that your faith would not fail; and you, once you have turned again, [xref]b[/xref]establish your brothers.
And he said to Him, Lord, I am ready to go with You both to [xref]a[/xref]prison and to [xref]b[/xref]death.
But He said, I tell you, Peter, a [xref]a[/xref]rooster will not crow today until you deny three times that you know Me.
And He said to them, When I sent you [xref]a[/xref]without purse and bag and sandals, you did not lack anything, did you? And they said, Nothing.
And He said to them, But now, let him who has a purse take [i]it,[/i] likewise also a bag; and he who has no sword, let him sell his garment and [note]1[/note]buy one.
verse.note: At that time people carried a sword while traveling, just as they carried a purse and a bag. The Savior's word did not mean that He wanted the disciples to arm themselves to resist the coming arrest (cf. [link]vv. 49-51[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:51-54[/link]); rather, it indicated that the people's attitude toward Him had changed.

verse.text: For I tell you that this which is written must be accomplished in Me, "And He was [xref]a[/xref]counted with the lawless." For indeed that which concerns Me has [i]its[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]fulfillment.
verse.note: Lit., end.

verse.text: And they said, Lord, behold, here are two [xref]a[/xref]swords. And He said to them, It is [note]1[/note]enough.
verse.note: Indicating not that two swords were sufficient but that the disciples had said enough (cf. [link]1 Kings 19:4[/link]).

verse.text: And He came out and went according to His custom to the [xref]a[/xref]Mount of Olives; and the disciples also followed Him.
And when He came to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]place, He [xref]b[/xref]said to them, [xref]c[/xref]Pray that you do not enter into temptation.
verse.note: Gethsemane ([link]Matt. 26:36[/link]).

verse.text: And He withdrew from them about a stone's throw, and He [xref]a[/xref]knelt down and [xref]b[/xref]prayed,
Saying, Father, if You are willing, remove this [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cup from Me; yet, not My [xref]b[/xref]will, but [note]2[/note]Yours be done.
verse.note: Referring to the Savior's death on the cross.
See note [link]36[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 14[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And an [xref]a[/xref]angel from heaven appeared to Him, strengthening Him.
verse.note: Some ancient MSS omit [link]vv. 43[/link] and [link]44[/link].

verse.text: And being in [xref]a[/xref]agony He prayed more earnestly, and His sweat became like great drops of blood falling down upon the ground.
And when He rose up from prayer and came to the disciples, He found them sleeping from [note]1[/note]sorrow,
verse.note: Sorrow and lack of prayer resulted in sound sleep. Hence, the Lord said, "Rise up and pray."

verse.text: And He said to them, Why are you sleeping? Rise up and pray that you may not enter into temptation.
[xref]a[/xref]While He was still speaking, behold, a crowd [i]came,[/i] and he who is called [xref]b[/xref]Judas, one of the twelve, was going before them and drew near to Jesus to kiss Him.
But Jesus said to him, Judas, are you betraying the Son of Man with a kiss?
And those around Him, seeing what would happen, said, Lord, shall we strike with the [xref]a[/xref]sword?
And a certain one of them struck the slave of the high priest and took off his right [xref]a[/xref]ear.
But Jesus answered and said, [note]1[/note]Let [i]them go[/i] this far. And touching his ear, He healed him.
verse.note: This may mean, "Let them arrest Me at this time." The Lord, realizing the situation, willingly accepted it because God had permitted it.

verse.text: And Jesus said to the chief priests and [xref]a[/xref]officers of the temple and elders who had come up against Him, Have you come out as against a robber with swords and clubs?

While I was with you day by day in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]temple, you did not stretch out your hands against Me. But this is your [xref]b[/xref]hour and the [xref]c[/xref]authority of darkness.
verse.note: See note [link]49[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 14[/link].

verse.text: And having arrested Him, they [xref]a[/xref]led [i]Him away,[/i] and brought [i]Him[/i] into the house of the high priest.[separator]But Peter [xref]b[/xref]followed at a distance.
And when they had lit a fire in the middle of the [xref]a[/xref]courtyard and sat down together, Peter sat among them.
And a certain servant girl, seeing him seated in the light [i]of the fire,[/i] looked intently at him and said, This man was with Him too.
But he denied [i]it,[/i] saying, I do not know Him, woman.
And after a short time, another person, seeing him, said, You also are one of them. But Peter said, Man, I am not!
And after about one hour had passed, [note]1[/note]another one insisted, saying, Surely this man was also with Him, for he is also a [xref]a[/xref]Galilean.
verse.note: See note [link]73[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 26[/link].

verse.text: But Peter said, Man, I do not know what you are saying. And instantly, while he was still speaking, a rooster crowed.
And the Lord turned and looked at Peter, and Peter remembered the word of the Lord, how He had said to him, Before a [xref]a[/xref]rooster crows today, you will deny Me three times.
And he went outside and wept bitterly.
And the men who were holding Him mocked Him and [xref]a[/xref]beat [i]Him.[/i]
And they blindfolded Him and questioned [i]Him,[/i] saying, [note]1[/note]Prophesy! [xref]a[/xref]Who is the one who hit You?
verse.note: See note [link]68[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 26[/link].

verse.text: And they said many other things against Him, [xref]a[/xref]blaspheming.
And when it became day, the assembly of the elders of the people, both [xref]a[/xref]chief priests and scribes, were gathered together, and they led Him away to their [note]1[/note]Sanhedrin, saying,
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]6[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]If You are the [xref]b[/xref]Christ, tell us. But He said to them, If I tell you, you shall by no means believe;
And if I ask [i]you,[/i] you shall by no means answer.
But from now on the [note]1[/note]Son of Man will be seated at the [xref]a[/xref]right hand of the power of God.
verse.note: See note [link]64[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 26[/link].

verse.text: And they all said, Are You then the [note]1[/note]Son of God? And He said to them, [xref]a[/xref]You say [i]rightly[/i] that I am.
verse.note: The devil had used this same matter to tempt the Savior ([link]4:3[/link], [link]9[/link]). In that case and in this one, the attack was aimed at the Lord's deity.

verse.text: And they said, What further need do we have of testimony? For we have heard [i]it[/i] ourselves from His mouth.
And the entire multitude of them rose up and [xref]a[/xref]led Him before [note]1[/note]Pilate.
verse.note: See notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link] and [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 15[/link].

verse.text: And they began to accuse Him, saying, We found this man [note]1[/note]perverting our nation and forbidding [i]people[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]pay taxes to [xref]b[/xref]Caesar, and saying that He Himself is Christ, a [xref]c[/xref]King.
verse.note: Or, turning away, misleading (cf. [link]v. 14[/link]).

verse.text: And Pilate [xref]a[/xref]asked Him, saying, Are You the [xref]b[/xref]King of the Jews? And answering him, He said, [note]1[/note]It is as you [xref]c[/xref]say.
verse.note: This answer is to be understood as a "distinct affirmation" (Alford).

verse.text: And Pilate said to the chief priests and the crowds, I find [xref]a[/xref]no fault in this man.
But they were vehement, saying, He stirs up the people, teaching throughout the whole of Judea, beginning from [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Galilee even to [note]1[/note]this place.
verse.note: This indicates that the "whole of Judea" comprised Galilee and the region in which Jerusalem was (see note [link]44[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]).

verse.text: And when Pilate heard [i]this,[/i] he asked whether the man was a [xref]a[/xref]Galilean.
And when he realized that He was of [xref]a[/xref]Herod's jurisdiction, he sent Him up to Herod, who also himself was in Jerusalem in those days.

And when Herod saw Jesus, he rejoiced greatly, for he had wanted to [xref]a[/xref]see Him for a considerable time, because he had [xref]b[/xref]heard about Him, and was hoping to see some [xref]c[/xref]sign done by Him.
And he questioned Him with [note]1[/note]many words, but He answered him [note]2[/note]nothing.
verse.note: Or, considerable, sufficient.
This is the fulfillment of [link]Isa. 53:7[/link].

verse.text: And the chief priests and the scribes stood by, vehemently accusing Him.
And Herod with his soldiers, having [xref]a[/xref]despised Him and [xref]b[/xref]mocked [i]Him,[/i] [xref]c[/xref]threw around [i]Him[/i] splendid clothing and sent Him back to Pilate.
And both [xref]a[/xref]Herod and Pilate became friends with one another on that very day, for they had previously been at enmity toward each other.
And Pilate, calling together the chief priests and the [xref]a[/xref]rulers and the people,

Said to them, You have brought this man to me as one who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]turns the people away, and behold, I have examined [i]Him[/i] before you and found [xref]b[/xref]no fault in this man regarding the accusations you bring against Him.
verse.note: Implying to turn the people away from their civil and religious allegiance.

verse.text: No, neither has Herod, for he sent Him back to us, and behold, nothing worthy of death has been done by Him.
I will therefore [xref]a[/xref]discipline Him and [xref]b[/xref]release [i]Him.[/i]
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Now he was obliged to release to them one [i]prisoner[/i] at the feast.
verse.note: Some ancient authorities omit this verse.

verse.text: But they cried out all together, saying, Take this man [xref]a[/xref]away and [xref]b[/xref]release to us Barabbas.
He was one who, for a certain [xref]a[/xref]insurrection that occurred in the city and for murder, had been thrown into the prison.
But Pilate, wanting to release Jesus, addressed them again;
But they continued to shout, saying, Crucify, crucify Him!

But he said to them a third time, Why, what evil has this man [xref]a[/xref]done? I have found [xref]b[/xref]no cause of death in Him; I will therefore [xref]c[/xref]discipline Him and release [i]Him.[/i]
But they pressed him with loud voices, asking that He be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]crucified, and their voices prevailed.
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: And Pilate [note]1[/note]gave sentence that their request be carried out,
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 15[/link]. The accusations of the Jewish religious leaders exposed their falseness and deceitfulness in their religion, and the judgment made by the Roman rulers exposed their darkness and rottenness in their politics. At the same time, the Man-Savior again was vindicated in His human perfection of the highest standard, with His all-surpassing divine splendor. This was the strongest sign that He was fully qualified to be the Substitute for the sinners for whom He intended to die.

verse.text: And he released him who had been thrown into prison for [xref]a[/xref]insurrection and murder, whom they asked for; but Jesus he [xref]b[/xref]delivered up to their will.
And as they led Him away, they laid hold of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Simon, a certain Cyrenian, coming from the country, and they placed the cross upon him to carry [i]it[/i] behind Jesus.
verse.note: See note [link]32[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: And a great multitude of the people and of women who were mourning and lamenting Him followed Him.
But Jesus turned to them and said, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Daughters of [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem, do not weep over Me, but weep over yourselves and over your children.
verse.note: Referring to the inhabitants.

verse.text: For behold, the [xref]a[/xref]days are coming in which they will say, Blessed are the barren, and the wombs which have not borne, and the breasts which have not [xref]b[/xref]nourished.
Then they will begin to say to the [xref]a[/xref]mountains, Fall on us! and to the hills, Cover us!
For if they do these things with the [note]1[/note]tree full of sap, what will happen with the one that is [xref]a[/xref]dry?
verse.note: The tree full of sap signifies the Man-Savior, who is living and full of life. The dry wood signifies the deadened people of Jerusalem, who were void of life sap.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]two others also, [i]who were[/i] criminals, were led with Him to be executed.
And when they came to the place called The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Skull, there they [xref]b[/xref]crucified Him and the [xref]c[/xref]criminals, one on the right and one on the left.
verse.note: See note [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: And Jesus said, Father, [xref]a[/xref]forgive them, for they do [xref]b[/xref]not know what they are doing. And dividing His garments, they cast [xref]c[/xref]lots.

And the people stood by, [xref]a[/xref]looking on. And the [xref]b[/xref]rulers also [xref]c[/xref]sneered, saying, He [xref]d[/xref]saved others; let Him save [xref]e[/xref]Himself if this is the [xref]f[/xref]Christ of God, the [xref]g[/xref]Chosen One!
And the soldiers also [xref]a[/xref]mocked Him, coming to [i]Him[/i] and offering Him [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]vinegar,
verse.note: See note [link]48[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: And saying, If You are the [xref]a[/xref]King of the Jews, save Yourself!
And there was also an inscription over Him[note]1[/note]: THIS IS THE [xref]a[/xref]KING OF THE JEWS.
verse.note: Some MSS add, written in Greek and Roman and Hebrew letters.

verse.text: And one of the criminals who were hanged [i]there[/i] [xref]a[/xref]blasphemed Him, saying, Are You not the Christ? Save Yourself and us!
But the other, answering, rebuked him and said, Do you not even fear God, since you are in the same [note]1[/note]judgment?
verse.note: Or, punishment, condemnation.

verse.text: And we justly, for we are receiving what we deserve for what we did, but this man has done nothing [note]1[/note]amiss.
verse.note: Or, out of place.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And he said, Jesus, remember me when You [xref]a[/xref]come into Your kingdom.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 42-43a[/link], some MSS read, And he said to Jesus, Remember me, Lord, when You come in Your kingdom. And Jesus said to him...

verse.text: And He said to him, [note]1[/note]Truly I say to you, Today you shall be with Me in [note]2[/note]Paradise.
verse.note: This record of salvation, beginning at [link]v. 40[/link], is unique to this Gospel. It displays the effectiveness of the Man-Savior's vicarious death and the highest standard of morality of His salvation.
See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Cor. 12[/link].

verse.text: And it was now about the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sixth hour, and [xref]b[/xref]darkness fell over the whole land until the ninth hour,
verse.note: See note [link]45[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]The sun's [i]light[/i] failing; and the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]veil of the temple was split down the middle.
verse.note: Some MSS read, And the sun was darkened.
See note [link]51[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: And crying with a [xref]a[/xref]loud voice, Jesus said, Father, into Your hands [note]1[/note]I [xref]b[/xref]commit My spirit. And saying this, He expired.
verse.note: See note [link]50[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: Now when the [xref]a[/xref]centurion saw what had happened, he [xref]b[/xref]glorified God, saying, Certainly this man was [xref]c[/xref]righteous.
And all the crowds who came together at this spectacle, when they beheld the things that happened, returned, beating their [xref]a[/xref]breasts.
And all those who [xref]a[/xref]knew Him, and the [xref]b[/xref]women who accompanied Him from Galilee, stood at a [xref]c[/xref]distance, observing these things.
And behold, there was a man named [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Joseph, who was a member of the Council, and a good and righteous man
verse.note: See note [link]38[sup]1[/sup] in John 19[/link].

verse.text: (This man had not consented to their counsel and action), from Arimathea, a city of the Jews, who was [xref]a[/xref]expecting the kingdom of God.
This man came to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.
And he took [i]it[/i] down and wrapped it in a fine linen cloth, and [note]1[/note]laid Him in a tomb hewn in the rock, where [xref]a[/xref]no one had ever lain.
verse.note: This was for the fulfillment of [link]Isa. 53:9b[/link].

verse.text: And it was the day of [note]1[/note]preparation, and the Sabbath was [note]2[/note]coming on.
verse.note: See note [link]62[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].
Lit., was coming to light.

verse.text: And the women who had come together with Him out of Galilee followed after and beheld the tomb and how His body was laid.
And they returned and prepared [xref]a[/xref]spices and [xref]b[/xref]ointment. And on the [xref]c[/xref]Sabbath they [note]1[/note]rested according to the commandment.
verse.note: This was a real rest for all God's chosen people and even for the entire universe. Because the Savior had fully accomplished redemption for all, all could rest.

verse.text: Now [xref]a[/xref]on the [note]1[/note]first day of the week, at early dawn, [note]2[/note]they [note]3[/note]came to the tomb, bringing the [xref]b[/xref]spices which they had prepared.
verse.note: See notes [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 28[/link] and [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in John 20[/link].
Referring to the women mentioned in [link]v. 10[/link] and [link]23:55[/link].
See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in John 20[/link].

verse.text: And they found the [xref]a[/xref]stone rolled away from the tomb;
But when they entered, they did [xref]a[/xref]not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
And while they [i]stood[/i] perplexed about this, behold, [xref]a[/xref]two [xref]b[/xref]men stood by them in [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]dazzling clothing.
verse.note: Or, shining.

verse.text: And they became [xref]a[/xref]frightened and bowed their faces to the ground, and [i]the men[/i] said to them, Why are you seeking the [xref]b[/xref]living One among the dead?
He is not here but has been [note]1[/note]raised. Remember how He [xref]a[/xref]spoke to you while He was still in [xref]b[/xref]Galilee,
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 16[/link].

verse.text: Saying that the Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men and be crucified and on the [xref]a[/xref]third day rise up.
And they [xref]a[/xref]remembered His words.
And returning from the tomb, they [xref]a[/xref]reported all these things to the eleven and to all the rest.
Now they were [xref]a[/xref]Mary the Magdalene and [xref]b[/xref]Joanna and [note]1[/note]Mary the [i]mother[/i] of James and the rest of the women with them, who told these things to the apostles.
verse.note: The mother of the Man-Savior.

verse.text: And these words appeared [note]1[/note]to them as [note]2[/note]nonsense, and they did [xref]a[/xref]not believe them.
verse.note: Lit., in their sight.
Used in medical language in reference to the wild talk of delirium.

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]Peter rose up and ran to the tomb; and stooping to look in, he saw the [xref]b[/xref]linen cloths alone, and he went away to his own [i]home,[/i] marveling at what had happened.
And behold, [xref]a[/xref]two of them were going on the same day to a village named Emmaus, which was sixty [note]1[/note]stadia away from Jerusalem.
verse.note: One stadion equals about six hundred feet; therefore, sixty stadia would equal about seven miles.

verse.text: And they were talking to each other concerning all these things which had occurred.
And while they were talking and discussing, Jesus Himself drew near and [note]1[/note]went with them.
verse.note: The Man-Savior was now in resurrection walking with the two disciples. This differed from His walking with His disciples before His death ([link]19:28[/link]).

verse.text: But their eyes were [xref]a[/xref]kept from recognizing Him.
And He said to them, What are these words which you are exchanging with one another while you are walking? And they stood still, looking sad.
And one [i]of them,[/i] Cleopas by name, answered and said to Him, Do You alone dwell as a stranger in Jerusalem and not know the things which have taken place in it in these days?

And He said to them, What things? And they [note]1[/note]said to Him, The things concerning Jesus the [xref]a[/xref]Nazarene, who was a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Prophet [xref]c[/xref]powerful in work and word before God and all the people;
verse.note: In their blindness they thought they knew more than the resurrected Savior.

Lit., a man, a Prophet. The two disciples knew the Savior in the flesh ([link]2 Cor. 5:16[/link]), not in His resurrection. They knew His power in work and word, not the power of His resurrection ([link]Phil. 3:10[/link]).

verse.text: And how the chief priests and our [xref]a[/xref]rulers [xref]b[/xref]delivered Him up to the [xref]c[/xref]sentence of death and [xref]d[/xref]crucified Him.
But we were hoping that He was the One who was about to [xref]a[/xref]redeem Israel. Indeed, besides all these things, it is [i]now[/i] going on the third day since these things took place.
But moreover some [xref]a[/xref]women from among us amazed us. Being at the tomb early
And [xref]a[/xref]not finding His body, they came saying that they had also seen a vision of [xref]b[/xref]angels, who said that He is [xref]c[/xref]living.
And some of those with us went to the [xref]a[/xref]tomb and found [i]it[/i] even as the women also said, but they did not see Him.
And He said to them, O [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]foolish and slow of heart to believe in all that the prophets have spoken!
verse.note: The word in Greek indicates dullness of perception.

verse.text: Was it not necessary for the Christ to [xref]a[/xref]suffer these things and [note]1[/note]enter into His [xref]b[/xref]glory?
verse.note: Referring to His resurrection ([link]v. 46[/link]), which brought Him into glory ([link]1 Cor. 15:43a[/link]; [link]Acts 3:13a[/link], [link]15a[/link]).

verse.text: And beginning from [xref]a[/xref]Moses and from all the [xref]b[/xref]prophets, He explained to them clearly in [note]1[/note]all the [xref]c[/xref]Scriptures the things concerning [xref]d[/xref]Himself.
verse.note: Including the Law of Moses, the Prophets, and the Psalms ([link]v. 44[/link]) — the entire Old Testament.

verse.text: And they drew near to the village where they were going, and He acted as though He would go farther.
And they constrained Him, saying, Stay with us, because it is near evening and the day is already gone by. And He went in to [xref]a[/xref]stay with them.
And as He reclined [i]at table[/i] with them, He took the loaf and [xref]a[/xref]blessed [i]it,[/i] and having broken [i]it,[/i] He began handing [i]it[/i] to them.
And their eyes were [note]1[/note]opened, and they recognized Him; and [note]2[/note]He disappeared from them.
verse.note: The Savior walked with them ([link]v. 15[/link]) and stayed with them ([link]v. 29[/link]), but it was not until they offered the loaf to Him and He broke it that their eyes were opened to recognize Him. They needed Him to walk and stay with them, but He needed them to offer the loaf to Him so that He could break it that He might open their eyes to see Him.
Lit., He became invisible from them. The Savior was still with them. He did not leave them but only became invisible.

verse.text: And they said to one another, Was not our heart burning within us while He was speaking to us on the road, while He was opening to us the [xref]a[/xref]Scriptures?
And they rose up that very hour and returned to [note]1[/note]Jerusalem, and they found the [xref]a[/xref]eleven and those with them assembled together,
verse.note: Jerusalem was the place where the resurrected Savior wanted His disciples to remain before the day of Pentecost ([link]v. 49[/link]; [link]Acts 1:4[/link]).

verse.text: Saying, The Lord really has been raised and has [xref]a[/xref]appeared to Simon.
And they related the things [i]that occurred[/i] on the road, and how He was made [xref]a[/xref]known to them in the breaking of the bread.
And as they were speaking these things, He Himself stood in their midst and said to them, [xref]a[/xref]Peace to you.
But they were terrified and became [xref]a[/xref]frightened and thought they beheld a [note]1[/note]spirit.
verse.note: A ghost or specter.

verse.text: And He said to them, Why are you troubled, and why do doubts arise in your heart?
See My [xref]a[/xref]hands and My feet, that [i]it[/i] is I Myself. [xref]b[/xref]Touch Me and see, for a spirit does not have [note]1[/note]flesh and bones as you behold Me having.
verse.note: This is the Man-Savior's resurrected body, which is spiritual ([link]1 Cor. 15:44[/link]) and which is a body of glory ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link] and note 3).

verse.text: And when He had said this, He [xref]a[/xref]showed them His hands and His feet.
And while they still [note]1[/note]did not believe for [xref]a[/xref]joy and were marveling, He said to them, Do you have anything here to [xref]b[/xref]eat?
verse.note: Lit., were disbelieving.

verse.text: And they handed Him a piece of broiled [xref]a[/xref]fish;
And He took [i]it[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]ate before them.

And He said to them, These are My words which I [xref]a[/xref]spoke to you while I was still with you, that all the things written in the [note]1[/note]Law of [xref]b[/xref]Moses and the Prophets and Psalms concerning Me must be fulfilled.
verse.note: The Law of Moses, the Prophets, and the Psalms are the three sections of the Old Testament, that is, "all the Scriptures" ([link]v. 27[/link]). The Savior's word here unveils that the entire Old Testament is a revelation of Him and that He is its center and content.

verse.text: Then He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]opened their mind to understand the Scriptures;
verse.note: Indicating that to understand the Scriptures requires that our mind be opened by the Lord Spirit through His enlightening ([link]Eph. 1:18[/link]).

verse.text: And He said to them, Thus it is [xref]a[/xref]written, that the Christ would [xref]b[/xref]suffer and rise up from the dead on the [xref]c[/xref]third day,
And that repentance for [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]forgiveness of sins would be proclaimed in His [xref]b[/xref]name to all the [xref]c[/xref]nations, beginning from [xref]d[/xref]Jerusalem.
verse.note: Forgiveness of sins could be proclaimed only after the Man-Savior's vicarious death for the sinners' sins had been accomplished and had been verified by His resurrection ([link]v. 46[/link]; cf. [link]Rom. 4:25[/link]). The Gospel of John, as the Gospel of the God-Savior, emphasizes life for fruit-bearing ([link]John 15:5[/link]). The Gospel of Luke, as the Gospel of the Man-Savior, stresses forgiveness of sins for proclaiming. To bear fruit in life requires the Spirit of life essentially, received through the breathing of the Spirit ([link]John 20:22[/link]). To proclaim forgiveness of sins requires the Spirit of power economically, received through the baptism in the Spirit ([link]Acts 1:5[/link], [link]8[/link]). To bear fruit is a matter of life; to proclaim forgiveness of sins is a matter of power.

verse.text: You are [xref]a[/xref]witnesses of these things.

And behold, I send forth the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]promise of My Father upon you; but as for you, [note]2[/note]stay in the city until you [note]3[/note]put on [xref]b[/xref]power from on [xref]c[/xref]high.
verse.note: The promise given in [link]Joel 2:28-29[/link], fulfilled on the day of Pentecost ([link]Acts 1:4-5[/link], [link]8[/link]; [link]2:1-4[/link], [link]16-18[/link]). It concerned the outpouring of the Spirit as the power from on high for the believers' ministry economically. This is different from the Spirit of life being breathed into the disciples ([link]John 20:22[/link] and note 1, par. 1) by the resurrected Savior on the day of His resurrection for His indwelling that He might be life to them essentially.
Lit., sit.

Regarding the Spirit of life, we need to breathe Him in as the breath ([link]John 20:22[/link]); regarding the Spirit of power, we need to put Him on as the uniform, typified by the mantle of Elijah ([link]2 Kings 2:9[/link], [link]13-15[/link]). The former, like the water of life, requires our drinking ([link]John 7:37-39[/link]); the latter, like the water of baptism, requires our being immersed ([link]Acts 1:5[/link]). These are the two aspects of the one Spirit for our experience ([link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]). The indwelling of the Spirit of life is essential and is for our life and living; the outpouring of the Spirit of power is economical and is for our ministry and work.

verse.text: And He led them out as far as [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Bethany, and He lifted up His hands and blessed them.
verse.note: At the Mount of Olives ([link]Acts 1:12[/link]).

verse.text: And while He blessed them, He parted from them and was [note]1[/note]carried up into [xref]a[/xref]heaven.
verse.note: In this book Luke displays and presents mainly five crucial and excellent aspects concerning the Man-Savior: His birth, ministry, death, resurrection, and ascension.[br][br](1) His birth was of and with the Spirit of God essentially, making Him a God-man so that He could be the Man-Savior ([link]1:35[/link]).[br][br](2) His ministry was by and through the Spirit of God economically for the carrying out of God's economy in His jubilee ([link]4:18-19[/link]).[br][br](3) His death was by His being the God-man to accomplish God's redemption for man ([link]23:42-43[/link]) and to release Himself into man as the fire of life to burn on the earth ([link]12:49-50[/link]).[br][br](4) His resurrection was (a) God's vindication of Him and of His work; (b) His success in all His achievements; and (c) His victory over the universal enemy of God.[br][br](5) His ascension was God's exaltation of Him, which made Him the Christ of God and the Lord of all ([link]Acts 2:36[/link]) that He might carry out His heavenly ministry on the earth as the all-inclusive Spirit poured out from the heavens upon His Body, which is constituted of His believers ([link]Acts 2:4[/link], [link]17-18[/link]), as recorded by Luke in his further writing, the Acts.

verse.text: And they [xref]a[/xref]worshipped Him and returned to [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem with great [xref]c[/xref]joy,
And were continually in the [xref]a[/xref]temple, [xref]b[/xref]blessing God. [note]1[/note]
verse.note: Some MSS add, Amen.
